PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-
The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos.

This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence.
The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honorable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we are strongly supportive of proposals for the establishment of electors' initiated referenda for the making of laws and alteration of the Constitution, in a form somewhat similar to that proposed in a Bill presented by Senator Macklin on 23rd September 1987.

That electors' initiative proposals have widespread support within our community, and in every major political party, being an established aim of the Democrat Party, fifty five years as endorsed Labor Party policy, recommended by the Queensland branch of the National Party, and raised recently in the Liberal Party's Law and Justice policy.
That the evidence of their great value and popularity as a superior development of democratic government, by and for the people, has been amply demonstrated in several advanced democracies overseas.
That the proposed legislation would be the greatest Bicentennial gift our Legislature could give to our people, the recognition that we have come of age.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name for the next day of sitting for disallowance of the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Regulations (Amendment). I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances wanted to know whether an administrative discretion to exempt a person from an export inspection charge could be challenged by a person who felt unfairly denied the exemption. The drafting of the regulations left this somewhat unclear. The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, has explained to the Committee's satisfaction that Administrative Appeals Tribunal review rights do exist in this case. However, since the Committee, with the help of a legal adviser, had some difficulty in determining the existence of this appeal right, it may be that companies or individuals could experience similar difficulty. The Committee will be writing to the Minister to ask that the drafting be improved to make it clear that a right of review is available. In accordance with the Committee's usual practice I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's brief correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
The Hon. Peter Morris, M.P.
Minister for Resources
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 19 November 1987, the Committee considered the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Regulations (being Statutory Rules 1987 No. 251, tabled in the Senate on 4 November 1987). The Committee seeks your advice on a difficult legal point concerning the applicability of review rights.

New paragraph 4(aa) provides for the exemption from an export inspection charge of dairy products prepared at an establishment which has a departmentally approved quality control system in relation to an export control order. The Committee has examined the provisions for approval of such a system as they appear in the relevant export control orders, from the point of view of the remedies available to a person who claims exemption and is denied that relief. The Committee noted that under Part 20 of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders (Export Control Order No. 7 of 1986), reconsideration and AAT review rights exist regarding initial decisions `made under an order'. (Order 11) Thus, rights of review would appear to exist in regard to order 23 of the Dairy Produce Orders (Orders No. 4 of 1985) referring to Approved Quality Assurance arrangements. The Committee seeks your advice as to whether the arrangements specified in that order are also the arrangements referred to in new paragraph 4(aa) which refers, not to an Approved Quality Assurance arrangement but to `an arrangement between the Department and the occupier of the establishment in relation to an export control order, being an arrangement with respect to inspection procedures to ensure the quality of products prepared'. If notwithstanding the different descriptions used, the arrangements are the same then it would appear that the approval is reviewable and the exemption is, therefore, an automatic right. On the other hand, if different `arrangements' are contemplated within new paragraph 4(aa) (and the Committee doubts that a Product Monitoring System referred to in Order 24 and Schedule 5 Part 2 of the Dairy Produce Orders would be an `arrangement') then the Committee seeks your help in identifying the avenue of appeal should an approval ever be unfairly refused with the consequent loss of exemption from charges.
This is a rather complex area of delegated law-making and the Committee would be greatly assisted by your expert guidance.
Yours sincerely,
BOB COLLINS
Chairman
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations
and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter to Mr Morris dated 27 November 1987 in which you sought comments on the applicability of review rights in relation to paragraph 4 (aa) of the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Regulations Amendments (Statutory Rules 1987 No. 251).

The reference in paragraph 4 (aa) of the regulations to ``an arrangement between the Department and the occupier of the establishment in relation to an export control order, being an arrangement with respect to inspection procedures to ensure the quality of products prepared'' does relate to an Approved Quality Assurance arrangement referred to in order 23 of the Dairy Produce Orders (Orders No. 4 of 1985). Consequently, the exemption contained in paragraph 4 (aa) of the Regulations is pursuant to order 23 of the Dairy Produce Orders has been entered into. The Secretary's discretion in order 23 is reviewable in accordance with Part 20 of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as amended.
Thank you for the opportunity to clarify this matter for the Committee.
Yours sincerely
Peter Cook

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980, to incorporate into that Act the tariff proposal tabled in the House of Representatives on 15 September 1987. As part of the 1987-88 Budget, the proposal increased the export duty on uranium concentrate produced from the Alligator Rivers Region in the Northern Territory from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram as from 15 September 1987. This export duty, which has been imposed on uranium since 1980, is to partially offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities by the Office of the Supervising Scientist associated with uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers Region. The increase in the duty proposed in this Bill will recover about 75 per cent of those costs.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist was created in recognition of the special need to protect the environment of the Alligator Rivers Region, an area of great beauty and world-wide environmental significance, from the effects of uranium mining operations both in the short and the long term.

To this end, the Office of the Supervising Scientist has, amongst other things, conducted significant research on uranium tailings management, including the conduct of geomorphological studies to provide the information necessary to ensure that radioactive tailings can be contained or isolated from that environment for thousands of years. The Office also monitors the effects of radiation exposure on workers involved with uranium mining, as well as on people living in the Alligator Rivers Region and is developing strategies for the revegetation of decommissioned mine sites, so that the long term rehabilitation of the habitat of surrounding mining areas can be planned.

The Government's continued commitment to the Office of the Supervising Scientist will ensure that the Alligator Rivers area, which includes the Kakadu National Park, is fully protected from any possible effects of uranium mining operations.

Clause 4 of the Bill provides an exemption from the increased levy in the standard transitional situations where uranium concentrate was loaded on to a vessel, or was part of a consignment, the loading of which commenced prior to the 15 September 1987 commencement of this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposed increased duty is expected to raise an additional $0.6m during that part of the 1987-88 financial year to which it applies, and an additional $0.9m in a full year. At the proposed new rate, the total uranium export levy is expected to raise $3.7m in the 1987-88 financial year and $4m in a full year. The proposed levy will now recover approximately 75 per cent of the annual cost of the uranium related monitoring and research activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for Alligator Rivers Region.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for a technical amendment to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 which will be required as a consequence of the passage of the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987.

The amendments provided for in the Bill will ensure that the Commonwealth borrowing levy will continue to apply to Australian Airlines and its wholly owned subsidiaries after the airline is converted from a statutory authority to a public company.

The Commonwealth borrowing levy is imposed on borrowing by all Commonwealth semi-government authorities and government-owned companies, other than those engaged in the business and financial intermediation (such as the Commonwealth Banks and Australian Industry Development Corporation).
The Bill will ensure that the revenue raised from the levy, estimated at $1.3m in 1987, will be unaffected by the changed legal structure of Australian Airlines.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, introduced by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), is designed to give the Government greater powers with respect to World Heritage properties. In particular, its purpose is to stop logging in the wet tropical forests of north Queensland. The Bill does not specifically deal with that because regulations have been made to do that. The Bill repeals those regulations and new regulations will be subsequently made to achieve that purpose. But it is quite clear from the policy of the Government, not just that of the Minister, Senator Richardson, but the whole of the Government's policy as explained on numerous occasions over the last 18 months and again in the second reading speech in support of this Bill, that the Government has adopted the policies and views of the extreme environmental lobby.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the prime objectives of that lobby is the prevention or cessation of logging in forests, whether they be rainforests in the wet tropics, the temperate zones or wherever. Basically, its policies would result in the ending of our forest product industries. I believe that that is the ultimate objective of these extreme environmentalists who have captured this Government, in particular the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

The Bill makes some other amendments to environmental legislation. In fact, it is misnamed conservation legislation because there is a very real difference between conservation and preservation. This legislation really ought to be called the preservation legislation Bill because its purpose is to preserve and protect the environment in its natural and pristine condition. The result of that would be no economic development or commercial use of resources. Conservation means-this is where some confusion is, no doubt, intended by the Government-the judicious use of natural resources to ensure that society receives the maximum benefits from the use of those resources. So conservation implies a sensible management of the economy to preserve environmental conditions in a way which does not totally exclude economic and social factors. Indeed, that is referred to as multiple land use. Although is some cases that does not exclude some areas from being kept in their pristine state it is certainly not consistent with the total prohibition on logging which seems to be the Government's policy in relation to this vast area that we are debating.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is in the chamber, seemed to understand that concept when he was Minister for Resources and Energy and there seemed to be some hope for the Government's understanding. Indeed, I think the Prime Minister also agreed with that view for a time. However, as I have said, it was only when the Government was suddenly captured by the extreme environmentalists that the policy of multiple land use which Senator Evans was endeavouring to develop in the Kakadu National Park area, was suddenly overthrown and, for the last 18 months or two years, the Government has embarked on this infatuation with the extreme environmentalists.

The Bill also does one or two other things. It creates a power to appoint inspectors; it greatly widens the application of the World Heritage properties that are the subject of inquiry as to whether they are of World Heritage standards; it excludes the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act applying to any decisions of the Minister in relation to World Heritage matters; and one or two other things. I do not propose to go through those matters as Senator Puplick, who is leading the debate for the Opposition, has dealt very adequately with our objections to them. I want to concentrate my remarks on what I believe is the fundamental issue which faces the Senate in relation to this legislation, that is, the Government's firm commitment to the total abolition of an important economic activity in a very important and growing region of Australia. Of course, in this case, the Act will apply generally but its specific purpose is to prevent logging from taking place in the north Queensland rainforest. This area extends from Townsville to Cooktown. It embraces the actual forest area that was the subject of the Government's preservation policy which covers about 9,000 square kilometres and about 850,000 hectares of rainforest. Including the main centres of Townsville and Cairns it has a population of over 250,000 people. This area is a vibrant and growing part of the Australian economy. However, one of the important industries and resources of that area has traditionally been sawmilling and the use of products from the rainforest.

The statistics in relation to these matters, which I propose to cover briefly, have been very adequately dealt with in an excellent report entitled The Analysis of the Socioeconomic Impact of the World Heritage Listing of the Rainforests of North Queensland by Professor Percy Harris, Professor of Economics at James Cook University in north Queensland. This report was submitted in November 1987. He submitted the report in response to the Government's own request originally for comments on its proposal to list this area. The Government also specifically commissioned some socioeconomic studies to find out what are the facts about this area. But of course, we know that that is total eyewash on the part of Senator Richardson and the Government, because clearly they had decided to seek to include the whole of this area on the World Heritage List, and to stop logging throughout the whole of this area, regardless of what the socioeconomic consequences of those actions would be. That is the price that the Government has already paid to the extreme environmentalists, who have been seeking exactly that purpose for some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without consultation.

—As Senator Sheil says, without adequate consultation. The extraordinary thing is that the Government itself commissioned these socioeconomic studies. It has now received the reports. I have been asking Senator Richardson's office when those reports will be made available. The answer has been that the Government is still studying the reports and will not table them until it has studied them. It is clear that the reports will not be made available to this Parliament for the purposes of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have a government bringing in legislation to enable it to absolutely ban any logging activities, any commercial sawmilling activities, in this area, regardless of the socioeconomic consequences of that action. Quite clearly, the Government made that decision before it ever sought the socioeconomic studies. So, it is total window-dressing for the Government to suggest that somehow it is concerned about these matters. Clearly the Government is not concerned about the socioeconomic effects of what it is doing to this region of Australia. If it were, it would not have made these decisions until the reports had been received and a study of them had been completed. That is not the case, because Senator Richardson will not table them as, he says, the Government has not finished studying them.

We are very fortunate that we have a report from the Professor of Economics at James Cook University. It is a detailed report, from which I have drawn a good deal for my speech to the Senate this morning. I want to read what might be called the vital statistics of this region, as found by Professor Harris. I might say that these statistics were first provided by the Queensland Government and the forest industries of the region some months ago when I visited there. Professor Harris has given the authority of an independent academic study to statistics which were clearly substantially correct as provided by the industry and the Government of Queensland, of which, of course, the Federal Government would not take any notice.

Professor Harris said that to stop the supply of timber from the rainforests would mean the closure of at least half of the mills in this area, that is, four-fifths of the production. Nine hundred people are directly dependent on the log processing industry. Four-fifths of them are dependent on logs from the proposed World Heritage area. Professor Harris considered Townsville and Cairns separately from the study area as he did not think that the cessation of logging would have much socioeconomic effect on those two major towns. However, he pointed out that in the seven remaining local authority areas the unemployment rate is already 15 per cent. The initial effect of stopping logging would be a loss of 1,092 jobs. However, from multiplier effects in the region, 1,994 jobs, almost 2,000 jobs, would be lost as a result of the Government's decision to stop logging. The unemployment rate in the seven local authority areas will increase to 18 per cent as a result of the cessation of logging. In the Herberton Shire alone the resulting unemployment rate will be 43 per cent.

The Government has said that it will create 640 jobs in the area. But, as Professor Harris points out, even if it does achieve that-and he has very great doubts, for the reasons he sets out, that it will be able to create 640 permanent jobs-there will still be a direct loss of 1,092 jobs and an indirect loss of 2,000 jobs. So the Government's proposal to create new jobs in the area is really just eyewash. Professor Harris points out that most of the timber workers are older people who have not completed year 12 education, have few outside qualifications and have a very low occupational mobility. These people have been longstanding, traditional timber workers. In fact, 22 per cent of them have been in the industry for over 20 years. In his opinion, their occupational mobility is zero.

Professor Harris casts grave doubts on the 250 plantation jobs that the Government says it will create. He says that the new plantation jobs will not be sustainable in the long term, even though they might offer some temporary employment at that level. But, essentially, the point is that the Government's own proposed compensation, so to speak, does not come within cooee of replacing the jobs that will be lost as a result of its decision. The other day my colleague Senator Boswell made an impassioned plea in the Senate in relation to those job losses. I simply add my support to the grave concern expressed by him as a senator from Queensland.

This is a loss for Australia as a whole. The Government has a total indifference to a loss of jobs of this magnitude in this area of Australia. People in other parts of Australia whose jobs depend on sawmilling face a gloomy future. The threat presented by the Government will have dire consequences for Tasmania, southern New South Wales and the south-west of Western Australia. As I have said, the Government is now on course to cave in completely to the extreme greenies who are determined virtually to close down the forest industries of Australia, with the connivance and active support of the Hawke Government and one of its Ministers, Senator Richardson.

The Government justifies all this on the grounds that this area is of such great environmental significance that it should be preserved in its natural, pristine state and that it should be nominated for World Heritage listing. I acknow-ledge-and I have ever since I took an interest in this matter-that the rainforest in north Queensland is an area of great environmental value. This forest area covers 850,000 hectares. I understand that experts indicate that originally there were just over one million hectares of rainforest. The development that has occurred in this area with cane growing, dairy farming and other activities has reduced the rainforest to 850,000 hectares. This is not a great reduction from the original rainforest area. Where accessible, that area of rainforest has been subject over 100 years to logging operations. In recent years, under very strict policies of the Queensland Government, the industry has been following a practice of sustainable yield logging which the Senate Select Committee on National Resources found in 1981 was a perfectly proper way of preserving forests. Indeed, the industry has clearly preserved them because, despite the fact that logging has gone on for 100 years, the rainforest is still of sufficient value for the Federal Government to propose listing the area for World Heritage purposes. Obviously the logging policies have not, by the Government's own admission, despoiled or damaged the World Heritage value of this area.

Even if one thought that logging was inconsistent with World Heritage listing-I do not agree with that, but let us assume that one does-the fact is that only 20 per cent of this area is subject to a logging policy at all. Large parts of it are inaccessible and will never be able to be logged. Also it is the policy of the Queensland Government that only 20 per cent of this area will ever be logged. Therefore, if this Government were genuinely interested in coming to reasonable conclusions and rational decisions, it only has to nominate 80 per cent of the area for World Heritage listing. If it did that, the desire of most people to preserve a substantial area of this forest in its pristine state would be satisfied, the economic and social damage would not be done and interests would be preserved. It is beyond belief that the Government would be so irrational and uncaring of people's interests that it could go ahead with this legislation and the subsequent regulations to achieve a purpose which could be just as easily achieved by a different policy which preserved those important interests.

We are talking about an area of more than 70,000 people. The whole region will be affected in some way by the decision to stop logging. Two thousand jobs will be lost and in a population of 70,000 that will have a huge impact on the region. As Professor Harris said, it may not affect Townsville and Cairns, but it will affect all those other towns in this region of 70,000 people. Indeed, there will be a great community loss because of loss of income. More than $30m a year will be lost in income, not just to the people affected but also to Australia as a whole. These matters have been totally ignored by the Government. We know that the Government is doing this because it has been captured by the extreme environmentalists. Senator Richardson was converted only because he thought that the Government might lose the last election and that it needed every vote it could get. That was the only reason why the Government adopted this policy and, incidentally, left the then Minister for Resources and Energy high and dry with his multiple land use policies at the same time. That does not seem to worry him. He seems to have survived that and is happy to remain a member of a government which has totally rejected the rational and sane policies of multiple land use which he supported.

The Government dresses up this naked piece of political vote buying with claims that it has the highest motives of the World Heritage listing and is observing its duties under the World Heritage Convention. It wants these powers because it says that it may not have sufficient powers under the existing Act. That argument has been completely demolished by Senator Puplick who pointed out that last week in the case known as the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests inquiry the High Court said that the Government had these powers under the existing legislation. That is by the way. The important point is that we have a government which has been prepared since the advent of the World Heritage properties conservation legislation to pursue policies of total preservation, regardless of the economic consequences. It has done it in Tasmania and in the Kakadu area and is going to do it again in north Queensland. What will it do next?

I was going to spend a little time in my speech today analysing the World Heritage Convention, and to point out that decisions under that Convention are the responsibility of what is called the national state party to the Convention, which is the Commonwealth Government; the word `state' is not used in the sense of the Australian States. The Commonwealth Government has responsibility to give effect to such conventions. The Convention does not state that one cannot log in a World Heritage area; nor does it state that one cannot mine there. In fact, one of the ironies of this policy of the Government is that it will allow some mining to take place in the World Heritage area in the north Queensland rainforests.

Last week in the Lemonthyme case the High Court emphasised the fact that discretion is with the government and the parliament of a country that is a party to the Convention. That has always been the position, but the constitutional law position has been misunderstood. The majority view of the High Court in the Tasmanian dam case stated:

. . . when Parliament exercises the external affairs power so as to carry into effect or give effect to such a treaty, it is for Parliament to choose the means by which this is to be achieved, provided at any rate that the means chosen are capable of being reasonably considered appropriate and adapted to that end.

So, of course, the High Court can still say, `No, Parliament cannot do that because it is not consistent with the Convention; you are going too far'. But it emphasises that it is for the Parliament to decide how to give effect to the duties under the Convention. The High Court made it even more clear subsequently in its decision last week when it said:
The terms of Art. 3-
that is, of the Convention-

together with the second sentence of Art. 4 and the qualifications in the opening words of Art. 5 are entirely consistent with the acknowledgement of State sovereignty in Art. 6 and with the recognition that each State, in giving effect to the obligations imposed by the Convention, with respect to the heritage situated on its territory will naturally have to take account of competing considerations, economic and otherwise. Thus though each State has a duty to identify and delineate the heritage in its territory, the performance of this duty will depend in many respects on the judgment of that State.

So it is for the judgment of this Government, of this Parliament, to decide these competing considerations between the preservation of World Heritage values and the economic and social interests of the people who would be affected by a rigid application of the Convention. To make it perfectly clear, the High Court last week said:

This is not to say that a failure on the part of a State to protect land, which is ultimately identified as part of the heritage, pending that identification is a breach of duty capable of enforcement.

The High Court recognises that there is no internal duty or obligation capable of enforcement under international law. That is the reality. I suppose the best one can say about members of the Government is that the poor things do not understand the law. They are not being very well advised by Senator Evans, a former Attorney-General, who does understand these things. They are certainly not very well advised by the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. They do not understand the elements of the obligation that is imposed upon them under this World Heritage Convention to which they are so subservient. I conclude with a further quotation from the High Court:
It is for each State to determine what it will do by way of protecting a particular property pending resolution of its status as part of the heritage.

As the High Court said, it is for the state, that is the nation, concerned-its government, its parliament-to decide how to give effect to the convention. There is no reason why, under the World Heritage Convention or as a result of a High Court decision this Government has any sort of legal obligation to ban completely logging or mining. That is a total misunderstanding of the situation.

I have referred to the details of the report of Professor Harris. The Government's policy flies in the face of the Senate committee report and it flies in the face of its own working group which was established by the former Minister, Barry Cohen, to provide advice on rainforest conservation, because that group pointed out that there are competing interests and they have to be accommodated. The sad thing about all this is very well summarised by Professor Harris in his report when he says:

The social costs of Heritage Listing are heavily concentrated in a small part of Australia and on the inhabitants of communities in that area. For many of these people the outcome will be a total disruption of their current lives and their future expectations. The unquantifiable social benefits are spread widely throughout Australia-
that is, among those concerned, particularly the greenies-

and even the world, although there is not evidence as to what proportion of the people in Australia as a whole really care about the Heritage Listing. In particular, even if they support such a proposal, they have no idea of the social costs that will be imposed on some North Queensland communities, nor will ardent supporters be forced to place a monetary value on their support by making financial contributions to offset the costs they have imposed on others.

That is being done with the active support of this Government-a denial by this Government of all its social policy rhetoric. It is destroying needlessly the jobs of at least 2,000 people. It is damaging needlessly the economic interests of a large number of people in the north of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just come into the chamber, having chaired a meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which has been discussing the international implications of aid for the environment. That brought home to me the global responsibilities this country has to its place in the world's heritage and that we are not simply considering State functions, or even national functions, in that regard, but total global considerations. I think that the time has come to put parochial interests to one side and to take our place in the world. That is what the Government is seeking to do.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal has been said already in this place in support of World Heritage listing of the north Queensland rainforests. The Government's unfailing support for the conservation of our natural heritage cannot be disputed and our determination to protect the outstanding values of the wet tropics of north Queensland is demonstrative of our continuing commitment. The Queensland Government has attempted to surround the wet tropics nomination with controversy and misinformation and has steadfastly maintained its opposition to the World Heritage listing of this area. However, the Federal Government has maintained a cooperative and rational approach to negotiations with the Queensland Government over the issue of protection. Yet, the Queensland Government has refused to drop its assertion that logging the area should continue. It is the Queensland Government that has forced the presentation of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill.

That the north Queensland rainforest must be protected is an indisputable fact. The Federal Government is convinced that the natural values of the area satisfy the definition of `world heritage' specified in article 2 of the World Heritage Convention. Indeed, the broader evidence suggests that these rainforests comply with all four criteria, establishing outstanding universal value. Within the north Queensland rainforests there lives a diverse range of animal life. Some of these are threatened species, including, from time to time, apparently, Senator Boswell and some of his colleagues. The rainforests contain one of the world's largest collections of primitive flowering plant families and an enormous range of features of incredible natural beauty. There is also evidence on cultural grounds alone that the rainforests deserve World Heritage listing.

The final judgment will be made not by us but by the World Heritage Committee in December this year. The fact is that the Queensland Government cannot justify its irrational opposition to World Heritage listing of this area. The events of the past week should have left the Queensland Premier and his Ministers facing the hard fact that they were misguided in their belief that they could effectively oppose the nomination.

Apart from this probably short-lived attempt to prevent World Heritage nomination through the High Court of Australia, one of the Queensland Government's most concerted attempts to oppose the listing was the establishment of the Northern Rainforest Management Agency, known as NORMA, in September last year. The Queensland Government claimed that the agency was established to receive submissions on the World Heritage nomination. In fact, the Queensland Government believed that this agency could, if it provided a watertight case opposing the need for World Heritage listing, legitimise its own rainforest management practices. The Queensland Government is now facing a situation in which not one of the credible scientists attached to NORMA is prepared to deny the heritage significance of the north Queensland rainforests.

When NORMA was established both the Queensland Government and the scientists attached to the agency were emphatic that the agency would be an apolitical body-that is, a body formed purely to collect and independently assess data. Certainly I am aware that many people attached to the agency, particularly those academics who were attached to it, joined NORMA in the belief that their knowledge could further the sound conservation of the northern rainforests. I am aware that one scientist, Dr John Winter, wants to pull out of active consideration and has asked to be demoted to observer status.

The behaviour, in particular, of a key member of the agency-the chairman of its scientific committee, Dr Ross Hynes-has established beyond any doubt that NORMA is not an impartial body. As I will establish later, while Dr Hynes's activities have confirmed on several occasions his support for the Queensland Government's campaign against the listing, even he at times has admitted the environmental value of the wet tropics. At a public meeting held in Innisfail earlier this year, Dr Hynes endorsed a 1984 report by the president of the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland, Dr Aila Keto, arguing for the need to conserve the region. While Dr Hynes criticised the report for technical inaccuracies, he admitted that the northern development rainforests had environmental values and that some areas should never have been logged. He has also agreed with his committee colleagues that there should be no further logging of virgin rainforests-something which would virtually close the industry down overnight.

In fact, the NORMA scientific committee has already endorsed the Federal Government's decision to protect the north Queensland rainforests. Through a report leaked to the media some days ago-from which the Queensland Government has since tried to distance itself by claiming that it was only a preliminary report-this group has clearly established the environmental significance of the area. The report found that of the 167,000 hectares allocated for logging by the Queensland Forestry Department, around three-quarters, or 126,000 hectares, should not be logged. On the basis of this recommendation, the timber industry would be reduced to about 30 per cent of its 1987 levels. The report found that only 2.5 per cent of the total area nominated for the World Heritage listing should be considered a low priority for conservation. The report further found that some 84,000 hectares of rainforest that are not included within the World Heritage boundaries should also be considered of high conservation value.

Four different scenarios were outlined in the report. Each scenario involved a significant logging reduction. Even the scenario that would be seen to most benefit the Queensland timber required that the logging allocation of the Queensland Forestry Department be reduced by half. I point out that the report was based on inad-equate data. Information relating to flora was mostly restricted to one family-the proteaceae. A large volume of relevant information compiled by the Queensland Herbarium was not included. In contrast, that data was included in the Fede-ral Government's assessment of the area. The Queensland Government's consternation at the report can be judged by various claims made by the Queensland Premier, Mike Ahern, and the Minister for Tourism, National Parks and Sport, Geoff Muntz, to the effect that the report was stolen, was labelled an internal working document, or was not endorsed by the NORMA scientific committee. In fact, the NORMA secretary, Clive Hughes, claimed that the findings constituted an interim report and said that final results would not be available until the end of April. I understand from media reports that another scientific committee representative claimed that the report's findings were even the result of a computer malfunction.

I note also that various honourable senators who have taken part in the debate have tried to dismiss the findings and the significance of this report. This is a distortion as fraudulent as the Queensland Government's claims to good management of the rainforests. Many credible rainforest scientists did participate and provide data for the report. These scientists discussed the report at a meeting of the scientific committee on Tuesday, 23 February. Indicative of their strong support for both the report and its pro-heritage findings, the committee gave quite clear instructions to its chairman, Dr Ross Hynes, that he was not to indicate that any of the scientists were opposed to World Heritage listing. The worst fears of the scientists, that both NORMA and the State Government would either disown or manipulate their work, seem about to be realised. The behaviour of Dr Hynes has made a mockery of any claim that the Agency and the committee were established as an independent body.

Despite his initial endorsement of Dr Keto's assessment of the north Queensland rainforest, Dr Hynes has consistently maintained that effective management and conservation of the region could be maintained without the World Heritage listing. Dr Hynes chooses to ignore the fact that had the Federal Government not moved to nominate the area, the State Government would have maintained its singularly inactive approach to responsible management of the area. I understand that it was claimed at a meeting of the area. I understand that it was claimed at a meeting of the NORMA scientific committee that had planning mechanisms then considered been implemented only two years ago the Federal Government may have seen little need for World Heritage nomination. Dr Hynes at that meeting did not oppose that claim.

Dr Hynes advocates that an effective management plan incorporating the establishment of biosphere reserves could be used more effectively than World Heritage listing in management of the region. Dr Hynes obviously chooses to forget the Queensland Government's rejection last decade of biosphere reserve proposals for the Downey Creek, Johnstone River and Palmerston regions. There is no doubt that the Queensland Government, as it has ably demonstrated in the past, could not be trusted with the responsible management of this region. Yet, as an indication of Dr Hynes's stand as an advocate of the Queensland Government, I refer to an advertisement for public meetings held by NORMA in the north Queensland centres of Innisfail and Malanda. I have a copy of the advertisement here. It reads:
Come and hear the latest report on the vital work of NORMA's Scientific Committee opposed to world heritage listing of our rainforest.
I repeat it:
Come and hear the latest report on the vital work of NORMA's Scientific Committee opposed to world heritage listing of our rainforest.

I understand that since then Dr Hynes has claimed that the use of the word `opposed' was a clerical error. Yet, when called on by members of the scientific committee to repudiate the advertisement and dissociate the committee from its comments, Dr Hynes did nothing. Some of the most damning indictments of Dr Hynes's activities as chairman of the NORMA scientific committee are contained in a letter written to Dr Hynes by Dr Graham Harrington, Director of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) tropical forest research centre in Atherton. Incidentally, Dr Harrington refused an invitation to join NORMA but attended meetings of the scientific committee as an observer. Dr Harrington asserts, despite Dr Hynes's claims that he and NORMA are apolitical, that the direction that the committee had taken made it impossible for the tropical forest research centre to cooperate with the Agency. In his letter dated 26 February, Dr Harrington expressed profound unease-the words `profound unease' are his-about the public meeting addressed by Dr Hynes in Malanda in February. Dr Harrington maintains that the entire flavour of the Malanda meeting-and I quote from his letter-`was politically slanted in favour of the State Government, taking swipes at Canberra and anti-World Heritage'.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of AWU workers up there, too.
—I will deal with the Australian Workers Union (AWU) workers soon. Dr Harrington also quotes in his letter an alarming statement made at the meeting by Dr Hynes. Dr Hynes said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, parts of the rainforest are of such high conservation value, we have to live with that.

He was lamenting the fact that they were of such high value. Dr Harrington attacks what he describes as clear statements made at the meeting that the World Heritage listing was an attempt by the Federal Government to gain control over land constitutionally administered by the State. Statements such as this emerge as even more contemptuous when one considers another claim made by Dr Harrington, namely, that NORMA has failed to admit that it cannot produce a case for opposition to the World Heritage nomination. It is still seeking to do that and it is still unable to do so. Dr Harrington in his letter is clearly justifiably concerned that Dr Hynes's behaviour reflects on the genuinely impartial members of the scientific committee. Dr Harrington maintains in his letter:
A true representative of the scientific committee position has been that they supported and were undertaking an objective examination of future rainforest management in north Queensland.

Dr Harrington claims that members of the scientific committee, and those who refused to join it, had feared that the objective workings of the committee would be misused by NORMA for `a preconceived political objective'. Dr Harrington maintains that these claims were justified at the Malanda meeting.

The deceitful campaign waged by the Queensland Government over the supposed objectivity of NORMA does not constitute its only attempt to mislead us on this issue. Earlier this month my colleague Senator Richardson exposed a deliberate distortion by the Queensland Government of the amount of logging that has already taken place in the northern rainforests. The deceit only serves to reinforce further the Federal Government's decision to provide interim protection of the area that has been nominated. An independent and expert analysis of Queensland Forestry Department maps has revealed the true extent of logging in the region and shows just how little virgin rainforest remains in the area.

In its attempts to establish credibility as a responsible manager of the north Queensland rainforest, the Queensland Government has repeatedly argued that around 75 per cent of the north Queensland rainforest is already protected and would never be logged. This claim, the analysis shows, relates to all rainforests north of Townsville. The analysis commissioned by the Federal Government from the CSIRO rainforest scientists estimates that some 45 per cent of the remaining rainforest between Townsville and Cooktown, where the wet tropical rainforest is located, had been logged. Much of the remainder of the rainforest, the analysis shows, has not been logged only because the forest was inaccessible or because it did not contain enough commercial timber.

Yet the Queensland Government has grandstanded on a completely false claim that only 25 per cent of the forest has ever been logged. In the wet tropics the estimate would be more like 55 per cent. The analysis shows that logging has targeted certain types of rainforest-those containing suitable types and species of trees. Those areas that have not been logged appear to have remained untouched because they contain unsuitable types of trees. The Queensland Government clearly bases it management of this important region on the needs only of the timber industry, yet it expects to be considered as a responsible and effective manager of this area. NORMA was an attempt by the State Government to justify more than a century of mining of these forests for timber. NORMA now stands exposed as a political sham.

The Federal Government's decision to nominate the north Queensland rainforests for World Heritage listing has received a string of endorsements from prominent scientists worldwide. I shall list a few of those. Professor of Botany at Harvard University, Professor Peter Ashton, describes the northern rainforests as `unique' and `the last refuge of a quite extraordinary number of specialised plants and animals'. Ghillean France, Director of the Institute of Economic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden, endorses the nomination of a `unique and important area of the world's rainforest' and `an area of great biological importance'. Three scientists from Marlboro College in Vermont, United States of America, say that they `keenly appreciate the biological wealth that these forests represent to Australia and to the rest of the world'. Professor E. J. H. Corner, from the University of Cambridge, has described the area as unique, `with many endemic plants, as the relic of the tertiary rainforest that covered much of Australia'. He says:

If that forest is exploited and ruined, biology will suffer an irreplaceable loss and travellers will despair. Its full significance for the history of Australia is far from known, and it will require years of investigation.
Professor Paul Richards, from Oxford University, says that the north Queensland rainforests:
Have a special claim to protection. Like all the natural ecosystems of Australia, they are unique and unlike those of other continents, and they are already fragmented and seriously endangered.

As the Queensland Government now fights to maintain its program of barely controlled clearing of this valuable forest, it courts arguments from the timber and other industry representatives that logging should not only continue but also be extended further as the timber industry declines, because that is the only way in which employment levels can be maintained. I noted that Senator Boswell, in his earlier speech, expressed some concern about the loss of what he claimed were 2,000 to 3,000 jobs. He went on to say:

I want every Labor and Democrat senator, sitting here on a minimum of $48,000 a year with a large superannuation entitlement to fall back on, to consider that they are destroying the jobs of their mates-the jobs of their fellow unionists. I hope that they feel proud about it. They are breaking their families up; they are destroying their lives; they are decimating the assets of their families, whose houses are being devalued . . .

I sat through a number of debates at the time of the South East Queensland Electricity Board (SEQEB) dispute in Queensland. I can clearly recall Senator Boswell being quite dismissive about the claims that the 1,002 SEQEB employees had to either a wage or any concerns for their families or superannuation, In fact, Senator Boswell said:
The 800 people-
the number had dropped down to 800, which is fairly illustrative of Senator Boswell's liberal use of statistics-

will not get back their jobs because there are no jobs for them there; those jobs have been taken up by other people. One can not create another 800 jobs for the 800 people who have sacked themselves.

I wish Senator Boswell had displayed the same concerns for the SEQEB workers that he purports to show for the people whose jobs are allegedly endangered at the moment in north Queensland. The Government, which he so naus- eatingly endorsed at that time, clearly sought to reimpose conditions on those persons if they were seeking re-employment, which would have involved absolutely no superannuation entitlements.

Senator Boswell then went on to criticise the Australian Workers Union and its coverage of those members and employees. He went on to claim that between 2,000 and 3,000 jobs would be lost and that most of these persons were AWU members. I would just like to say that as a result of modernisation of the Australian Workers Union records in Queensland, which I was pleased to be a part of, the union is able to say exactly how many members were affected. Far from being 2,000 or 3,000 the union was able to come up with a figure of 204 members who were affected by the proposed wet tropical rainforest listing. The union sent out a letter, which I would like to read, to those 204 members. I will quote from that letter from the Secretary of the union, Mr Errol Hodder:

Employers engaged in the timber industry have already lodged claims with the Federal Government for compensation. I understand that at the same time, some employers have suggested to their employees that it is not appropriate for employees to commence similar claims.

In other words, the bosses were lining up for the handouts and telling their employees not to talk to the nasty Federal Government. It is a common enough story. They wanted to get their slice of the action first. I will go on with the letter:

The Federal Government has announced that funds will be available for compensation. The Union is committed to ensuring that its members and their families benefit to the maximum extent possible from the expenditure of these funds.

Following representations from the Union at the time of the first announcement of the Government's intention, the Government has agreed to establish a register of workers dependent on the logging industry. This register will form the basis of future planning compensation.

It is vital that all Union members notify the Union if they consider that they are entitled to participate in the compensation package. The attached questionnaire should be completed and returned as soon as possible.
The Union has already begun negotiations with the Government and the Minister and the Minister has assured the Union that its representations will receive the Government's most serious consideration.
The Union will collect this information and prepare submissions to the Federal Government on behalf of its members.

Despite those urgings, only 108 members replied. I note with interest information supplied to me from Senator Richardson's office to the effect that 106 people have received compensation packages already from the Federal Government. So as far as the projections about the 2,000 or 3,000 jobs are concerned and the argument that a majority of these people are AWU members, I simply point out again for the record that 204 members were found. They were all written to and, despite the urgings of their employers, or the instructions of their employers in some cases, they were all urged to claim compensation. Despite that, only 108 have done so, and 106 have received benefits and compensation from the Federal Government.

The timber industry has been in decline in north Queensland for the last decade. Progressively, as the mills became more uneconomic and as the operations wound down, they were sold out to what were described to me by Mr Hodder as accountants and asset strippers who basically oversaw the almost complete dismantling of the timber industry in north Queensland. Up to 40 per cent of the jobs were lost over that decade. There was no doubt in the minds of union officials in that area and at the State level that the industry was going to be finished; it was just a matter of time. They saw that their job, clearly, was to be responsible to their members to try to arrest the situation where several thousand jobs had already been lost without a murmur from the State Government and where, at that time and until two to three months ago, not one cent of redundancy payments was made available to any of those members who were sacked, often at 24 hours notice.

The position that the union took was that if there was to be money available for redundancy packages and if there were to be long term jobs available for those workers affected, the union had a responsibility to ensure that that offer was taken advantage of. In fact, I have a statement that was made at the time by the union officials concerned. It is pretty important that this be put on the record, because the union has complained to me that because of the disinformation campaign that has been waged by the National Party of Australia and by its various bizarre support groups in north Queensland, a number of workers who will be affected have not made adequate claims for compensation. That is what is hurting those families and that is what is hurting those workers. I read in part from a statement made at the time by the Australian Workers Union Secretary, Errol Hodder, when the World Heritage move was announced. The letter says in part:

The Australian Workers' Union, Queensland Branch, has given its full support to World Heritage listing of the Wet Tropics of North East Queensland conditional upon an adequate adjustment and compensation package for affected workers.

State Secretary of the A.W.U., Errol Hodder, said that the Union's decision had been reached with great difficulty and after a lengthy consideration of all of the issues. He has met with logging members in North Queensland and fully discussed Listing with them.
I read further from that letter:

My Union represents thousands of workers in North Queensland from a wide range of industries. We are conscious that our members in the timber industry would wish us to oppose the listing. However, we have had to consider what long term prospects the industry itself offers to its workers and the options which offer opportunities for other industries such as tourism which also employ our members.

I point out that, in contrast with the 204 persons employed in the timber industry who were affected, the union covers 4,000 workers employed in the tourist industry in north Queensland. You would be interested to know that, Mr Acting Deputy President, because in other States they may be members of the liquor trades union. I continue to read from Mr Hodder's letter:

The timber industry in North Queensland has been in decline in recent years with workers leaving the industry in large numbers with no compensation for redundancies. If the industry continues in its present pattern of decline then the best that the present work force could look forward to is a very limited period of employment and the chance of some redundancy provisions.
The operations of the logging industry leave the rain forests severely damaged, to the extent that it adversely impacts upon North Queensland's vital tourist industry.

It must be understood that North Queensland's accessible rainforests are as much an attraction to the overseas tourist as is the reef. The combination is unbeatable. Members of my Union who work in the tourist industry and all North Queenslanders who readily understand that their future prosperity is closely linked to the development of the tourist industry will appreciate that World Heritage listing is an investment in jobs and opportunities, not just for North Queensland, but for all Australians-
in the longer term-

The A.W.U.'s support for the listing is conditional upon appropriate adjustment programs and funding for that program. I wrote to the Prime Minister immediately after his announcement and asked him to answer a number of questions. In particular, the amount of funds that will be available for adjustment and how these funds are to be used. I asked specifically if funds would be available primarily for the development of alternative industries and whether adequate funding would be available for compensation and income maintenance for the current timber industry work force, and assistance with relocation for those workers who may have to go elsewhere for employment. The Prime Minister has assured me that funds are available for financial assistance from both the National Rainforest Conservation program and the National Afforestation Program.

Errol Hodder said that he has commenced negotiations with Senator Graham Richardson on the compensation package. At the same time, the Union is surveying its membership to establish a profile of the affected workforce . . .

Errol Hodder said that he understood the feelings of workers in the industry who are fearful for the future of themselves and their families and that the Union would be active at all times in their interests.

I note that Senator Boswell has said that he would send a copy of my speech to all of those AWU workers who were losing their jobs. It would be about the only honest thing he has ever circulated to anybody in Queensland and I look forward to his saving me some postage. I point out to Senator Boswell that far from the 2,000 to 3,000 persons that he has mentioned as being affected by this decision from the Federal Government, the union concerned could find only 204. Of those 204, 108 have replied and 106 have already been provided with assistance by the Federal Government. I think the most useful thing that National Party senators and the Queensland Government could do as far as these people are concerned is to start to tell the truth for a change. The truth is that economic adjustment was necessary and it will take place. If people accommodate themselves to those changes, they will not suffer any deprivation of income in the short term or the longer term.

I point out in closing that, in politics, one of the hardest jobs one has is to tell people things that they do not want to hear but which they know to be true. The truth is that that industry was finished. It was going to be finished irrespective of what we would have done. The State Government has sought to mislead workers in that area by giving them the understanding that their jobs could have been protected under State Government control. That was not the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. Of course, this legislation has very little to do with the protection of our unique natural heritage; it has everything to do with increasing the power of the Federal Government. As we have just heard from Senator Black, he has very little concern about any of the workers, particularly in Queensland, or in any other areas that are due to be affected at a later date, but he has every concern for having more control put on this country by this Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government. This Government is using the issue of conservation both to undermine the quite legitimate responsibilities of the States and to sacrifice the common-sense management of our natural resources in a very cynical vote-buying exercise. If any example needs to be given about the cynicism of this Government, we have quite clearly had it in recent times with, on the one hand, the Government pandering to the green conservation vote and, on the other hand, accepting donations from companies associated with woodchipping.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill gives the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories the power-let us not forget that the present Minister, Senator Richardson, is quite obsessed with power-to ban any activity within an area of any size that may be of World Heritage value and is merely subject to a Federal government inquiry that is considering its potential for World Heritage listing. In other words, an area that may not be considered worthy of nomination to a World Heritage Committee in the final analysis can, for months, be subject to a freeze on economic activity through a ministerial declaration. It is also a fact that actual nomination to the World Heritage Committee, resulting in an investigation that will take the best part of a year, may result in its rejection. The Minister, in his second reading speech, admitted that in 1987 only 65 per cent of nominations were accepted.

But the main feature of the Bill is, therefore, an open-ended increase in Federal government power. So, too, are two other major aspects. The exemption of World Heritage areas from the requirements of environmental impact studies for actions approved by the Minister is the prime example of our contention that this Bill involves not conservation but control. In effect this would allow the Minister to enforce the building of a monorail in the Uluru World Heritage area without the safeguard of an environmental impact study. It is hypocritical of any government in effect to prohibit State governments or citizens from activity in an area that may or may not receive World Heritage listing, but then give itself a free hand in the World Heritage areas for which it has responsibility.

Secondly, this Bill provides for a system of inspectors to enter property with a warrant from a federally created court or, if necessary, without a warrant. Any legislation that allows for the creation of an army of people with new official powers in any field must be regarded with suspicion.

TALK.START.PARA: —With ID cards.
—That is exactly right; with ID cards.
—Oh, Tony, don't be stupid.

—This Bill must be regarded with increased suspicion because of the Government's attempt, only a few months ago, to foist an ID card onto Australian citizens. Senator Aulich is bleating away because, of course, he was the instigator of the minority report on the Australia Card, and he was the one who wanted everyone in Australia labelled. If through this legislation he is still to persist and obviously encourage a further extension of his ideology, at some time he must recognise that Australians do not want ID cards.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is that nothing in this Bill will prevent a Minister from enrolling militant extremists from the conservation movement to act as inspectors. Let us face it: that is more than likely to happen. By clause 7 of the Bill, proposed new section 17b provides for a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months if one presumes to obstruct or hinder the inspectors whom this Bill will create. So, thanks to this Government, Australian citizens are likely to cop $1,000 fines or 12 months imprisonment terms. Many Australian citizens simply could not afford to pay a $1,000 fine imposed purely and simply because they cherish their privacy. So, what will the Government do? It will slap those people behind bars for 12 months.

As Senator Puplick clearly stated in his speech on this Bill, these Richardson greenshirts, these inspectors, may enter and search, take photographs, examine, inspect, and measure. They may stop, detain and enter any vehicle. Allegedly they are to do so either with the consent of the person in charge of the property concerned, or on the basis of a warrant. However, in circumstances that are of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry, entry may be gained without the consent of the person in charge, or the authority of a warrant issued under the relevant subsection. That is how far this Government is prepared to go; and that is what it will not explain.

This Bill will allow an invasion of privacy similar to that which we repeatedly debated when the Australia Card legislation was before the Parliament. However, this will be the law. One must either allow inspectors to enter, or cop a fine or a term of imprisonment. I would be very surprised if the Government were proud of that, but of course it will be interesting to hear Senator Aulich's comments when he follows me in this debate, because obviously he will seek to justify how the people of Australia can be fined or imprisoned as a result of his thugs not being allowed to enter a property.

Legislation that increases Federal Government power and seeks to undermine legal action taken by the Queensland Government makes an absolute farce of the commitment given by the Minister last September when he said, `I wish to stress as strongly as I can that the Government is taking the consultation process extremely seriously'. That commitment was reported in the Ecofile newsletter that the Minister's Department publishes, at taxpayers' expense of course. Perhaps it could be said that the Minister does take consultation seriously, inasmuch as he wants an iron club in the form of this Bill to take with him to any of the negotiating tables.

There is no question but that the immediate application of this Bill will be to the north Queensland rainforest. However, we just heard Senator Black say that that is not important. That is even more serious when one considers that he happens to be a senator from Queensland. Without doubt, parts of the 9,000 square kilometres within the boundaries of the area that the Federal Government has nominated for World Heritage listing are indeed of unique value and should never be subject to commercial exploitation. The Opposition does not disagree with that. However, the State governments have agreed to set such areas aside from logging. Further, those areas are already within national parks.

From the Opposition's point of view this debate is not about the need to protect the Daintree. What honourable senators can and should query is the blanket inclusion of areas that may be of far less significance and where a degree of carefully controlled exploitation could occur, at least in order to wind down logging more gradually. Of course, it will be interesting to see whether the Government receives donations from loggers for the next election-particularly after the loggers have been wiped out.

Equally, the Senate should be aware that included in the ambit of the nominated area of this Bill are areas of private land, service areas and essential water catchment areas. Commercial quarries, for example, are scarcely deserving of World Heritage protection beside the Daintree. Local communities have every right to be concerned about a Federal Minister having the power, by virtue of clause 5 of this Bill, to prevent any upgrading of water supply or of existing hydro-electricity schemes.

This Labor Government has not heeded such responsible voices as that of Dr Ross Florence, Reader in Forestry at the Australian National University, who last September warned that the Minister was taking a simplistic approach that failed to realise that wood production could exist alongside conservation. Sadly, since this Minister has assumed this portfolio, we have seen a totally simplistic attitude adopted to so many conservation issues. He has not really bothered to consult; he has only visited north Queensland particularly to ensure that he gets across his point of view that these people will lose their jobs, their livelihoods and their future.

Dr Florence said that the Government was ignoring the possibility of adopting a socially acceptable strategy that would confine rainforest timber to a specialised end use. He pointed out that the situation in north Queensland is different from that in northern New South Wales, in respect of which lengthy debate took place about the prohibition of logging, and where forest diversity provided a buffer to the timber industry.

It is both ironic and sad that a Minister in this Labor Government can dismiss the concerns of timber workers by dangling the prospect of alternative work in forestry tourism and firefighting. If this were not so serious it would be a joke. A moment ago we heard Senator Black say that these people would not lose their jobs, that they would have the options of employment in these other areas. However, Senator Black and the Minister should at least have known that the tourist industry does not create jobs suitable for male blue collar workers and, I suppose one could say, that there is little call for firefighters in an environment in which it rains for nine months of the year. Yet, these are serious jobs offered to those people. Firefighters where rain pours down nine months of the year? Really! If it were not so serious it would be laughable.

The Government has proceeded with a blanket World Heritage listing, not because that is the only way of protecting those areas of undisputed value, but because the numbers men of the Labor Party-of whom Senator Richardson is the prime example, together with the Enmore Branch in New South Wales and so forth-believe that there are more votes in the environmental lobbies of the major cities than there are in rural timber communities. It is also a convenient way of providing a trade-off to the members of the extreme left of the ALP who dominate sections of the conservation movement. This cynical policy is creating not only an increase in the arbitrary power of this Federal Government, made so crystal clear in this Bill, but also frustrates the possibility of a national conservation policy that is based on a true consensus.

It is alarming to see this Labor Government depart from the spirit of the 1983 national conservation strategy that defines conservation as the management of the total environment for the greatest sustainable benefit to present and future generations, thus embracing both preservation and sustainable utilisation of the natural environment. The strategy also recognises that Australia can best contribute to global conservation by maintaining its position as a supplier of food and resources. Therefore, I believe that Australians should be concerned when the Chairman of the Heritage Commission, Mr Pat Galvin, stated at a conference in Colorado last year-presumably with the concurrence of this Government-that conservation and development are antagonistic.

But actions always speak louder than words and the Labor Party has already demonstrated inconsistency born of political cynicism over the Kakadu World Heritage area. Listing has applied to an area of 17,000 square kilometres, even though only 30 per cent of stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu have outstanding ecological significance. Indeed, some 67 per cent of stage 3 of Kakadu consists of bare rock, spinifex and shrubs over sandy soil. Let me remind the Senate that this area was once described by Senator Evans as `clapped out buffalo country', before the ALP started running so hard for the conservation vote. Of course, all of these attitudes change when the ALP tries to pander to certain interest groups to get a vote. This is a classic example of what has happened.

In effect, the Government has sacrificed objectivity in the protection of an undoubtedly magnificent environmental resource to include acreage for the sake of political effect-not reality, but political effect. In so doing in September 1986, this Government broke its previous undertakings to consult with the Northern Territory Government in the listing of stage 2 and arbitrarily revoked earlier guidelines for mineral exploration. Of course, that is not uncommon either. Agreements are easily broken by this Government, not just with the Northern Territory but, of course, with the Tasmanian Government. One does not need to be Einstein to figure out why agreements are broken with governments that are not of the same political colour. Clearly the Labor Party will now play up to ill-informed prejudice to the effect that mining exploration is sinister and destructive. Future generations will not even know the mineral potential of areas of less than unique environmental importance that have been arbitrarily listed by the Federal Government.

Similarly, this Government does not care that 20 per cent of the area covered in the north Queensland World Heritage listing is covered by mineral exploration titles. New technology allows for exploration techniques that do not damage the environment but, of course, that is not a consideration by this Government. It does not want to know about new technologies. All it wants to know is where it can grab an extra vote. It is not a matter of permitting mining in what may well be areas of greater environmental importance. We can now expect that no mineral exploration will proceed over this entire area. The 20 per cent of Australia's land surface already sealed away from exploration and rational assessment of its total land use potential can be expected to grow under this Hawke Government.

The Opposition firmly believes that some areas must be conserved in their natural state for the benefit of present and, of course, future generations. We support the World Heritage listing of such areas where objective fact and broad agreement testify to their unique environmental significance. Accordingly, there has been no controversy over the nomination of such environmental treasures as Uluru or Lord Howe Island. World Heritage listing in itself involves no surrender of sovereignty, as the actions of the current United States and United Kingdom governments in listing unique buildings show us. What does concern the Opposition is when World Heritage nomination becomes the vehicle for a massive land grab by a Federal government that is both buying votes and is determined to increase the authority of central government. Such cynicism and insensitivity to both State governments and affected industries and their workers can only bring World Heritage listings-listings that are, in fact, an Opposition initiative-into disrepute.

The people of Australia want their State and Federal governments to ensure the protection of those aspects of their environment that are unique and irreplaceable. Of course, there are thugs in this Federal Government who will override the State governments. They have little or no consideration for the State governments unless they are of their own colour.
