Of course, we have a situation currently in Western Australia where an area of Shark Bay on the coast north of Perth has now been put up for listing by the Western Australian Government. I do not believe that the Federal Government should intervene in respect of what the State governments want to do. Are the views of the local people in those areas ever taken into account? No, they are not, because the future of these people means absolutely nothing to Labor governments.

But, at the same time, most Australians who live in cities appreciate the importance of those industries that must, to some degree, exploit the environment to survive and to create the jobs and wealth that Australia needs. But, once again, that is not a consideration because the green vote is yet again more important. The Opposition believes that the right balance can be achieved while the Labor Government panders purely and simply to one viewpoint and one viewpoint alone. In so doing, it overlooks the fact that some extreme conservationists have an irrational and sweeping dislike of the Australian timber industry.

On 12 November 1984 Philip Toyne of the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) reportedly called for an inquiry into all logging in Australia, pending which it must stop. Certainly, ACF policy aims for the elimination of all forestry in native forests, with 50 per cent of them immediately reserved in national parks and severe interim restrictions on the remainder. This ACF policy would result in the loss of 5,000 direct jobs and of 18,000 to 37,000 indirect jobs in the short term, rising to 9,000 to 12,000 direct and 46,000 to 74,000 indirect jobs if all harvesting of native forests were to cease. Yet, this Government believes that the employment side of this Bill does not matter. We are talking about thousands of people who are going to be affected by this legislation. Yet, this Government says that it does not matter.

Current turnover of $640m in forestry would fall to $460m in the short term and to $215m over the long term. This is a disgrace. Total turnover in the forest products industry that now stands at $8.1 billion would be cut by as much as $3.4 billion in the short term and by $6 billion over the long term when all logging ceased in native forests. We are talking about an industry that overall employs 92,000 Australians, the same number as the car industry, with exports of $340m offsetting a national timber import bill of $1 billion. It is ironic that a government that wants our industries to make use of the export opportunities caused by a depreciated dollar, and that wants heavy investment in industries where tariff protection is properly being cut, should be jeopardising the forest products industry that is investing heavily in pulp and paper production.

As a senator from Western Australia, the State which, along with Tasmania, would be worst hit by a shut-down of the timber harvesting of native forests, I sound this warning about the trend of conservation policy under this Labor Government. This legislation would enable the Government-and particularly this Hawke Labor Government-at some future time when it felt a need to pursue the extreme conservation vote, to list the jarrah and karri forests of the south-west of Western Australia for blanket inclusion as World Heritage. I have grave concern about that because it is crystal clear that this is the objective of this Government. Never mind that these forests are carefully supervised by an expert and dedicated State Department of Conservation and Land Management. Never mind that some beautiful stands of karri are in fact regrown after earlier harvesting and that one major timber producer, Bunnings, employs almost 3,000 Australians. Never mind the fact that in 1986-87 this company was one of Australia's top 100 exporters, achieved sales worth $263m and returned $14m to the Government in taxation revenue. This Government does not worry about those things. It believes they are all expendable.

The Government may say that it has no plans for the south-west of Western Australia but the fact remains that, through this Bill and its mechanism of inspectors, any Federal government has the means to shut down an essential industry in my State and override the professionals who are successfully conserving the forests, if sometimes in a manner not approved by the extreme conservationists. Then again it is unlikely that any work in the forests will ever be approved by those extremists. It is now nearly 10 years since the much criticised practice of controlled burn-offs saved the Manjimup forests from an Ash Wednesday-style conflagration in the wake of Cyclone Alby.

Last year the Liberal Party criticised the actions of this Government and its Democrat allies in regard to the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests in Tasmania as an example of the blanket and unscientific listing of areas as part of the National Estate. But of course we see the Democrats once again hand in hand with this Government trying to override the States. They do not care; it does not matter to them; they can promise anything. Fortunately, they will never have to deliver anything because they will never be in government. They just pander to the green vote as well and pander to this Government, voting consistently with it without regard to the States. Once listed, all land, such as the Lemonthyme Forest, becomes deliberately confused with national parks with the dangerous assumption that land on the National Estate Register becomes, in effect, land under the control of the Federal Government. The principle behind this legislation is equally dangerous and should not be overlooked. The Federal Government is stepping outside its proper constitutional role, not to save unique areas that are in no practical danger, but to place yet larger areas of Australia under its direct supervision.

In opposing this Bill-and opposing it very firmly-the Opposition is not trying to allow the logging of the Daintree Forest or denying the proper role of the Federal Government in working with the States in consultation to preserve the environment and to nominate truly magnificent areas to World Heritage listing. But this Government is simply going overboard. It has completely lost its marbles on this subject and it continues to pander to a particular group for votes. We seek to oppose the blatant centralism of a Labor government extending its control over land use, in subverting civil liberty through the employment of inspectors with ID cards who, I remind the Senate, can come onto a person's property at any time. If one does not allow them to come onto one's property, one can be fined or imprisoned. We also seek to oppose the Government's demanding carte blanche over the management of existing World Heritage areas. We also register our opposition to the practice of this Government of playing politics with the environment to the detriment of the mining and timber industries and their employees and to the ultimate detriment of responsible environment management. The Opposition and I, as a Western Australian senator, are committed to opposing this type of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating how to protect effectively the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia, nominated by Australia in 1987 for inclusion on the World Heritage List. I am proud to be involved in that process, just as I was proud to be involved in the protection and listing of the West Tasmania Wilderness Park in the early 1980s. I do not feel any of the self-consciousness that Senator Knowles somehow or other seems to indicate we should feel about our part in this process. We are talking about not only our heritage but also the heritage of our children. After all, we are caretakers-just caretakers-of this environment and our role is to ensure that we hand on that environment in as pristine condition as possible to future generations. That will always be done despite the objections of vested interest groups, developers and those who support them politically. Because of the protection of some jobs, but more particularly the gaining of money with the least possible effort, that process of objection will continue in this Parliament and in the community as long as this Government moves to protect the environment in an effective manner. That is the difference between our legislation-the way in which we approach the protection of the environment-and the approach that was taken by the Fraser Government, which moved only when it was forced to step in. I will mention that later when I get to the question of the Franklin River and its relationship with this Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is basically a tightening of the current Act to ensure that areas of World Heritage value are protected immediately and effectively. As I indicated before, that is the basis on which we are operating. We want to be effective. We are not doing this for political purposes or for show; we are doing this because we want to make sure that we effectively protect those areas that are nominated for World Heritage listing. If one looks at the 288 sites in the world that have been protected by World Heritage listing one sees some of the great birthrights of mankind-that is, such things as the pyramids of Egypt, the Grand Canyon of the United States of America, the Taj Mahal, Chartres Cathedral in France and many others. In Australia we have about seven World Heritage sites: the Great Barrier Reef, stages of Kakadu National Park, Lord Howe Island and groups around it, West Tasmania Wilderness Park, Uluru National Park, Willandra Lakes region of western New South Wales and the subtropical rainforest park of New South Wales. Surely when we look at those 288 sites and areas on the World Heritage List, and we understand that in Australia we are able to provide at least seven significant parts of that list, then as Australians we ought to be proud that we are doing something about ensuring that future generations have access to those pieces of World Heritage. I make no apology for making legislation to protect those pieces of World Heritage as effective as possible.

Let us have a look at the opposition to the Bill. It is interesting that, once again, as with the Bill of Rights and a number of other policies that were introduced in this chamber, the Opposition-and in particular the Queensland Government and to some extent the Tasmanian Government-has attempted to build a coalition of interest groups against the Bill, creating a bogyman amongst groups such as canefarmers, graziers, miners and timber companies, none of whom will ever be directly affected by this legislation. But of course the aim is not to debate the issue; not to work out how to ensure that our heritage is passed on to our children and that we play our part as a nation in this world to ensure that there is some future for the significant features that are beautiful, unique and important to the ecosystem. No, it is not that. The aim of the Opposition is to ensure that it builds up a coalition of fear, just as it did about the Australia Card and just as it did about the Bill of Rights. That is what it is doing with this piece of legislation.

Let us look at some of the issues that Opposition senators raised and some of the deliberate misinterpretations they have made in their minds and forced onto the minds of others about what this Bill does. The first Opposition criticism is that large areas of Australia, especially in Queensland and Tasmania, will be locked up against mining and other developments. The truth is that mining companies have access to all land except national parks. That means effectively that they are locked out to some extent of about 13.4 per cent of Tasmania's land area and about 2 per cent of Queensland's land area. That is all the area that is locked up against mining by virtue of its being protected by its national park status. Further, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has also said that mining in the area under consideration, that is, the Queensland rainforest, is not banned per se. Decisions on mining will be made on a case by case basis provided-there are two provisos-that there is not wholesale clearing of rainforest and that the World Heritage values of the area are not compromised.

The second criticism that has been thrown around with varying degrees of stupidity and cynicism amongst groups outside by the Opposition is that there will be a massive and new invasion of privacy and civil liberties as a result of this legislation. The truth is that under this legislation no inspector can enter private homes, with or without a warrant, under any circumstances whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about private property?

—The truth is also that, under State powers given to inspectors under existing State legislation of various kinds-noxious weed Acts and so on, particularly in the primary industry area-State inspectors are currently allowed in many cases the right of entry, despite the opposition of the land owner, and the right to prosecute, to destroy property and to confiscate property and stock. Senator Parer does not disagree with those powers in primary industry areas. For example, he believes that, if there is an outbreak of foot and mouth disease, the appropriate authorities should not be able to move in there overnight, destroy the stock and burn the buildings.
—That is a totally different issue and you know it.

—Every Minister in this country who has a responsibility in the primary industry area accepts that the powers of inspectors and the various authorities to beat cattle disease and so on must be paramount for the protection of the community as a whole. Senator Messner says that that is a different story. But is it? The rights to entry, confiscation and destruction are already in the hands of State authorities. I say to those people who are fearful about this Bill that, if they are concerned about Big Brother invading their privacy, and if they are farmers, they should go into their back paddocks because Big Brother is already there; he probably is the inspector from the primary industry department in that area because those inspectors have more powers than will any inspector appointed under this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have been in this forum, in the Senate, and in the six years that I was in the State Parliament, I have not heard one objection to the powers that primary industry inspectors have in various areas under State legislation. Yet Opposition members quibble about having inspectors under this legislation who, for example, will not be able to enter private homes, with or without a warrant. Of course, Opposition members are not interested in the truth of this matter. They are interested only in stirring up a coalition of fear amongst groups that will not be affected. They are doing it for political purposes.

The next point-it is an interesting one-that mining companies have made is that they object to the legislation because of the powers to enter properties. The mining companies should talk! They know very well indeed that under relevant State legislation-by giving the land owner two days notice in Queensland and three days notice in Tasmania, for example-they can enter property and explore without the permission of the land owner, provided that they have a permit to do so from the mining department with the relevant powers in that State. The land owner can object as much as he likes, but the mining companies can enter that property and begin drilling. In Tasmania, with the exception of about 2 per cent of land in certain parts that was handed out in grants in the early 1820s or so, land owners do not have the mining rights to their land. In terms of mineral rights, 98 per cent of all land in Tasmania is owned by the Crown. For example, if the Crown decides to allow, say, an oil exploration company to enter a property, provided that company gives the owner three days notice it can enter the property and begin drilling and exploration despite the objections of the land owner. Yet the mining companies have the hide-and I must say the hypocrisy-to go out in the general community and say that this legislation takes away people's rights to private property and to prevent people from entering their land. I cannot believe that they are being anything less than cynical in that.

The next point is that Opposition members have been indicating quite clearly around the traps, wherever they can get away with it-for example, wherever one of us is not there to correct the misinterpretations that they push around-that this legislation takes away the rights of States and individuals to have access to the courts, particularly the High Court of Australia. The Tasmanian mining industry, through its executive body, has indicated just that. It has said that this legislation prevents access by States or individuals to the High Court. This is such arrant nonsense that there should be no need even here today to point out that under our Constitution all legislation passed by this chamber, by the Parliament, is subject to the right of States and of individuals to challenge its validity in the High Court. There has never been any doubt in the minds of Opposition senators about the right of States and individuals to do such a thing. There has never been any doubt that they have access to the High Court; yet the Opposition continues to push this lie out in the community, for various reasons best known to them, primarily political.

Why does Australia need this Bill? Quite simply, we need the Bill because history has shown, and current political experience tells us, that State governments alone cannot be trusted to protect the environment; that some State governments are much more subject to pressure from short term development groups; that some are more corrupt than others; and that, in the end, they cannot be trusted as caretakers of this environment, of World Heritage listed sites and places.

Let us look at some of the examples that prove conclusively that State governments in many areas cannot be trusted to protect the environment. I do not want to dredge up old scandals, but we need to look at the track record because people who do not learn from history will be condemned to repeat it over and over again.

Let us look at Queensland, for example, and the Great Barrier Reef, one of the unique assets not only of Australia but of the world. That is why it is one of the 288 great places of the world listed for World Heritage listing. Everybody in this chamber and 99 per cent of Australians have no doubt that the Great Barrier Reef has to be protected. Yet that was not always so. If we look at the record of the Queensland Government in 1969, we see that there were numerous attempts by private enterprise to suborn that Government through various mechanisms. The first, for example, was the Comalco company which gave preferential shares to members of the Queensland Cabinet; they admitted that.

The Premier at the time, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, admitted that his Cabinet had accepted shares from Comalco at a discounted price. It got preference shares-that is, shares that were sold at a cheaper price than those on the market. Those people in that Cabinet had the hide to come out, through Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and defend their right, as Ministers, to sit in the Queensland Cabinet and make decisions about the environment. Comalco was one of those interested in touching up the Barrier Reef.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Absolute rubbish! Comalco was not involved in the Barrier Reef.

—I invite Senator Parer to have a look at all the share listings and the ownerships of companies. They believed that they had the right, as Cabinet Ministers, to accept shares from a private company at a preferential rate. That is something that none of us in this chamber would accept, but it was accepted then.
—Comalco had nothing to do with the Barrier Reef.

—Senator Parer has provoked me, so I will get down to details. Let us talk about the Premier of Queensland who made decisions about the Great Barrier Reef. We will get closer to home. In January 1969 some 40 groups of oil search companies applied for exploration permits on the Great Barrier Reef. The then Premier, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, held 49 per cent of shares in Artesian Basin Oil Co. Pty Ltd, which, in turn, held one million shares in Exoil NL, which was an applicant for a lease on the reef. So the Premier, through Artesian Basin Oil Co. Pty Ltd, held shares in Exoil which was an applicant to examine and explore the reef for oil. Senator Parer provoked me to illustrate that clear example of what can happen in State governments that can be bought by development interests. A Premier and a Cabinet can be bought. How can we hand total control of the environment to such a government? If Senator Parer believes that such governments will not exist in future, obviously he is pretty naive.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the other activities of the Queensland Government. There was the Lindeman Island affair. In a semi-secret deal which leaked out, the Queensland Government tried to sell off Lindeman Island to a consortium connected with the then Premier's friend, or the Premier's then friend-I am not sure which phrase I should use-Sir Edward Lyons, known colloquially as Top Level Ted. At that time, in order to dampen down the understandable anger of most Queensland citizens and the disgust of other Australians, the Queensland Government promised that a further 23 islands would be gazetted as national parks. That is what it promised a couple of years ago. Nothing has been done about that promise. Not one of those 23 islands has been gazetted. That is a shameful breach of the Queensland Government's responsibilities under its respective environmental Acts. It told a shameful lie at the time to dampen down enthusiasm. That shows how much the Queensland Government can be trusted.

Honourable senators will remember the Bellevue Hotel affair in 1979. Let us go over that again. It was in one of the most beautiful parts of Brisbane, which could have become a beautiful city. Because there were public protests about the loss of a State monument-it was a State monument; it was a very beautiful section comprising the Parliament, the Queensland Club and the Bellevue Hotel-and to get around universal support for the retention of the Bellevue Hotel, the Premier had the bulldozers move in on a Saturday, at about midnight, with police protection, to demolish it. One of Queensland's most beautiful buildings went to the ground. When people woke up the following morning the building had gone. When the Premier was queried about that he said, `I congratulate the demolishers on a job well done'. Do honourable senators believe that that Government should be given control over the environment? Do they believe that the Federal government, of whatever political persuasion, ought not to have the right to protect our unique historical and environmental assets? Not one person in this House really believes that in his own heart of hearts.

Let us look at another matter, with which I was associated as a Tasmanian Cabinet Minister-the Franklin River issue. In the early 1980s the then Tasmanian Labor Government made a decision, which cost it office-we knew pretty well that it might cost us office; we were not naive about it-to save the Franklin River and to declare that area a national park. We rejected, for the first time in the history of a Tasmanian government, the recommendations of the Hydro Electric Commission to dam the Franklin River. We said that we would put a dam elsewhere. The Hydro Electric Commission went out and effectively knocked off that Government. The Gray Government succeeded the Labor Government. It began work as quickly as possible on the Franklin River to put a dam there. It told people that if a dam was not built, industry would dry up. It said that Tasmania desperately needed the 130 or so megawatts of electricity that would come out of that dam. The Government and the Hydro Electric Commission lied at the time-because now that the dam has not been built the new Hydro Electric Commissioner has stated publicly that not one megawatt of the electricity that supposedly would have come from that scheme has been taken up by Tasmanian industry. So at a cost of $1,000m, 130 megawatts of power would have been produced and Tasmania would have been in enormous debt for absolutely nothing. The Gray Government intended to dam one of the most exciting and beautiful rivers not only in Australia but in the world. It is the last wild river in Australia. If honourable senators doubt that, I invite them to go up it some time. Premier Gray described the river as a leech-ridden brown ditch. That boy is a man of soul!

The Hawke Federal Labor Government moved in and saved the river. We won an appeal by the Tasmanian Government in the High Court of Australia. We beat the Tasmanian Government on that and saved the river. Now we see that the Tasmanian Government, in its official brochures, promotes the Franklin River; it promotes the national park that the Labor Government brought in at its own cost. The Liberal Government now says, `Come to Tasmania because we have beautiful national parks; we have the Franklin River'. It does not include, in brackets, the words `which the Hawke Government saved and about which the Tasmanian Labor Government of the day made the right decision'. Also, the Tasmanian Government does not say that about a year or so ago 300,000 people visited national parks in Tasmania. It does not tell us about the economic value of national parks, let alone the value to people's peace of mind of knowing that there is a pristine wilderness which they can pass on to their children. I was proud to be involved in that decision, just as today I am proud to be able to make sure that we have legislation which effectively protects the environment and assets that are of World Heritage value.

The Bill is not about giving police powers. It is about making sure that we are effective. It means, for example, that if a State government, in its stupidity, short-sightedness or greed, decides to circumvent what we are doing in terms of listing something on the World Heritage List, we will be able, as a government, to stop that without having to have spy flights over a State and without having to send in people with secret cameras. We are giving inspectors their just and appropriate powers to ensure that the vandals do not get in and ruin that asset before it is officially listed by the World Heritage Committee. We recognise that a long and complex stage of discussion is involved when something is put on the World Heritage List. We know that in that time that particular area or site is vulnerable to attack by the vandals. I have already indicated that those vandals can take the form of private developers in there for a quick dollar or the form of a State government which is determined, for political reasons, to ensure that those developers can get in there. The Franklin River for example still bears scars because Robin Gray and the Liberal Government of the day, knowing that there was a High Court of Australia challenge coming which they might lose, moved in with the bulldozers. Those scars are there now as a testimony to the need for interim protection and that we need effective protection by the Federal Government to ensure that those vandals do not destroy the asset before it can be listed. If the World Heritage Committee decides in its wisdom that it does not wish to list a particular site or asset, what has been lost? Only a year or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —A stack of jobs.

—Senator Parer has said, `A stack of jobs'. I ask Senator Parer why something like 6,000 jobs in the Tasmanian timber industry have gone down the chute in the last 20 years. They have been lost not because land has been locked up by the greenies, a green Federal Government or green State Labor governments. The jobs have gone because of technology. They have gone because we sold our assets in the timber industry short. That is why, for example, the Tasmanian Government had to reduce the allocation to the timber companies by 20 per cent about six years ago. A Labor government backed up by a Liberal government, went out and sold, to the Japanese in particular, contracts for volumes of timber which it could not fulfil. Why did this happen? It happened because we never bothered to find out what the volume asset was in Tasmania. We sold our birthright in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I sat in the offices of some of those Japanese companies in January this year. I listened to those companies say what they think of us. I know that we were very foolish indeed. Just as I was proud to be involved in saving the Franklin River, I feel ashamed to have been involved in the selling off of Tasmania's forests at the cheapest possible price-a price which I believe makes us a laughing stock of Japanese companies. I asked one particular company two questions: `What are you going to do if, politically, it is not possible to get woodchips out of Tasmania? What will happen if Tasmanians say, ``We do not want to sell at rock bottom prices. We don't want to rip off our forests; we don't have the volume to supply you''?'. The Japanese said, `It is simple. We go to Chile because we do not have trade union problems there'. I thought that they were joking, but they were not. They said, `We go to China where they are doing very well with their new plantings of exotics because they are getting rid of their beech trees'. I thought, `Yep, that is the way exploitive companies view the world'. If we are foolish enough to put our heads on the block to cut out the environments that are important to us and our children, we ought to be ashamed of ourselves.

This Bill is about making sure that our own short-sightedness does not dominate the economic and environmental agenda in this country. I am proud to be here today to say that we are going to be effective about protecting World Heritage listing. I make no apologies about that. I deride the sorts of viewpoints pushed around the community by people such as Senator Boswell and Senator Knowles. I think that there is a point at which ideology has to end and a point at which we have to look at what we are giving to our children and to the future. The environment is a once-off thing. Once it is gone, it is gone. To let the Queensland rainforests be cut down, ruined and given away is the equivalent of putting dynamite in the pyramids of Egypt. If that is what honourable senators opposite want to do, if that is the way they think, let them say so now. If they do not think that way but think about the future and our children's future, I ask them to vote with the Bill because there is no other option but to ensure that we protect World Heritage listings not only in the long term but also in the interim to ensure that the asset is still there when the Committee says, `Yes, we want to list it because Australia has an eighth wonder of the world that we think is worth protecting'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. I think that I should say from the outset, because Senator Aulich has said that in his opinion we on this side of the chamber are not interested in conservation, that we are very interested in conservation. However, we are not interested in preservation. That is the antithesis of conservation. We are interested in preserving areas that need to be preserved. But what we are objecting to in regard to most areas is the way in which the conservation has been done, the way in which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has ridden roughshod not only over the Queensland Government but also over people who live in the areas concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most intrigued to find that honourable senators opposite, who are supposed to represent workers, their way of life and their living standards, have barely mentioned those workers in the debate. Their attitude is, `Who cares about the people who have been there for two or three generations; who cares that they cannot sell their homes; who cares that people with families are pulling their kids out of schools because they cannot afford the school fees?'. Even if they were able to move to other areas, they are unable to do so. I think that we have to balance the rights of individuals. It is wrong to go back and say to such people after all these years that they have been vandals. However, the areas these people are supposed to have vandalised are now being nominated for World Heritage listing.

I refer honourable senators opposite to the remarks of Professor Percy Harris from James Cook University in this regard. The Federal Government's environmental policy is in a shambles. It is in a shambles because it has been politicised by the Minister. The Minister in a knee-jerk reaction, supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), decided before the last election that come hell or high water there were some political brownie points to be gained by riding roughshod over people in north and far north Queensland, hoping like hell thereby that as a result, although they might almost certainly lose the seat of Leichhardt, they might retain some marginal seats in Sydney and Melbourne. That is a disgrace. I think that the old-time Labor people would be rolling in their graves at that treatment of individuals in north and far north Queensland-individuals who only want to have an honest and decent living.

In summary, the effect of the amendments will be as follows: they will declare retrospectively that World Heritage legislation is not subject to any provisions of the Environment Protection Act. Any High Court of Australia challenge by the Queensland Government on current grounds would therefore not be possible. Incidentally, the aim of the Queensland Government challenge was to question the scientific evidence. We have heard a lot from honourable senators opposite about how good the scientific evidence is. They have cited scientific authorities here and scientific authorities there. However I ask: if the scientific evidence is really so good, why prevent by legislation a High Court appeal on the basis of scientific evidence?

The amendments propose also to establish that the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) so-called World Heritage Commission has total responsibility for the determination of World Heritage nominations. As a result of the amendments no appeal to any nomination by the Federal Government would be possible in an Australian court. The amendments propose to establish a new definition of `identified property'. For example, it would be any property subject to inquiry by the Commonwealth about its cultural heritage or natural heritage. I say also that the Bill does not set out any procedures for an inquiry. They are not detailed. The definition would also include any property included in the World Heritage List or property declared by Commonwealth regulation to form part of Australia's cultural or natural heritage. The amendments set out to establish that identified property may be protected by Commonwealth proclamation which may restrict activity on that property. The Commonwealth can define the restricted activity. The amendments propose to establish inspectors with power to enter and search private property, including vehicles but excluding private dwellings on an identified property. The penalty for obstruction or hindrance of an inspector is a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months.

The Queensland Government has challenged the World Heritage listing of the north Queensland rainforests in the High Court of Australia on the basis that the Hawke Government does not have scientific or technical evidence to support its case. I think it is worth quoting Dr Joe Baker, a retired chairman of the Australian Heritage Commission. At a meeting held in Cairns on 19 February 1988 he slammed the Federal Government nomination of the wet tropics on the basis that the case was badly prepared, that the boundaries could not be justified, and that current scientific studies were not complete. At an earlier time the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies at the Australian National University took a similar view. It saw little science in the nomination process and questioned the wisdom of extensive reservation of areas of forest types already well reserved and the exclusion of other forest types inadequately reserved and already at risk.

So the major purpose of this Bill is to prevent the court challenge and to do so retrospectively. Individuals and State governments will have no legal avenue to challenge the nomination of their property within Australia. The Bill is an absolute attack on natural justice and a gross infringement of the civil rights of every Australian. To make the legislation retrospective is intolerable. It is quite apparent that the Government is not confident of winning in the High Court, and the amendments proposed in this Bill effectively castrate those Acts which could be used in a legal challenge to the Government's action. While I am aware of the view of the Australian Democrats on World Heritage listing, the issues we are considering today are far wider than those involving the environment. There is no way in the world that the founder of the Australian Democrats, Don Chipp, would have had a bar of this legislation.

There are many other offensive aspects of the Bill. One of the most objectionable amendments is that which seeks to remove the precondition that an area nominated for World Heritage listing must form part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage of Australia. Under this Bill such matters will be determined by the World Heritage Committee, which Senator Richardson tells us is the appropriate and proper authority to do so. What this will mean, of course, is that Australians will not be able to decide for themselves whether an area is worthy of World Heritage listing. Instead, those decisions will be made by foreign bureaucrats in Paris who will dictate what we can and cannot do with our country on the instruction of their own national governments. I ask: Will the Government go further and let the International Labour Organisation set wage rates for Australian labour or let the Security Council determine how Australian troops should be deployed? This amendment will also prevent the Government's nomination of the north Queensland rainforests being tested in the courts on its scientific and technical merits.

If the Government truly believed that the entire nominated area was worthy of World Heritage listing, it would not be worried about the validity of that listing being challenged in the courts. Yet, the major purpose of this Bill is to prevent such a challenge. Surely even the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, can see that for the sake of fair play he owes the Queensland Government and the countless hundreds of local people who will be affected by this policy a day in court to test the validity of the decision. So much for the Government's much vaunted policy of consensus. I wish to refer to a booklet put out by Senator Richardson's own Department wherein he talks about the process for nominating Australian properties for inclusion on the World Heritage List. The booklet reads:

During the July 1984 meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM), some guidelines were agreed to apply to new nominations of Australian sites to the World Heritage List, which involved full consultation with the State and Territory Governments.

We know that this Government has a habit of breaking its promises and changing tack. However, these guidelines were reaffirmed at the November 1987 meeting of CONCOM. They were reaffirmed at the same time as the Minister was riding roughshod over the Queensland Government and not consulting with it. Those guidelines have been reaffirmed as recently as 1987. The 1984 guidelines also included inviting the State and Territory governments to submit suggestions of places to be examined with a view to possible nomination to the World Heritage List. That is fine. No-one disagrees with that. The aim is that the State governments nominate areas for listing, the Federal Government looks at the nominations and determines whether they are worthy of listing and, if so, nominates them for inclusion on the World Heritage List. The booklet produced by Senator Richardson's Department goes further. I think Senator Richardson should read his own publications, for it reads:

Once a State or Territory Government has endorsed a potential World Heritage nomination, of course, the Federal Government needs to assess the proposal to ensure that the strict criteria set down by the World Heritage Committee are met as the World Heritage List must remain an exclusive list of the world's natural and cultural treasures.

What we are saying is that Senator Richardson should read his own guidelines. The Government is not confident about the validity of its nomination, so it has chosen the coward's way out of vandalising legislation to prevent the possiblity of its decision being tested. Maybe its decision will be overturned; I do not know. What is the Government worried about? What Senator Richardson is saying is that if he and his Department say that white is black and a committee of foreign diplomats agrees with that proposition, then not even the High Court of Australia can intervene to set the matter right. The total hypocrisy of this amendment is demonstrated by the fact that, although Senator Richardson stated in his second reading speech that it was his view that the ultimate World Heritage test should be left to the World Heritage Committee, the Government has retained the right for itself in proposed new section 3a (1) (iv) to declare property as part of the cultural or natural heritage. The Government wants to have its cake and eat it too.

Another amendment in this Bill which seeks to ride roughshod over the rights of the States and the people is that which broadens the definition of identified property. This provision will give the Government power to prohibit activity in areas that it is merely thinking about having declared at some later time as part of the World Heritage. Part III of the Bill seeks to insert in the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 a provision which will exclude World Heritage areas from the Government's own environment impact assessment legislation, in the past, the present or the future. It is clear that the Government has moved retrospectively to cure any breach which may have occurred when its nomination of the north Queensland rainforest was lodged with the World Heritage Committee in December last year. Such is the arrogance of this Minister and of the Government that they believe that they are not obliged to undergo the same process of social environmental assessment which they demand of others.

The Bill provides also for the establishment of the Richardson police, so ably referred to by my colleague Senator Puplick. The Minister will appoint his own army of inspectors who will be able to enter and search people's private property and vehicles, and those inspectors will be able to do that with or without a warrant. There has been a cover-up in that regard. Senator Richardson indicated in his second reading speech that all sorts of safeguards would be put in place. If anyone hinders or obstructs Senator Richardson's Rambos they will be subject to a fine of $1,000 or 12 months imprisonment, or both. I think it is worth referring to a Press release put out yesterday, I believe, by the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties. It is very much a Labor organisation, the President being Mr Stephen Keim. Stephen Keim is very heavily associated with the Australian Labor Party in the Hendra area of Brisbane. His Press release reads in part:
The Council is concerned at any extension of powers for the State to interfere in the lives of its citizens.
He was referring, in fact, to the proposed penalties. The Press release continues.
Any such extension of these powers, even if justified in the individual case, needs to be accompanied by the strictest of safeguards. The Council-
that is, the Council for Civil Liberties in Queensland-
calls upon the Minister to ensure that relevant changes are made to the legislation to provide the safeguards called for.

Is it any wonder that people are saying that the Labor Party has lost its touch? This is a Labor Party organisation and these are its views on this sort of draconian legislation. The question must be asked: Why is the Minister making provision in this Bill for the Government to set up its own police force with quite unprecedented powers? This is East European stuff, totalitarian government stuff. I will be interested to see how Labor senators on the other side of the chamber, who often claim to uphold human rights, will vote on this quite unacceptable invasion of individual privacy.

There are two major criteria for World Heritage listing. Firstly, the area must be worthy of being listed. Everyone agrees with and understands that. Secondly, and equally importantly, the Government must be able to show that the area can be properly managed. It is no good having an area which is worthy of being listed if it cannot be properly managed. To do this, the Government needs the support of the State in which the nominated area lies-in this case Queensland. The Government and the Minister clearly do not have that support.

I have a copy of the nomination of the wet tropical rainforest for inclusion in the World Heritage List, which was signed on 23 December 1987 on behalf of the State Party-and when I say `State' under the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and National Heritage, `State' means the Federal Government of Australia and the people of Australia-by Graham Frederick Richardson, Minister of State for Environment and the Arts. I refer in particular to clause 2 (c) on page 3 of the nomination. The question is asked: Who will be responsible for the administration? The answer is:
The public property is administered by the Government of the State of Queensland . . .
It goes on to outline the Department of Forestry, the Lands Administration Commission and so on. It says:

The Government of Australia has enacted the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 to implement its responsibilities and obligations arising from the World Heritage Conventions. A joint authority of the Australian and Queensland Governments is envisaged to assume responsibility for administration of the property.
I refer again to clause 4 on page 17 of the nomination. When the question is asked about management plans the answer is:
There are Statements of Purpose and Management Guidelines for the National Parks managed by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service.
I go to page 16 which refers to the agent responsible for preservation conservation. The answer is:
Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service
Queensland Department of Forestry
Lands Administration Commission, Queensland-

and, again, the envisaged joint authority. This is very serious stuff because to an international body reading this nomination, it would appear that the area being proposed was proposed with the enthusiastic support of all parties. Yet there has been no consultation or agreement with the Government of Queensland, the people responsible for land administration in that State. The document is a fraud. A Minister of the Crown in this Government, I believe, has set out deliberately to mislead an international organisation-UNESCO. It is a dishonest act by a Minister. He should resign and if he does not he should be sacked by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I draw your attention to the allegation being made of dishonesty. It is unparliamentary language, as the honourable senator would be aware. I ask that he withdraw it.
—Senator Parer, I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw. Perhaps I should rephrase my comment to say it was a deliberately misleading statement.

—With the utmost respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, `deliberately misleading' is utterly synonymous with the expression `dishonest'. Senator Parer ought to be able to appreciate the verbal point involved and not pursue what is an unprofitable attempt to breach Standing Orders. I ask that he withdraw `deliberately misleading'.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: There is a world of difference between the two expressions used. There can be no suggestion that the term `deliberately misleading' is unparliamentary. I ask you to override Senator Evans's point.
—I uphold the point of order.
—I will rephrase that and say that there is a misleading statement in the nomination signed by the Minister for the environment.
—Yes.
—Senator Evans will accept that.

—The Government must withdraw the nomination for World Heritage listing and get into sensible discussions with the Queensland Government, as outlined by Senator Puplick in his speech. It is important to refer to the copy of a telex from the Premier of Queensland to the Prime Minister, which Senator Boswell had incorporated in Hansard during his speech. The Premier said:

SPEECH.PARA: As new Premier of Queensland, I look forward to working constructively with you on matters of mutual interest to our governments.

One matter requiring urgent attention concerns the confrontation situation which has emerged as a result of your Government's action to proceed with World Heritage listing of Queensland's wet tropical rainforests. As indicated in a recent Press release, I believe that this matter has been mishandled by your Government and that if the current situation is not corrected, there will be serious adverse economic and social consequences.

I strongly urge that your Government make no final decisions on this issue until our governments and our officials have had discussions. Once my Ministry is finalised and has met, I will be in a position to suggest arrangements for progressing consideration of the rainforest issue.
M. J. Ahern, Premier of Queensland

Honourable senators opposite have a habit of saying that the Minister has attempted all methods of consultation with the Queensland Government. Clearly that is not true. I made a point earlier that in the nomination for World Heritage listing there were statements which were misleading because the implication to foreign people receiving this document from UNESCO is that everyone is happy with the nomination. That is not the case. I have suggested that the nomination be withdrawn, sensible discussions take place and some balanced view come forward which has that support.

The reason I say that the area cannot be managed-and this is the major second part of any nomination where, first, an area must be worthy of being listed and, secondly, it must be able to be managed-is that the Queensland Government has the responsibility for land management within its boundaries. Without the cooperation of the State, the listing will be an absolute fiasco, as the area cannot be managed. Notwithstanding Senator Richardson's blatant attempt to mislead the World Heritage Committee, it is aware of this fatal flaw in the nomination. I understand that there is every possibility that in November a decision on listing will be postponed until there is cooperation between the Federal and State governments. In other words, the World Heritage Committee clearly is embarrassed about this issue becoming a political football. I would like to quote from a telex sent by the Ambassador to UNESCO, Mr Charles Mott, to the Federal Minister for the environment, Senator Richardson. He complained that members of the World Heritage Committee were resentful about having to resolve what should be domestic issues. He is reported to have said:
We are the only country that sends its internal difficulties to the committee on an annual basis and, to this extent, appear to be earning a bit of a reputation for eccentricity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blame the States and Territories, not the Federal Government.

—Senator Evans knows, as Mr Ahern and I know, that if Senator Richardson were prepared to enter into consultations with the Queensland Government led by Mr Mike Ahern some resolution of this matter could come about. He has decided to ride roughshod over it for cheap political Brownie points. He thinks that by doing that the Government will get a few marginal seats in Sydney and Melbourne even though the seat of Leichhardt is down the gurgler-nothing more, nothing less. To continue with Mr Mott's remarks, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Some members resent being placed in a position of having to react to and resolve matters they think should be resolved in Australia.
He warned that the Queensland rainforests issue was shaping up as a Kakadu rerun and urged Senator Richardson to find a solution.

We are also urging Senator Richardson to find a solution. We have told him how to do it-by withdrawing the nomination and getting into consultation with the Queensland Government. It is not opposed to the preservation of areas that it believes are worthy of listing or worthy of being preserved.

In conclusion, I repeat that it should be an embarrassment not only to this Government but also to every person in this country that a Minister has placed a nomination before the World Heritage Committee of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation which implies that everyone is happy with that nomination when, clearly, that is not a fact. Hence he has been reprehensible to an international organisation. As I said earlier, it is bad enough if a Minister does it within the Parliament, but when a Minister goes overseas to an international organisation he is putting at stake the credibility of not only the Government of this country but also the country itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad of the opportunity to join my colleagues on the Opposition benches in opposing this legislation, which I feel is a very unacceptable continuation of a collection of legislation to do with the environment which this Government has been putting in place over the months that it has been in office. There is no need for the Commonwealth Government to take these heavy-handed actions when there is an effective method of co-operation with the States-the so-called famous consensus for which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) regards himself as such an expert. If he had been such an expert, he would have been able to achieve much more by co-operation instead of trying to use the heavy hand of centralist power. There is considerable concern in the country at this increasing trend of the Federal Government to move into areas which have always traditionally been the responsibility of the States. No State has suffered more in this area than my State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to speak at length on this piece of legislation but, first of all, I want to congratulate Senator Puplick on his excellent speech, which set out the problems which the Opposition sees in this legislation. It is interesting, when considering trends towards centralism and control of these matters being taken more and more by the Federal Government, to look at the proposals that are coming forward from the Constitutional Commission that relate to this area. I was very interested to read that the Constitutional Commission has looked at the question of the use of the foreign treaty power by the Commonwealth Government and has chosen to make no recommendations as to the limitation of its use in so far as it affects intrusion into powers normally exercised by the States. I am sad that the Constitutional Commission, which has seen fit to bring down so many recommendations on changes to the Constitution, has not seen fit to make a recommendation in this area. I think it is curious and significant that it has studied the matter and has chosen not to make a recommendation. It bears out my concerns that the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees have been hand-picked for the job by this Government. All this points to one direct, determined effort by the Commonwealth to become a centralist, powerful government in Canberra, dictating to individuals and to the States as to how these matters can be dealt with.

I have lived in Tasmania for many years now and I feel that we are often given very poor Press coverage on the mainland. On many occasions I have known the full details of something which relates to an environmental matter only to find that it has been portrayed very differently on the mainland. A very clear example of this only recently was the question of pollution in the Macquarie Harbour area of Tasmania which was alleged to be the cause of poisoning of a large number of fish in a fish hatchery. I was intrigued to find that the 7.30 Report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) carried quite a long item on this matter. It gave all the information that was adverse to Tasmania's reputation as an environmentally careful place and failed to carry to the mainland an interview which was carried in Tasmania as part of the story. There was very selective editing by the ABC's 7.30 Report staff. So the answers to the allegations were never carried on the mainland while they went to air in Tasmania.

It has been a feature of the environmental debate over the last few years that explanations of the true situation are often not understood on the mainland. I wonder whether the Federal Government does not get to know the facts in environmental debates that take place a long way from Canberra, or whether it is determined to ignore the facts. Certainly, when it comes to the debates that we have had recently in Tasmania and Queensland, the Federal Government has been prepared to blunder on regardless of the realities of the situation.

But matters come to a head when we see the powers that the Government is prepared to give to people it employs to go onto private land as inspectors. This is one of the features that concerned me on the Lemonthyme legislation, over which we fought very hard in this place last year. I recall that the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was very critical at the time of the power that was to be given to the commissioners to go onto private land. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that paragraph 14 (c) of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests legislation:
. . . confers on the member or authorised person a broad power to enter upon private land based upon nothing more than the personal opinion of the person exercising the power.
The Committee went on to say:
. . . by providing such a broad power of entry upon land it might be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

That is virtually what the Government is doing now. There are some differences but not enough to make it very significant. The Government is allowing its inspectors, who may or may not be police officers, to go onto private land in certain circumstances without any warrant or consent. I believe that it is quite unacceptable to be continually widening the class of persons who can go onto private land. We now have a vast army of people who would be able to do such things. All Australians should be concerned at this increasing power of the bureaucracy to enter onto private land without the approval of the courts or the consent of the owners.

The entry in itself is serious, but I believe that the widening of the class of people who can go onto private land is also serious. I have drawn this matter to the attention of the Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee because I believe that it is an area in this legislation to which that Committee has not given sufficient thought. It is certainly an area which is concerning very much the industries that understand what this legislation will do to private property. A number of honourable senators have had letters from industries concerned about this. I do not think there is any need to go into that in any detail, except to say that the offering of these powers to wider classes of people is quite unacceptable, not just to the Opposition but also to the people outside this chamber.

I also find it quite unacceptable that judges of the High Court of Australia seem to be no longer the ones who will have the ability to decide matters such as heritage values. Those decisions will now be made not by our judges but by people outside Australia. When one looks at some of the countries that are signatories to the World Heritage Convention one wonders why the Australian Government would give people in those countries power over decisions that affect us. I refer to Mozambique, the Laos People's Democratic Republic, the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, Bolivia, Bulgaria, Cuba, Haiti, Ethiopia-many countries that do not seem to be able to run their own countries too well, and have forms of government that we certainly would not want to see having an impact on the way we run our country. However, the Hawke Labor Government seems to be prepared to give that power to other countries. I for one find that quite intolerable.

I find quite unacceptable the whole direction of power that the Government is adopting. I refer to the power given by the Government, firstly, to other countries and, secondly, to its employees-that is, to bureaucrats. They are empowered to go on to privately owned land in Australia. The Government is also prepared to take unto itself power in making decisions in Canberra, not always in full possession of the facts and quite often against the wishes of people who live in the more remote areas of Australia.

I find intolerable that the Government is continuing down a path which, it is quite clear, many people in Australia find unacceptable. I find intolerable also that the Government's line seems to be nothing more than a cheap stunt in order to keep the Australian Labor Party in office by boosting its stocks in Sydney and Melbourne, where it believes it can win more seats. These measures are certainly not politically attractive to people in most areas of Australia. However, by the Government's dominance of House of Representatives seats in New South Wales and Victoria, it believes it is good politics to play for the greenie vote in those electorates.

I fear that the Government is losing touch with its natural constituency, if such it be-the working men and women of Australia. Those people have seen through this nonsense. They understand that it is a political ploy, that it is not based on principle. Indeed, this Government does not seem to have many principles. It is prepared to chase the greenie vote down the holes and burrows and up and down the trees; but it does not seem to care too much about the people whose jobs will be affected by its actions.

I warn the Government that the people in those jobs realise how vulnerable their jobs are now that the Government has jettisoned any pretence at trying to look after people. The Government seems to be concerned more about trees than about people. But we know that the Government is concerned about trees only in so far as that affects votes in certain localised areas.

I trust that the electorate will give the Government a bit of a surprise on Saturday so that the Government will realise that its jettisoning of principles has not paid off. Any government that goes down the track of governing simply by what it perceives to be the opinion polls, and has no caring for the men and women who need their jobs and want to support their families, deserves to be given a shock by the people-and a shock the Government certainly will be given on Saturday. I hope that the people in rural New South Wales particularly, who understand just what it means to care more about trees than people, will send a message to Canberra as well as to Sydney on Saturday.

I am glad that the Opposition opposes this legislation. We certainly have a fine record on environmental matters, and we are not ashamed of what we have done in the past. We believe that when we attain government we will achieve a much more honourable record on environmental matters. The Federal Government is not an environmentally alert and aware government. It is an unprincipled government that will do anything for a vote regardless of the men and women of Australia who are working to keep their families and to increase the wealth of this country. This sort of legislation, with its quite obnoxious overtones, is destined, fortunately, eventually to bring down the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken several times in the last few weeks in this chamber about issues concerning the State of New South Wales in terms of the gerrymander and in terms of an ageing and discredited government hanging onto power. There is a particular matter I would like to bring before this chamber this afternoon. As I have said, I have spoken earlier about the gerrymander in New South Wales, where the Liberal Party and the National Party together require 53 per cent of the vote, and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) requires only 47 per cent of the vote, in order to win the coming election. I have raised that issue specifically because we hear so much about the gerrymander in Queensland and yet the Labor Party, being the main aggressor in that area, has failed to acknowledge the gerrymander that exists in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also seen, and I have highlighted, the `protect your own' mentality that pervades the New South Wales Labor Party and particularly the right wing of that Party. We have heard over the last week in particular of Mick Young's Qantas Airways Ltd appointment; of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) touting for business for Mick Young. One asks oneself: What does mateship really entail? What is really involved in the handing out of golden parachutes? I have pointed out that yesterday morning on Sydney radio Premier Unsworth attempted to pre-empt the decision of Mr Ian Temby as to whether or not to prosecute Stephen Loosley when he said, very simply, that he considered that Stephen Loosley would be found only to have committed some sort of an administrative error. He said specifically:
I think you will find that while Stephen Loosley has taken the initial responsibility in the long run he will not be held responsible for what was an administrative question.

We have seen a whole series of articles with headlines such as `Old Mates Rush for Life-raft'. This is not something new to the ALP; it is something which has been long experienced by those of us who come from New South Wales. It goes hand in hand with a `win at all costs' mentality, which began, clearly, with the election of Neville Wran, remained throughout his premiership and has certainly been taken over lock, stock and barrel by Barrie Unsworth as Premier. We could well say that in this respect Unsworth is well in the mould of Wran.

Let us take a look at the weekend story that was not leaked to the Sunday Telegraph but, indeed, given to the Sunday Telegraph exclusively, it claimed, by the Premier himself. The Premier is anxious to win at all costs and to hold onto power at all costs. The article stated:
``We can still govern with a minority. I'll tell the Governor that we are the Government and he can work it out for himself,'' the Premier said on Friday.
``If we're voted against (in Parliament) there'll be another election. And, you know what happens to Independents if the people go to the polls again-they're tumbled out . . .''

This so-called tough minded proposal revealed in the Sunday Telegraph is being developed as the Labor Party's fall-back mechanism for the coming election on Saturday. Nick Greiner, quite properly, pointed out that the Liberal Party will win in its own right in any event but that it was a superb example of the arrogance of Labor's desperation and persistence in trying to hang on to power. The Sunday Telegraph commented as follows:
Independent MPs might enjoy the balance of power on the floor of the State Parliament, but the Governor would have to decide which major party leader he would call on to form government.

Mr Unsworth's disclosure this week suggests he would revel in such a pressure-packed position. And, if the Governor gave Nick Greiner the nod, Barrie Unsworth would be spared the fate of a loser; instead, he would become the latest Labor martyr to be sacked by the Queen's man.

Such cynicism and hypocrisy is engendered by the Labor Party into the political scene in New South Wales that it will be seen through by the people. But, of course, Wran, who has been fixed up with a job for the boys himself, was the master manipulator. He employed in his Administration some interesting operatives who, on their own admission, carried out some very strange tasks.

One such person who was employed by the Labor Government was one John Patrick Begg. John Patrick Begg joined the Premier's Department in 1976. He wrote speeches and Press releases for Premier Wran and was promoted to the Ministerial Advisory Unit after three months. In 1976 he was responsible to the Premier for restructuring the Department of Industrial Development and Decentralisation. In 1977 he wrote legislation and recommended key appointments for the New South Wales Meat Industry Authority. Also in 1977, he set up and managed a nine-member trade mission to Saudi Arabia and returned with a $1m three-year meat contract. In 1978 he was responsible for the 1978 State election campaign in the country and, in the words of his own curriculum vitae, `By astute identification of issues raised the Government's vote from 33.2 per cent to 50.04 per cent'. A by-election was held in Castlereagh in 1980. He says that in 1978 he:

Organised and managed the Castlereagh By-election campaign culminating in a Government win. Co- ordinated press releases/ads/slogans/protocol and issues. The `Curran for Castlereagh-Your Vote in the Government' campaign is regarded as his most outstanding achievement.

I read those items concerning John Patrick Begg from a curriculum vitae prepared by him. I have done that to show that he was a most trusted and important member of the Wran Administration. So he was a man who was in the trust of the Labor Party. He was a man who had influence in the Labor Party and he certainly was in the mould of the winning at all costs scenario.

The year 1980 saw the calling of the by-election for Castlereagh, a country seat which had been held by Premier Renshaw in that great movement of country seats that had been established decades before. It would traditionally be called a Country Party or National Party seat. In 1980, when that by-election was called upon the retirement of Mr Renshaw, 28,828 voters were enrolled. Of that number, 18,112 in fact voted. Those are most interesting figures. We can see that the margin by which the Labor Party won that seat was in the region of 660 votes. If one-half of those people had changed their vote, of course, there would have been a different result.

Mr Begg in 1984 addressed a meeting of a group on the central coast. This meeting was set up for organisers of a campaign to work against the establishment of power stations in that area. In fact, it was held at the Wyong Creek hall in Wyong. On that occasion Mr Begg made a speech which I will now quote. He said:

. . . get your captive audience, and get around and buy 'em a beer, buy 'em a drink, buy 'em a steak sandwich, and keep talking, you know? Stooge-for God's sake, this has been done before, you know, like I mean, they read out my-I'll be quite open to you about this, you know-they read out my curriculum vitae. One of the things was the Castlereagh By-election which was a traditional Country Party seat they said the Labor Party had no chance of winning, and once again, getting back to basics, there were beautiful advertising slogans, there was this, there was that, and I just sat down one day and I, you know, sort of got myself and I thought to myself-this is going to be close. Now, you know, I then went down-there's one office, the regional newspaper office, and Castlereagh started at Dubbo and went right through to Bourke-it was huge-big electorate-and I went down to the local thing and I went-it took me two days-and I went through twelve months and looked at the obituaries and I got everyone that died in the past 12 months and then I compared them to see if they were on the roll and there were 400 on the roll. So I sent little people out to vote for them on these blokes' behalfs and, do you realise, we won the seat by 330 votes.
Loud laughter and comments resulted. He said:

I'm telling you, Big Brother's going to do it to you, so you've got to do it to the-Fred Daley time-you know, do unto others as they do unto you, only better. And that's, you know, that's the way you've gotta do this-you've gotta be tough, you know, you have gotta be tough, and you've gotta realise, now, you know . . .
I have a tape of that speech which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that speech Mr Begg-as I said, a trusted man in the Wran Government-demonstrating the win at all costs mentality, has said from his own mouth that a tactic that was acceptable to the Labor Party was to go through the notices in local newspapers to find the dead and, in his words, `Send little people to vote for them on these blokes' behalf'.
—They have been doing it for years, early and often.

—That is perhaps another manifestation of the `hang onto power at any costs' principle. I have raised this matter here today for the simple reason that, as we go to the polls on Saturday, the scrutineering that will take place will be most scrupulous on the part of the Liberal Party. It has become of great concern that the laws have been changed to allow people to vote in any subdivision so that we run the risk of having multiple voting. As I have clearly outlined, the Labor Party is there to hang on at all costs. Mr Unsworth has his fall-back plan of trying to hang onto a minority government, to try to force the Governor into a position whereby Mr Unsworth could become, in the terms of the Sunday Telegraph, `not a loser but a martyr'. The man who was described by Bill Hayden as pulling wings off butterflies and who has another nickname-Chainsaw Barrie-is not likely to become a martyr. Barrie Unsworth, the man who has tried to pre-empt--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: It is not appropriate for Senator Bishop to tell untruths. The proper quotation is, of course, not that he is a man who himself pulled wings off butterflies but, `If you were the sort of person who pulled wings off butterflies, Barrie was your man'. There is a subtle but very important distinction, which I hope Senator Bishop will acknowledge.
—I thank Senator Evans for his esoteric knowledge on these matters. Indeed, it confirms the point I was just making.
—So you accept the point made by Senator Evans?

—I accept his superior knowledge of the esoterica that Mr Hayden can indulge in. I conclude with these remarks: The people of New South Wales will no longer be fooled by the sorts of pervasive attitude that the arrogant Labor Party, particularly the right wing machine in New South Wales, has to the voters. We have seen a whole sad, sorry tale of the decline of the Labor Party federally. The decline that it has reached federally has been passed in the State arena. On Saturday the people of New South Wales will make their decision and the tired, stale ALP Government, which will do all in its power to cling to government, will be a tired and spent force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution this afternoon will be a little lighter than the one we have just heard from Senator Bishop. I suppose it should be lighter, because today we are all celebrating Senator Devlin's birthday. I am sure that all honourable senators in this chamber join with me in congratulating him and thanking his good wife, Vurlie, for the contribution that she has made over the years to ensuring that Senator Devlin is here today to celebrate with us. It is appropriate, with a name like Devlin, that he should be celebrating his birthday on this particular day.
—Bipartisan support.

—Of course. I thank Senator Watson. The matter that I want to address today is a recent publication which was launched in this Parliament, a book called Acts of Parliament, by Gavin Souter. I found this book absorbing and tremendously informative, and it is one that I will be recommending to any person who has an interest in politics and in the parliament of this country. As a newcomer to the country, in reading it I found a whole lot of information about what has happened in the Parliament over the years, information that I was unaware of or of which I had only scanty knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: In recommending this book to other people to read-it certainly should be in every school library in the country-I point out that it is not a heavy book in the sense of being full of heavy technical terms, which, of course, the Parliament from time to time is full of. It is a compelling narrative that is very easy to read. I did say that it was not heavy in the sense that it was not complex and complicated, but it is certainly a heavy book. It is not a book that one would want to keep holding up. One has to put it down because it is a very large book. It is packed with historical information and I am sure that it will in later years be used as a reference book. But therein lies the difficulty and the reason why I have chosen to stand up and make a contribution today. In the final chapter in the book, `Adjournment', on page 600, Mr Souter talks about the previous Parliament, in 1985. He uses some statistics which are compared throughout the book for the various parliaments that have been formed in this country. I quote only part of what he says:

Ninety-three per cent of members in 1980 were Australian-born, compared with 91 per cent in 1950, and their ethnic origins were overwhelmingly Anglo-Saxon-Celtic. The only non-British European-born members in 1985 were Dr Klugman, who had been born in Austria; Dr Andrew Theophanous, (Lab, Calwell, V), Cyprus; Lewis Kent, (Lab, Hotham, V), Yugoslavia; and Senator David Vigor-gone but certainly not forgotten, who was born in France.
The book continued:
Senator Arthur Gietzelt . . . and Norman Sanders . . . had been born in the United States.

Therein lies the problem for me, because it brings into question all the knowledge contained in the book. Here I stand before the Senate as a person who is European but not British. I certainly was not born under the Union Jack. Of course, I am Irish, but there is no mention of this. I think that in 1988 we ought to have overcome those difficulties.
