The statistics that we have in this country relating to the origins of the people who are here now are confused, because until very recent times the only statistics collected from the part of the world of which I speak referred to everybody as British or British and Irish, and there was no differentiation between the two.

I choose to say this today as it happens to be St Patrick's Day. I will point that out to Mr Souter. Hopefully, he will be able to do something to correct it and an erratum-or whatever the technical term is for the issuing of a correction to a book such as this-will be put out. It is unfortunate that this has happened, and I hope that Mr Souter will turn his attention to it and make some corrections in whatever way possible. I would not suggest that the whole book be reprinted merely because of this small error. It is small, but I see it as important.

I raise this matter today because it is the national day of Ireland, St Patrick's Day. The Irish people have been in this country now for 200 years and were a very important part of the First Fleet. Indeed, if they had not been part of the First Fleet perhaps the First Fleet would not have come at all. Over that 200 years my country-people who are now Australians have contributed enormously to the development of the cultural, religious, legal, political and labour movements throughout this country. In the nation we have now joined, we each share a passion for freedom, and we are prepared to acknowledge that in other forums in the world.

There are deep and enduring bonds between Australia and Ireland-bonds which will be brought to the forefront in a few short weeks when the first ever delegation from this Parliament visits the Republic of Ireland on a fact finding mission. I am happy and proud to have been selected by the Government, by the Australian Labor Party, to be a member of that parliamentary delegation.

I have only a few brief remarks to make but, given that the subject matter is Ireland and today is St Patrick's Day, I mention another very important event which has occurred in recent times and which is cause for celebration, I am sure, by all honourable senators in this chamber and, indeed, by all honest and free thinking people throughout Australia. I refer to the announcement that the former Premier of Western Australia has been appointed to become Ambassador to Ireland on behalf of the Australian nation. Brian Burke has made a contribution, and a measurable contribution, to Australian politics. It is a contribution that will not be recognised, unfortunately, until many years into the future. It is a contribution that has almost always been positive. I speak as a left winger and Brian, of course, is quite happy to announce publicly that he is a member of a different faction. We have had our differences in the past. Nonetheless, I can--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you staying with him in Ireland?

—Unfortunately, Brian will not arrive there until July. I will perhaps have to make arrangements for another trip. I put on the record my appreciation for the work that Brian has done for the people of Western Australia and for the Australian Labor Party, both at a national level-he has played a role there-and in my home State of Western Australia. Many people will, I am sure, be eager to jump up and join me in these good wishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my concern over a Press report in the Canberra Times concerning the remarks of Mr Hand, a member of the other place. The report states that Mr Hand has said that the Aborigines support the idea of setting up an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I am very happy to learn that Mr Hand has agreement from, as the report states, some 6,000 Aboriginal people and some 1,200 communities and organisations. But what the report omits to say is that Mr Hand does not tell us whether he has agreement with the Torres Strait island people. As far as I am aware, Mr Hand has not come to a position whereby the islander people will be catered for under the proposed new legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I know these island people very well. I have been invited to their islands a number of times and I know their inspirations, ambitions and hopes. They are a people of Melanesian and Polynesian background and are a completely different race from the Aboriginal people. The islanders are understandably fearful that the proposed new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will not give them a say in their own rights. They believe that it is going to swamp their culture, their race and their lifestyle.

This Commission, if it goes ahead in the form that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has proposed, will give the Torres Strait islanders one vote out of 11. The islanders have been run by whites for the last 200 years, and under this proposal they will be run by Aboriginals for the next 200 years. The islanders do not want to offend their black brothers and sisters, but they are a separate identity and they have their own needs. It was under these conditions that the islanders became desperate and called for independence-and it was a genuine plea. The islanders are being invaded by Papuans, who come down for traditional visits and stay for some time. Sometimes the women have babies on the islands, the babies become Australian citizens and they are allowed to stay. Sometimes the Papuans intermarry and stay there. The islanders are fearful that they are losing their identity. Some of the people who go there are not immunised and are carrying certain tropical diseases, and that is a worry to the island people as well.

The Queensland Government has recognised the islanders' right to self-management through a democratically elected island coordinating council. That coordinating council represents all the 17 islands and the people on Thursday Island. The council makes its own decisions on behalf of the island people. The council members are elected every three years under the Local Government Act, and I believe that they will be facing an election this Saturday. Every island community is treated as a local council, and one representative from each of the 17 islands-including Yam, Badu, Yorke, Sue and Warraber-form the co-ordinating council, which has its headquarters on Thursday Island. They make their own decisions as far as the State Government is concerned.

The Federal Government, however, has not recognised the islands' ability to make their own decisions, and all the Federal money allocated goes through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. All decisions and priorities are made and set down by white officers in the white-controlled office of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Just 60 or 70 miles to the north of Thursday Island lies Papua New Guinea: a people of similar Melanesian background, a people who have independence. They make their own decisions, arrange their own priorities and run their own lives. The same priorities are denied to the islanders by the actions of the Federal Government. When I say that, I am not supporting independence. I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —You sound like you are.

—Well, I am certainly not. What I am supporting is some sort of autonomy for the island people. I do not believe that they want independence. But let us not force them down that track by denying them autonomy. I believe that they are proud Australian people and that the majority of them do want to remain so. But the islanders have to go cap in hand to the white officers in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to buy a tractor, a boat or a bus, and the system leaves itself open to manipulation. I am not making any accusation against any white officer, but the system is wrong and it can be manipulated for political advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: After 200 years it is time to give these people the responsibility of running their own lives. I believe it is time for a change, and that is what they want. They want some autonomy whereby they can make their own decisions. I do not mean to imply that they want independence. The Federal Government can no longer treat these people as ignorant, uneducated black people. Most of the islanders are educated to senior standard. Some of them go to schools in Cairns and Mackay and other places on the mainland. The young people are growing up, and they are moving down to Cairns and Townsville because they cannot see any future on the islands. They are not able to give anything back to the islands because there are no jobs for them there.

The islands are run by white public servants in the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs, who spend three or four years on the islands and then go to another posting or back to Canberra, and I do not believe that they have the islanders' interests at heart. If they do, they certainly would not be able to put as much ethos into their work as would the people of the islands themselves. Positions in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Customs Service, the police forces and other government instrumentalities must be given to the islanders. The islands are their home and they want to give something back. They are not recognised by the Federal Government. The Government agrees with all the decisions made by white officers, and those white officers receive their instructions from Brisbane and Canberra.

It is time to change, to give the islanders a chance to develop their own industries. Often when a white project officer has been assigned to develop a project on the islands it has failed because the presence of the officer has undermined the confidence of the islanders. There is a fine example of the islanders running their own business. A crayfish industry was developed by the Aboriginal Development Commission and operated by white public servants, and it failed. The island people pulled it together and formed Bardu Enterprises, developing a prominent crayfish industry which has an income of around $3.5m a year. I will not say that it is a thriving industry. It is going through problems but it has been employing a number of island people for the past three or four years and it is contributing to the economy of the Torres Strait islands by some $3.5m a year. The islanders are now developing a trochus shell industry, receiving around $4,000 a tonne, and a fledgling beche-de-mer industry is starting.

Other industries can be introduced. The climate and conditions are ideal for the production of coconuts. The goldmining industry can use huge volumes of coconut fibre in the extraction of the gold. The islanders wish to develop a tourist industry. The Torres Strait area is one of the few remaining unspoilt paradise areas in the world. People who see the islands fall in love with them, and they like the islanders too. The islanders have plans for economy accommodation on the outer islands where one can catch a fish-a sweetlip or a red emperor-almost from the back door of the house, or dive on the reef for crayfish. It would be ideal. The islanders make beautiful artefacts and handicrafts, which would be in great demand for the American and Japanese tourists.

However, none of these industries will ever develop until the islanders can make their own decisions. The islanders are sick of this Government's promotion of the hand-out mentality. They are ready to take responsibility for managing their own affairs. I do not believe that they want independence. They are proud Australians and proud Queenslanders, but this Government should not force their hand by including them in an Aboriginal and Islander Commission. They do not want to be lumped in with the members of that Commission. They recognise their black brothers and sisters but they want to be independent. The Government must give the islanders their own autonomy and allow them to run their own lives, make their own decisions and set their own agendas. We can make the Torres Strait islanders a role model to be held up to the rest of the world as an example of how Australia has created racial equality, or we can drive the islanders to seek independence once again.

After 200 years, we must recognise that these people are hard working, responsible and proud-people who do not want to live on government hand-outs. Giving money to indigenous people without responsibility has never solved any problems and has only created misery among our black brothers and sisters. We do not want to give our islander people a free meal; we want to give them a fishing line so that they can feed themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to speak of a few of the achievements of the Tasmanian Liberal Government. We have just passed the halfway mark in the term of the second Tasmanian Liberal Government led by Robin Gray. It is therefore timely to reflect on some of the achievements of that Government and its plans for the future. In May 1982 the first majority Liberal Government in the history of Tasmania was overwhelmingly elected. On 8 February 1986 it was returned with an increased proportion of the vote. In fact, if Tasmania had single member electorates the Australian Labor Party would have won only a solitary seat in the House of Assembly as only one subdivision, that of Moonah, returned a majority Labor vote. As an aside, I think it is interesting to draw a contrast with the Hawke Government, which has yet to serve anything like its full term, and whose percentage of the vote has declined consistently since 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: In Tasmania there is a government of achievement and a government of reform. In the economic field, 25,000 new jobs have been created since 1982-an increase of 14.5 per cent. We compare that with 10.9 per cent nationally. Also on the economic front, the Gray Government has established, first, the Tasmanian Development Authority, which is a major instrumentality designed to encourage entrepreneurial development of all sizes of business. Secondly, it has established the Tasmania Bank, through a merger of the oldest building society in Australia and the oldest savings bank, to result in a comprehensive financial institution which is able to service the needs of individuals as well as the larger corporate bodies.

Every Tasmanian Budget to be brought down since Robin Gray became Treasurer has been brought in on target. This is despite his Government's inheriting a deficit of over $34m from the Labor years. The Tasmanian Government has abolished death duties and has slashed payroll tax for small and medium sized businesses. The size of the State Public Service has been reduced by natural attrition and unemployment has been reined in. Largely due to the Tasmanian Government's employment schemes such as Taswork, aggregate employment in Tasmania has climbed from 168,000 in 1982 to today's total of 189,000-a good benchmark by any standards of economic development.

Several major industries have objectively seen the favourable economic conditions in Tasmania and a competent government and have moved their operations south. Some examples are the New South Wales clothing manufacturer Gazal Industries Ltd. It has recently moved some of its factories to Tasmania and there is the potential for 300 more jobs in the Glenorchy area with a new plant. The frozen food processor McCains Australia Pty Ltd has moved from Ballarat, and its new plant will make Tasmania the biggest producer of potato chips in Australia. Ansair, the bus building division of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, builds its vehicles in southern Tasmania and Commonwealth Industrial Gases Ltd is presently negotiating a venture with the State Government to farm pyrethrum daisies in order to produce what is estimated to be a $20m natural insecticide industry within five years.

In the field of care for the aged and the needy, the Gray Government was the first in Australia to have a Minister for the elderly. Keeping it in mind that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, I am pleased to see that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, endorsed this approach by appointing a Minister for aged care, even if it is in his Ministry a more junior portfolio. In 1987-88 the Gray Government will spend more than $56m in caring for the elderly and the underprivileged. This represents an increase of some 19 per cent. It has also increased the local government rate remission for pensioners to 30 per cent, and it has increased the heating allowance and the Hydro-Electric Commission rebates for winter Hydro bills. In fact, there has been a conscious decision by the State Cabinet, with the establishment of the Division of Community Health, to increase home nursing and ancillary services so that 1,500 more elderly Tasmanians are able to stay in their own homes, amongst friends and with a measure of independence. This is something that the other States and the Commonwealth could well emulate.

Some people think that the Gray Government is one which is not particularly concerned with the environment or is anti-conservationist. Such a judgment is totally wrong. The fact is that since the Liberals have come to power many initiatives have been taken in the environmental area. The most comprehensive program for better forest practices in Australia, the forest practices code, has been introduced. The departments of lands and national parks have been merged to provide a macro approach to land use management and the protection of native fauna and flora as well as the development of new scientific and recreational areas. The Environmental Department has rigorously tightened up exemptions for industry and has increased penalties for pollution violations. There is an extensive anti-litter campaign supported by strict legislation. The State Government has announced a ban on chlorofluorocarbons in aerosol pressure cans, in a world first to prevent further deterioration of the ozone layer.

I have touched on only a few areas and I will take additional time in other such debates permitted during the year, in which I will outline the achievements of the Gray Liberal Government and the way that it has transformed Tasmania. All this, I must remind the Senate, is against a backdrop of continually decreasing Federal funds from Messrs Hawke and Keating with the loss to a small State of $327m-a drop of 23.2 per cent in State grants, which is disgraceful. Under Liberal stewardship, Tasmania has been transformed from an economic backwater with a moribund government to an exciting and invigorating State with a huge potential and with a State Government which is ready and equipped to manage its beautiful State well into the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of representations made to me I have become aware of a serious anomaly in the operation of Medicare and taxation legislation with regard to living organ donors, such as bone marrow and kidney donors, whose selfless sacrifices can and do save lives. The facts of this matter also clearly demonstrate that this Government has totally lost the respect of the average hardworking Australian family because of its shameful lack of compassion and callous disregard for the suffering accompanying families undergoing transplant surgery.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the case which brought this anomaly to light is as follows: The brother of a leukaemia patient was found to have compatible bone marrow and as part of the treatment made at least five trips from Melbourne to Sydney. These trips involved stays of five days while the medical procedures were carried out. In addition to air fares and accommodation expenses there was, of course, a loss of earnings from the time off work involved. In the case to which I am referring expenses totalled in excess of $3,000. I very much regret that, notwithstanding the excellence of the medical care and the family support, the patient failed to overcome the complaint. This instance only involved trips from Melbourne to Sydney. One can imagine the intolerable burden it would have caused had the donor lived in Perth, Darwin or Hobart.

When I became aware of the situation I put the case to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) for relief under Medicare. He declined and passed it onto the Treasurer (Mr Keating), looking for some taxation relief. This was also refused, although Mr Holding, on behalf of the Treasurer, did say that while some medical expenses were deductable, the donor in this case was not eligible. He went on to say that to cover such a case an amendment to legislation would be necessary and that, although such an amendment had been considered, `it has not been possible to amend the law in this way due to other budgetary responsibilities'. What a pathetic and shameful statement. This Government, which can find money for artists in residence with the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) and for the design of women's surfboards, finds it impossible to assist the people who are helping to save the lives of others.

No doubt this is not a unique case, but there would not be a large number of people affected. How many, I wonder, would there be? Assistance in this area would not be an intolerable burden on the Budget, and I am sure that most Australians would rather see their taxes used to relieve such suffering than to paint a mural for the BLF. I ask the Government, if it has any moral sense or compassion left, to amend the relevant legislation as a matter of urgency so that at least those donors involved in the future are given some assistance in and recognition for the sacrifices they make. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three letters: mine to Dr Blewett and the two pathetic responses-one from Dr Blewett and one from Mr Holding, representing the Treasurer.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
17th September, 1987
The Honourable N. Blewett MP,
Minister for Health,
Parliament House,
Canberra, 2600
Dear Minister,
Re: Mrs Roslyn Mary Newcombe, Raymond Terrace, NSW
I have had representations on behalf of the family of the above who is a sufferer of chronic myloid leukaemia, and has been for 2 1/2 years.
Upon diagnosis, the family were all tested to ascertain their marrow compatibility with a view to a transplant.
Mrs Newcombe lives at Raymond Terrace in N.S.W., and her brother Mr David Edward Wright (who was a compatible donor) lives in Ormond Victoria.

Treatment is being carried out at St Vincents Hospital in Sydney and has necessitated Mr Wright making five trips to Sydney to give bone marrow and blood. The airfares have been $350 per trip, and there has been loss of wages, accommodation costs, etc. etc. that has caused them considerable total loss.

Can you please advise whether the costs incurred can be recouped under Medicare as, although Mr Wright is not a ``patient'' within the normal interpretation, he is very much a part of the treatment and in the saving of a life.
Should you believe this is not an item of claim, can you advise me if the costs can be claimed as a tax deduction.

I feel sure that the Government would accept that this type of treatment is just as essential as that provided by the doctors themselves, and in this instance the strains on Mr Wright's family by his providing assistance to his sister, has been very considerable.
Yours sincerely,
Brian R. Archer,
Senator for Tasmania
20 November 1987
Dear Senator Archer,

Thank you for your personal representations of 17 September 1987, on behalf of the family of Mrs Roslyn Mary Newcombe of Raymond Terrace, about the recoupment of costs associated with trips to Sydney by Mr David Wright to donate bone marrow.

Under the Medicare arrangements benefits are only payable towards the cost of professional services rendered by legally qualified medical practitioners, certain specialist services rendered by approved dentists and consultations by participating optometrists. There is no provision under Medicare for costs associated with travel to or from places where hospital/medical treatment is undertaken.

Although my Department administered the Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme (IPTAAS) until 31 December 1986, I regret that as Mr Wright is not a resident of an isolated area he would not have been eligible for financial assistance under that Scheme if his journeys occurred before IPTAAS ceased.

From 1 January 1987 the State Health Departments assumed responsibility for patient transport assistance. Mr Wright may therefore wish to take this matter up with the State Department of Health, Victoria.

With regard to your request for advice as to whether Mr Wright's travel costs can be claimed as a tax deduction, I have forwarded a copy of your letter to my colleague, the Treasurer, for reply to you direct on that aspect.
Yours sincerely,
(Sgd.) NEAL BLEWETT
Neal Blewett
Senator B. R. Archer
PO Box 542
BURNIE, TAS. 7320
TREASURER
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA 2600
Senator B. R. Archer
P.O. Box 542
BURNIE TAS. 7320
Dear Senator Archer

As you know your representation of 17 September 1987 to the Minister for Community Services and Health on behalf of the family of Mrs R. M. Newcombe of Raymond Terrace, NSW was referred to the Treasurer. In particular you asked whether the costs associated with travelling to donate bone marrow and blood could be claimed as an income tax deduction. Mr Keating asked me to reply.

The Commissioner of Taxation, whose assistance I sought, explained that there are no provisions within the income tax law which authorise deductions or rebates for travel and other incidental expenditure ancillary to medical treatment. However, the law does allow a rebate for medical expenses, and for this purpose the term ``medical expenses'' is specifically defined. Although the definition covers a fairly wide range of expenses, it does not extend to include the type of expenditure incurred by Mrs Newcombe's brother.

Accordingly, an amendment of the law would be necessary before the taxation concessions could be extended to cover such expenditure. Similar proposals have been considered on several occasions in the past. However, to date it has not been possible to amend the law in this way due to other budgetary responsibilities. Although I sympathise with Mrs Newcombe's situation, I am unable to recommend such a change to the Government.
I trust this information is of assistance to Mrs Newcombe and her family.
Yours sincerely
(Clyde Holding)
Minister Assisting the Treasurer

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators and members have been circulated with a note on the withdrawal of cleaning services today. The text of the circular issued by the Secretary of the Joint House Department reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: Cleaning in the new Parliament House will be undertaken by contract and tenders are presently being evaluated. Concurrently action is being taken by the Joint House Department to ensure that as far as practicable alternate employment is found for cleaning staff currently employed and that the rights and entitlements of staff are protected. Consultations with staff and the Federated Miscellaneous Workers' Union (FMWU) have been an integral part of this process.

At a meeting this morning between staff and the FMWU they have advised that they have stopped work for the remainder of today. This action has been taken in support of issues arising from the abovementioned action. Consequently there will be no further cleaning undertaken in Parliament House today.
Normal cleaning services will resume tomorrow.

The Department has been engaged in discussions with staff and has taken a number of initiatives to find alternative employment. To date, jobs have been found for eight staff, with 18 yet to find alternative employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Staff of the Parliamentary Catering Service held a stopwork meeting today which affected luncheon services. Services resumed at 1.20 p.m. Staff have advised that further rolling strikes may occur. The Joint House Department has requested urgent meetings with staff and union delegates. I table for the information of honourable senators the letter that the Speaker and I sent to staff early in January regarding decisions taken on cleaning and catering in the new Parliament House. I will keep honourable senators informed on these matters.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENT HOUSE: CLEANING AND CATERING STAFF

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statements regarding the catering staff and the cleaning staff.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statements.

I think it is unfair and totally inappropriate that cleaning and catering staff who in some cases have worked in Parliament House for 30 years, since the Menzies era, giving loyal, faithful and good service to Parliament House, should become redundant on 30 June and have to go onto unemployment benefit. I would just like to point out to honourable senators that if the same procedure were adopted for honourable senators because of the move to the new Parliament House, we should probably all go to the people again to see whether current senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your case?

—The High Court of Australia is currently deciding mine. Perhaps we should all go to the people again for them to decide whether honourable senators and honourable members are suitable for the new premises. I do not think that any senator or member would agree with that course of action. Neither do I think it is fair that long serving members of the catering staff and cleaning staff should be put on the scrapheap just because we are moving into a new building. Some of the cleaners are young people with families and homes to pay off. They do not know what they will be doing after they lose their jobs. No doubt they will have to join the ranks of the unemployed. I do not think it is proper and fair for the Parliament to be acting in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not think a debate on this matter is warranted. But, since Senator Wood has made those remarks, I will say that I believe that the people of Australia would expect the Presiding Officers to be looking to the efficient running of what is a very expensive institution. Mr President, I have noted that all of your comments have included reference to the fact that discussions have been going on with respect to the placement of staff who will be losing their jobs in the transfer.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is quite absurd to suggest that the running of this place should be exempt from the normal requirements of efficiency that face other Australian institutions. I hesitate to say that I welcome some privatisation of these matters, but, in fact, I do think you are entitled to the support of the Parliament in what is, I think, a very necessary effort to avoid a ballooning of costs. I am sure that Senator Walsh would require that of you, knowing a little of the negotiations that have taken place between the Presiding Officers and the Department of Finance with respect to appropriations.

Mr President, because of Senator Wood's comments, I merely want to add that everybody here would expect the existing staff to be treated with consideration and would expect to be taken the sorts of measures that you have indicated are being taken. But that should not stand in the way of appropriately efficient and effective procedures being put in place in the new and permanent Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also point out to all senators that no members of the catering staff have been made redundant. There are completely different sets of issues in both disputes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February I reported that a species of legionella bacteria, legionella bozemanii, had been detected in air-conditioning water cooling towers in the provisional Parliament House. I further reported that at the time of its detection, the contents of the towers had been dumped, the towers scrubbed and the new water treated with biocides to control bacterial growth.

INTERJECT.PARA: The latest series of tests of the water cooling towers were carried out on 25 February and the certificate of analysis for these tests provided by Maxwell Chemicals Pty Ltd advises that no legionella bacteria were detected during these tests. Weekly dosing of the towers to control any bacterial growth will continue and scientific testing of the water for legionella bacteria will be carried out on a monthly basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the Minister remember that on Monday, 22 February-three weeks ago-he claimed that the container depot crisis in Sydney would be under control within two weeks? Does he still make that claim today, when the Australian Shippers Council states that the backlog has increased since the Minister's statement from 1,000 TEUs to 1,500 TEUs? Does he now agree that, even with the extra facilities provided by the Australian National Line depot which began operating a few days ago and the reopened Rozelle depot, it will still take at least another seven weeks to clear the backlog? Is the Minister also aware that the proposal to introduce a second shift of depot workers failed because the unions would not agree to a second shift without a trade-off of five weeks annual leave instead of the usual four? When will the Minister seriously consider the possibility of allowing licensed depots, other than union approved depots, to assist in clearing the backlog? When, in fact, will the Minister do something to bring an end to this appalling situation on the Sydney waterfront? How long will the Minister delay while small businesses are suffering serious hardships and facing bankruptcy as a result of the delays in receiving their imported goods?
—I have great pleasure in referring this question, if I may, to the Minister assisting me in shipping and waterfront matters, Senator Robert Ray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not copy down the nine or 10 parts of the question that Senator Hamer asked, but I think I got the general drift of what he said and I did follow his previous questions and interest in this matter. A whole series of talks has been held between employers, unions, ship companies and officials of the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Transport and Communications to try to resolve the short term problems in regard to this backlog in Sydney. The Government, like any responsible government, cannot be satisfied with the current situation in Sydney. In a previous answer, Senator Gareth Evans pointed to some of the almost exceptional circumstances that have occurred on this occasion. An increase of 30 per cent in the arrival of containers was one of those. The closing of Darling Harbour for events associated with the Bicentennial was another. Nevertheless, this dispute, or this failure to clear the backlog, is really a good window, if you like, into the general problems of waterfronts around Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: In some ways the Government is stuck because of its own strategy. Because these matters are not strictly Federal and in many cases State matters are involved-for instance, States usually control the harbours-this situation was referred to the Inter-State Commission for a general development of a strategy. I am fairly certain that Senator Hamer would have followed the timetable on that. It is very hard to find other than bandaid solutions to these problems when everyone knows that there is an overall body which, hopefully, will bring down a final report in July to outline a total waterfront strategy. It is very hard to bring all the parties together. Nevertheless, on the latest information available to us, we think that the backlog will be cleared up in about four to six weeks and there is ample potential for it not to recur. I have also instructed members of my Department to start looking at the waterfront in Melbourne in case a similar problem develops there. If there is a backlog in Sydney it is natural for some importers or exporters to say, `Let us re-route the goods through Melbourne'. Suddenly we could have the situation replicated in Melbourne. I hope that if there is any sign of that occurring these matters can be dealt with more expeditiously and headed off before Melbourne has the problems that exist in Sydney.

In conclusion, I share Senator Hamer's concern about the delays that have occurred in Sydney. However, I believe that the various employer and employee bodies have made some substantial progress in this regard in the past few weeks. The indications are that the backlog should be out of the way within four to six weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications comment on a report on the front page of today's Australian newspaper suggesting that Qantas Airways Ltd could fund the coming expansion of its airline fleet using internal funds and retained earnings without blowing out its debt to equity ratio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to do so. The report in today's Australian of statements by Qantas officials to the Caucus committee on transport and communications a couple of nights ago is not in fact accurate. The first thing that should be said is that the planned capital expenditure program by Qantas over the five years to 1991-92 is not $600m as reported but $5.4 billion. The $600m is the capital injection needed by the company to prudently undertake a capital program of $5.4 billion. Secondly, the article ignores the fact that Qantas is already very highly geared, by any international standard in the aviation business, and it implies that Qantas could comfortably undertake this huge capital program without a further capital injection.

ANSWER.PARA: In the discussion paper which I released publicly a few weeks ago, in mid-February, I made it clear that Qantas is presently very highly geared, with a debt to equity ratio of 79 : 21, as at the end of the last financial accounting period, 31 March 1987. I further noted that, if a capital injection was not received, that ratio would increase from an estimated 72 : 28 in 1989-90 to 78 : 22 for the two years thereafter. In that paper I also pointed out that independent professional advice obtained by Qantas had concluded that a ratio in the range of 70 : 30 at the top and 60 : 40 at the lower end would be commercially prudent. An injection of $600m in 1989-90-or about that period-is required to bring the debt to equity ratio of Qantas within this range.

A marginal improvement in the ratio from the current high level to that of 78 : 22 simply does not address the potential problems that a highly geared company faces, particularly a company in a commercial environment with a very variable revenue flow. A high gearing ratio reduces the company's commercial opportunities and does not provide a cushion for cyclical downturns that occur, particularly in the international airline business. The article in the Australian this morning points out that three of Qantas's major competitors-and I am sure that this is generally true elsewhere-have debt to equity ratios ranging from as low as 33 : 67 to 58 : 42, yet the article fails to draw the obvious conclusion from that. The Qantas officials at the meeting confirmed the conclusions and the figures which I detailed in my discussion paper and which I am retailing to the Senate now.

Contrary to the impression given by the article, the Qantas officials did not see a continuation of the current high debt to equity ratio as being sustainable. While it is possible to finance any capital expenditure program through a combination of extra borrowing, particularly when supported by a degree of government guarantee and through retained earnings, the truth of the matter is that the directors of Qantas-no more than any other similar commercial organisation-cannot be expected to undertake a course of action that they consider commercially imprudent. That would contravene their obligations not only under the companies code but also under the guidelines issued by this and the predecessor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Following concerns expressed in the Australian Labor Party's Caucus and other Party forums about the impact of some environmental legislation on regional economic interests, I ask: Has the Government established an inter-departmental committee (IDC)-either formally or informally-or some sort of working group or party to look in detail at matters of environmental legislation with a view to getting a greater input from departments such as the Department of Primary Industries and Energy? If so, what is the precise nature of this IDC or working party, what is it specifically undertaking at present and to whom will it be making any reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a discussion in the Party Caucus a few weeks ago which involved some criticism of the Australian Labor Party having too much of an environmental bent. However, that was in relation to national parks and, as I pointed out to the Caucus in the debate, the Commonwealth has no jurisdiction over national parks. Therefore, the matters being raised were for the States. People who are concerned about it should talk to the State governments concerned. I pointed out that it was my responsibility as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to look after the National Estate-I will be doing a bit of that this afternoon in opposing Senator Walters's Bill-and to look after World Heritage. I might say that Caucus has decided to do nothing about this and has continued to support the basic line that I have taken; I have no doubt that it will continue to do so. The only IDC of which I can think and to which Senator Watson may be referring is an IDC which is currently looking at land use. That may report towards the end of April. It will report to a range of Ministers and I anxiously look forward to seeing it.
—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister give us the details of that inquiry into land use?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —If further details are required on what we are looking at, I shall inform Senator Watson of them. I am delighted to see that he is taking an interest.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of reported comments by the Tasmanian Health Minister, Mr Roger Groom, about the funding problems facing Tasmania's public hospitals? Is it true, as suggested by Mr Groom, that the funding problems are the result of the Federal Government's introduction of Medicare? Is the Minister able to say why public hospital funds in Tasmania are under pressure? Can he explain how the Federal Government is responsible for the failure of the Tasmanian Government to include the 4 per cent second tier wage rises in estimates of the salary budget for public hospitals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —From recent Press comments, I understand that the Tasmanian Government faces a $6m blow-out in its hospital budget this year. Any suggestion that the Federal Government or Medicare is to blame for this is, of course, nonsense. State governments are entirely responsible for preparing and maintaining hospital budgets. The States set their own priorities for spending their health dollar-not the Federal Government. Under Medicare, the State governments are currently provided with an additional $1 billion to compensate them for the abolition of charges in their public hospital sector and to subsidise the cost of treating private patients in public hospitals. Tasmania will receive over $35m this year under the Medicare compensation grants. This is in addition to the identified health grants and general financial assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears from the Press comments that a major reason for the budget overrun is the cost effect of the 38-hour week for nurses. All State governments have been aware of the likely flow-on effects of nurse awards and the cost implications of the second tier wage rises. I am not aware of any other government finding itself in the embarrassing position that the Tasmanian Government apparently is in at the moment. It is a reflection on the industrial relations practices of the Tasmanian Government that now, at the eleventh hour, it finds itself at loggerheads with its hospital sector unions. In short, the Tasmanian Government has got itself into a mess because of bad planning and, in casting around for any scapegoat other than itself, it has attempted to blame Medicare. Blaming Medicare for anything and everything wrong with the public health system is a tired old excuse. The facts simply do not support the assertion. Public hospitals in Tasmania are under pressure because of bad State Government management, not Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of Victorian Government plans to allow subdivision of an area of wetlands around Greens Bush on the Mornington Peninsula? Is the Minister also aware that this wetlands area is used as a shelter area during the Australian summer by migratory birds-in particular, the Japanese snipe, a bird which is protected by the `agreement between the Government of Australian and the Government of Japan for the protection of migratory birds and birds in danger of extinction and their environment'? Will the Minister undertake to investigate the matter and ensure that Commonwealth Government responsibilities under the international agreement will be met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the concerns regarding the Greens Bush area on Mornington Peninsula where a subdivision has been proposed because I received a number of representations on it prior to getting Senator Powell's question. The significance of the area has been recognised by the Government. Last year the Prime Minister provided a message of support to the Victorian Conservation Trust's efforts to purchase some of the land in question to make sure that there is a possibility of its incorporation into the national park in the area. The Greens Bush wetlands is a habitat area for the Japanese snipe, which is listed under the agreement between Japan and Australia for migratory birds. The habitat values of the area have been exhaustively assessed by the Victorian Government and it subsequently acquired 171 hectares of the Greens Bush area for ultimate inclusion in the Nepean State Park.

ANSWER.PARA: The responsibility for the implementation of the agreement between Japan and Australia will be met. It does not oblige Australia to protect particular areas where migratory birds occur. Rather, it provides a framework within which each country can give an overall commitment to the protection of migratory birds and their habitats. Australia will continue to implement the agreement. In Victoria it is implemented via wildlife legislation. However, I will ensure that the concerns raised by Senator Powell are conveyed to the relevant Victorian Minister. If there is any more that the Commonwealth can do, I will make sure that we do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. In light of recent reports about the low take-up level in Victoria of the Government's new family allowance supplement compared with better figures in States such as Queensland, can the Minister provide any information about the take-up in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Devereux for his question, which obviously highlights the Government's concern for the needs of low income earners in the Australian community. The family allowance supplement scheme was introduced in a context of people on low incomes having acute needs for finance. It should be noted and remembered that under the previous Government real disposable incomes for low income families declined substantially. The incomes of beneficiary couples with, say, four children, decreased by over 5 per cent. As a result of the period of the previous Government, the number of children in poverty more than doubled while at the same time the additional pension benefit for children fell by approximately 32 per cent in real terms. So in government we have had to work within that contextual background.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's new family allowance supplement has been welcomed by low income working families not only in Tasmania but throughout Australia. The payment is especially valuable to Tasmanian families because incomes are generally much lower in that State than elsewhere in Australia. In response to Senator Devereux I should say that, on the most recent available figures, 4,868 families in Tasmania are now receiving this tax-free assistance of up to $28 a week for each child, on top of their family allowance payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who introduced the family income supplement?
—Senator Chaney mentions the family income supplement. I will get to that later.
—He doesn't mention it; he asks who introduced it.

—Senator Vanstone will get her answer. The imposter of Miss Devine should just simmer down. The most recent available figures show almost 5,000 Tasmanian families now receiving this assistance. The Government estimates that in Tasmania 9,000 working families, with about 20,000 children, are eligible to receive the family allowance supplement, and the Government is keen to ensure that all these families are processed to receive the supplement. Already the Department of Social Security is processing 500 further claims. In addition, the Department of Social Security hotline in Tasmania is indeed running hot with inquiries about the family allowance supplement. I should mention that this is happening in the context that the Prime Minister recently wrote to 1.3 million Australian families which have one or two children, reminding them of their eligibility for benefit under the scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The question that Senator Chaney raised was in respect of another provision. I should say in that context that the Government is particularly pleased with the take-up of the family allowance supplement when one considers that fewer than 2,000 families in Tasmania were receiving the payment that it replaced, the family income supplement. I do not have to say much more than that this is part of the Government's program. The Prime Minister has written to all of these families and it is part of the Government's commitment to ensure that no Australian child lives in poverty by 1990.

In closing, I thank Senator Devereux for his concern in this matter and note the disregard with which some members of the Opposition obviously treat this extremely important issue of incomes assistance to low income families.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR HOME AFFAIRS: LOW INTEREST HOUSING LOAN

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of yesterday's statement by the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Ray, as reported in today's Melbourne Age, that, despite being currently in receipt of a salary package approaching $100,000, he will not be pushed into paying out a low interest housing loan which he obtained in 1978 prior to entering the Parliament? In view of the refusal by the Minister for Home Affairs to acknowledge any moral obligation to make way for the many thousands of deserving families who would greatly appreciate access to such funds, I refer the Minister to remarks he made in the Senate on 17 November 1982 about the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, who found himself in similar circumstances. Senator Walsh said:

QUESTION.PARA: If the Government really expects to be taken at all seriously, the prerequisite to gaining any moral credibility, any moral authority at all, is for the Prime Minister to instruct his deputy to repay that 4 3/4 per cent loan.

Does the Minister still adhere to those lofty principles? If so, will he advise the Prime Minister to instruct Senator Ray to repay the loan? If he will not do so, is the Minister content for the Australian community to reach the irresistible conclusion that double standards have replaced moral standards as the order of the day?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of double standards. Indeed, I used to publish quite a lot about standards a few years ago. I table a page from a June 1981 issue of News Sheet which I used to publish some years ago. It has some examples of double dipping, with the notation that the dollar figures given are those of the day and need to be upgraded quite significantly, of course, to convert them to present value dollars. I have not seen the story to which Senator Alston referred. My colleagues tell me that it appeared in several newspapers, but as I have yet to read this morning's newspapers, I have not seen it.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I do remember that in the 1960s Mr Anthony, Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon obtained loans with, I think, a 4 1/2 per cent interest rate. In the early 1980s, Mr Anthony was paying a massive $19 a week-not as rental, but as rental purchase-for a house in Forrest which even at that time was believed to be worth well over $100,000. I think that the interest rate was 4 1/2 per cent over a 25-year period. Mr Nixon, who, even by National Party of Australia standards, has a very thick hide, had one as well. For all I know, both still have those loans, although, I think Mr Anthony flogged off the house in Forrest in 1983 for about a quarter of a million dollars. I certainly remember that very well and I do not resile from anything I said about it at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does Senator Walsh resile from the moral standards that he enunciated in 1982? If not, why are they not applicable in the present instance?
—I have already answered that, Mr President.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security the following questions: Has the proposed agreement with Italy providing for reciprocal arrangements for the giving of social security benefits been ratified by the Australian and Italian governments? If either or both governments have not ratified the agreement, what is the reason? If it has not been ratified, can the Australian Government do anything about finding an expeditious conclusion to the agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised in Senator Cooney's question is of concern to the Government. Reciprocal agreements are an important priority for the Government for a number of reasons. Obviously, they impact on the income of migrants in this country and are of real concern to elderly migrants in Australia. The three categories of people to whom they are of real concern are migrants in Australia who have not been here long enough to qualify for payment of Australian benefits; those who have been resident in Australia for long periods but return to their original country before eligible for Australian pensions; and those who paid into overseas social security funds but do not get paid because they came to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to Senator Cooney's second question, the Prime Ministers of Australia and Italy signed the reciprocal agreement in April 1986. Australia is ready to ratify the agreement, but Italy has yet to pass legislation. The recent resignation of the Goria Government has, yet again, delayed ratification. Yesterday the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, expressed his disappointment at the new delay and also his intention to proceed quickly with ratification. The Government is very keen to see the agreement ratified. Last January in Rome Mr Howe raised the matter with Mr Rino Formica, the Italian Minister for Labour and Social Welfare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are you staying?

—I have not stayed at some of the places at which the honourable senator would probably stay. The Government is extremely concerned to get the agreement ratified very quickly. To that effect, Mr Howe gave an undertaking yesterday that he would be keen to return to Italy if that would assist ratification in any way.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator KNOWLES: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What amount of Federal Government funding has been allocated in total for the recovery of unexploded ordnance in the Warnbro area of Western Australia and over what period? What is the current allocation for such clearance? When will this allocation cease? Has any provision for further funding for clearance at Warnbro been made in the 1987-88 defence budget? Is it proposed that any other funds be allocated for clearance of unexploded ordnance in neighbouring areas?

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time I have some fairly detailed briefs, which even go so far as to talk about dead fish in Jervis Bay, but unfortunately, by some oversight, we do not have this issue covered at the moment. I will seek an answer from the Minister for Defence and try to provide it by tomorrow.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources, is a follow-up on a question asked yesterday by Senator Giles regarding the Australian Bureau for Agricultural and Resource Economics and relates specifically to the iron ore industry. I ask the Minister to inform the Senate of the industry's performance and to give reasons for its performance. I ask the Minister whether the industry is approaching the next round of negotiations with confidence because the buyers of our iron ore now see Australia as being a reliable supplier.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did answer a question by Senator Giles yesterday about Australia's production of mineral commodities over the last year and the quite spectacular output that we enjoyed over that time. I knew of Senator McKiernan's question so I was not surprised by it. Production of iron ore in Western Australia last year was a record one million tonnes, 4 million tonnes above the previous record that Western Australia set--
—One million tonnes?

—I am sorry; it was 100 million tonnes. I thank Senator Chaney for his interjection. He has given me an opportunity to correct the record. It was 4 million tonnes above our previous record. That record output was achieved despite a significant reduction in the number of workers employed in the Pilbara. Improvements in productivity and a significant reduction in industrial disputes have been features of the iron ore industry over the past three years. Those factors have had a positive impact on the marketing of iron ore overseas. The improvements in productivity, which in some cases have exceeded 30 per cent, have given buyers a clear indication that the Australian iron ore industry-both management and workers-is determined to ensure that it remains the most efficient supplier in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: The reduction in industrial disputations over the past four years has shown that Australian suppliers can be relied on to supply iron ore when it is required. I might say that the one exception to that was when the industrial relations record was blemished last year by a dispute at Robe River. That is the most significant single blemish. Of course, that dispute was a company initiated one. The Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council, which was inaugurated by the Prime Minister in 1984 as a joint Commonwealth and Western Australian Government initiative, has played a most important role in achieving productivity gains and improvements in industrial relations.

Regarding Senator McKiernan's question on price negotiations, those negotiations have been completed for deliveries of iron ore in 1988. I am confident that the improvements in efficiency and reliability will result in significant gains in the quantity of ore the Australian industry is able to sell overseas. I am aware that those negotiations have resulted in Australia obtaining something close to its record share of the Japanese iron ore export trade-a percentage from which we had declined previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also addressed to the Minister for Resources, relates to the ongoing funding of the Bundaberg and Isis irrigation project in Queensland. Is the Minister aware that, until December 1987, expenditure on the project amounted to $163.2m, with $112m coming from the Queensland Government and $51.2m from the Federal Government? Given the desperate plight of farmers in the Isis area who are facing the ongoing effects of drought, can the Minister give an assurance that the Commonwealth-State agreement that finishes at the end of the financial year 1988-89 will be renegotiated and that the Commonwealth will provide a commitment to continue funding at the present level of 40 per cent of the total costs to allow the scheme to be finalised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I am aware of the Bundaberg irrigation scheme. In fact, I have exchanged correspondence with the relevant Queensland Minister, Mr Neal. I might add that he has ranked all of the irrigation projects in Queensland in order of priority. Obviously, I acknowledge and accept his ranking as being indicative of what the Queensland Government regards as the most important priorities. I have to say that in that ranking the Bundaberg irrigation scheme is not No. 1. In fact, I think that the Queensland Government assigns the No. 1 ranking to the Burdekin scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: To go to the detail of the question, the Commonwealth has made a substantial financial contribution so far to the Bundaberg irrigation scheme-exceeding its initial commitment in 1970. The project in Queensland has been generously treated by the Commonwealth under the Federal water resources assistance program and its predecessor program, the national water resources program. From the original commitment to the Fred Haigh dam in 1970, at an estimated cost of $12.8m, the Commonwealth has now contributed a total of $52.65m for the dam and irrigation infrastructures. That confirms part of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. A further $4m will be provided in 1988-89 under the current agreement.

During 1987-88 Queensland will be allocated 60 per cent of the total funds allocated to the States for the Federal water resources assistance program which, the honourable senator will agree, is a fair allocation of priority for those programs from the Commonwealth. Further Commonwealth assistance for the scheme will be considered when the current agreement concludes in 1988-89, in light of the priority accorded to it by the Queensland Government for the Federal water resources assistance program funding and then the prevailing budgetary circumstances and other competing commitments and priorities within the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Transport and Communications has seen media reports that the Queensland airline Flight West Airlines has refused to pay Federal Transport Department charges totalling in excess of $70,000. Can the Minister advise whether these charges have now been paid? If they have not been paid, and in light of the appalling safety record in Papua New Guinea of Flight West's parent company Talair which has resulted in more than 130 deaths of pilots, passengers and bystanders in the last 10 years, could this refusal reflect Flight West's attitude to its financial and safety obligations as a Queensland carrier? Is the Federal Government considering any review of the charter licence and supplementary airline licence issued to Flight West in 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in respect of this matter is as follows: following compliance with all Federal operational requirements for issue of the respective licences, a charter licence was issued to Flight West on 1 June 1987 and a supplementary airline licence was issued on 16 July last year. On 1 July 1987 revised charging arrangements were introduced for all general aviation (GA) aircraft. Under these new arrangements, GA aircraft which use aviation turbine fuel, such as those operated by Flight West on the western Queensland route, pay landing charges for all landings at Commonwealth airports or at airports which receive Commonwealth financial assistance. Landing charges are based on the weight of the aircraft concerned and the extent of the facilities provided by the Commonwealth at the airport.

ANSWER.PARA: The new charging arrangements were introduced only after quite extensive consultation with the aviation industry and were certainly known to Flight West when it commenced its supplementary airline operation in Queensland. However, Flight West has objected to the new charges and has mounted a campaign against them. As Senator Black said, Flight West has refused to pay the landing charges since August 1987. Currently, some $68,900 is owed in respect of its five aircraft. Statutory liens were imposed on these aircraft on 10 March this year.

Under the new charging arrangements, the landing charges applicable, for example, to a return flight from Brisbane to Longreach by a Super King aircraft is $73.71. Based on passenger figures supplied by Flight West this represents some $5.25 per passenger or 1.2 per cent of the return air fare for this flight. This is considerably below the average charge per passenger paid by the domestic trunk operators, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines.

An exemption from landing charges for any operator such as Flight West would require a compensating increase in charges to the remainder of the aviation industry. It would not be appropriate for Flight West to be subsidised by the rest of the aviation industry in this way. In addition to the commuter airline subsidy already provided by the Commonwealth, I understand that the Queensland Government is providing further assistance to Flight West-whether it deserves it or not-through a $1.3m subsidy for the operation of routes formerly serviced by Australian Airlines. As to the final part of Senator Black's question, I can say that Flight West has met all Federal operational requirements for the issue of its charter and supplementary airline licences. Those requirements are very rigorous indeed, as is well known around the world. Flight West is subject to the same monitoring arrangements that apply to all similar operators. Licences cannot be removed because of non-payment of air navigation charges. Accordingly, no review of the charter and supplementary airline licence is being considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories. I refer the Minister to my question to him on 23 February in which I asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Why does the Government not . . . ban X-rated videos once and for all?
I urged the Minister to act before the New South Wales State election. The Minister then replied:
If it is possible to take action on the basis of the information I receive prior to 19 March, I shall.

Has the Minister received the information he expected to receive prior to 19 March? What action has the Government taken? Is it true that an amending ordinance banning X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory has been drafted and, if so, why has it not yet been gazetted? Finally, is there a meeting tomorrow of Australian Attorneys-General with a priority agenda item of video classifications and the achievement of a consistent ban on X-rated materials throughout Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the Government will be taking any action prior to the New South Wales election. There is a meeting of Australian Attorneys-General taking place today and tomorrow in Brisbane. They are discussing this issue with, I think, particular reference to violent videos. I also understand that there will be a meeting in May of those Ministers with some responsibility for censorship. I am informed that that is in fact the most important meeting that will be taking place on this matter. It would therefore be unlikely that we would seek to take action until all that information was to hand. If that means that we have to wait for a further short period, so be it.

—I ask the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women whether it is a fact that Australia recently reported to the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women-the CEDAW Committee. Can the Minister indicate to the Senate how the Australian statement was received? Can she also inform the Senate whether there is any Australian representation on the 23-member independent committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to advise the Senate in answer to Senator Zakharov's question that Australia's reputation as a world leader on the status of women has been further enhanced with a most favourable reception by the United Nations Committee monitoring the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. This was on the occasion just two weeks ago when Australia gave its first report since the Convention was ratified. Under the terms of the Convention which was ratified by the Hawke Government, signatories must submit on a regular basis a report on the measures adopted to give effect to the Convention in their country. Australia's first report was delivered to the Committee in New York on 23 February. I am very pleased with the way in which the Australian report has been received by the Committee. The report was commended by the Committee as an important and diverse report which was an example to other nations in its adherence to reporting guidelines and data provisions. I am optimistic that the fact that Australia's reputation has been recognised overseas will perhaps assist in the process of achieving some kind of bipartisan approach to the very important issue of the status of women in Australian society.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the past several years we have not heard in this chamber as much as I would like from members of the Liberal and National parties on the way in which they, if they were ever given the opportunity, would continue the work that has been pioneered by the Hawke Government. While I am not expecting them to be given that opportunity, nevertheless, I think it is about time that we approached these very important status of women issues on a more bipartisan basis. When the report was presented the Committee also congratulated the Government on its commitment to the Convention through legislation, programs and administrative structures. In particular, the Committee commented positively--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you table the statement instead of just reading it out?

—Some people are very interested in this matter. I am sure that Senator Giles is very interested, as she has worked very closely with my predecessor, Senator Ryan. I am sure that people listening to the radio broadcast are very interested, and I am sure that women of Australia--
—People were listening.

—I am very surprised that Opposition senators are so sensitive to the Australian Government being praised. I cannot understand why they would not welcome and be looking forward to working on a bipartisan basis. I shall continue, because I believe this is a most important issue. The Committee also congratulated the Commonwealth Government. In particular, the Committee commented positively--
—Did you tell them in the report that you dig into the lives of Opposition members' wives?

—I do not know why the honourable senator is so angry. The Committee commented positively on the Commonwealth's sex discrimination and affirmative action legislation, the placement of the Office of the Status of Women within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the implementation of the domestic violence public education program, the establishment of the register of women, the measures taken to counter the sexist portrayal of women in the media, and the active commitment of the Government to the implementation of the Nairobi forward looking strategies through the national agenda for women which, I understand, is the first to be prepared. I would be remiss if I did not comment that this report in which the Australian Government is congratulated is totally at odds with what Senator Puplick said about the national agenda for women in what I would consider to be a rather sloppy Press release. In a Press statement dated 11 March Senator Puplick referred to the national agenda for women as another sloppy, tokenistic and insulting statement. That is what Senator Puplick has to say about this very important document. I am glad that he has returned to the chamber. He might like to explain--
—Why don't you be honest and say why I said that?

—I can go on and explain why he said that; I am happy to do so. He might like to ask me a particular question about that so that I do not take the time of the Senate now, as Senator Vanstone does not like to hear the good news about what the Australian Government has done for the status of women. She is supposed to be the Opposition's spokesperson on the status of women. Why can we not accept this report as good news and why can we not have a bipartisan approach to status of women issues? All we get from the Opposition is criticism and carping about how it is not interested.
—You are boring everybody to tears. Ask yourself why the Labor people say that there is a weary complacency evident in that report.
—Order! I ask Senator Vanstone to cease her repeated interjections, and I ask Senator Reynolds to ignore the interjections and reply to the question.

—In reply to the second part of the question asked by Senator Zakharov, I am also pleased to report to the Senate that Justice Elizabeth Evatt has been re-elected as an independent expert member of this Committee, polling second in a field of 16. Justice Evatt's reappointment clearly indicates her high international standing in this field. I am sure that I am reflecting the view of honourable senators on this side of the chamber-I hope it is also the view of honourable senators on the other side of the chamber-in congratulating her on her reappointment.

—I ask a question of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Media reports relative to the replacement of the Nella Dan allege that there have been irregularities in the handling and awarding of the contract, which allegations now involve the Australian Federal Police. Have such allegations been made to the Minister? What steps has the Minister taken to have a full inquiry conducted into all facets of the calling and handling of tenders and the awarding of the contract? Will the Minister make a report to the Senate as soon as such an inquiry has been carried out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the reports to which the honourable senator refers. A couple of weeks ago I received a letter from a person called Ralfs-I forget his first name-in which some allegations were made about the tender process. Mr Ralfs has forwarded those allegations to the Australian Federal Police. My understanding is that the Federal Police have asked for further information from Mr Ralfs in order to see whether they can establish any sort of problem. It is difficult for me to comment, therefore, on the specifics of Mr Ralfs's allegations. Until that Federal Police investigation is completed it would be improper for me to do so. Nonetheless, as soon as the investigation is completed I intend to comment at some length on what Mr Ralfs has said. However, as to the general question of the tender process itself, I have asked that an official of the Department of Administrative Services with considerable experience in the tender process visit the Antarctic Division in Hobart, go through all the files and report to me on whether or not each and every obligation we had to meet was met. I hope that that report will be available to me by the end of next week or, if not, during the following week. I will most certainly report to the Senate on what I am told.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the revelations by the German magazine Der Spiegel, based on European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) documents and company documents, that the label on a shipment of Australian uranium was swapped with the label on some unenrichable American uranium in order that the Australian uranium could be enriched to weapons grade in breach of Australia's safeguards agreement with EURATOM. I refer also to statements by officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade reported in yesterday's Age newspaper in which they said that the Australian Safeguards Office had uncovered no illegal activity. I ask the Minister: First, if the swap was illegal, does this mean that the Australian Safeguards Office is unable to detect the diversion of Australian uranium for illegal purposes? Second, if the swap was legal, does this mean that Australia's safeguard arrangements are unable to prevent the diversion of Australian uranium into activities banned by Australia's safeguards policy? Third, does the Minister agree with the Foreign Affairs official quoted in yesterday's Melbourne Herald as saying that Australian uranium `goes into one big melting pot' and that `the safeguards are monitoring on paper only'? Finally, will the Government tighten up its safeguards arrangements to prevent the illegal use of Australian uranium? If this is not possible, will the Government ban the export of uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sanders for giving me notice of this question. Two questions were asked yesterday on this very subject. I think one was asked of Senator Evans by Senator Haines and one was asked of me by Senator Wood. The answer that I gave on that occasion is exactly the same answer that I give now. I stand by what I said yesterday. I am sure that that answer is consistent with what Senator Evans said. That answer applies to all of the questions that Senator Sanders raises today. What may not have come through during Question Time yesterday was an interjection that I think Senator Peter Baume made just as I was resuming my seat. The interjection was, `Will you report back?'. That interjection was in the form of a question to me. The answer to that interjection, which I gave at the time but which I do not think is recorded in Hansard, is, `Yes'.
