It is my understanding that the portfolio Minister, Mr Kerin, intends to make a report on the investigations that have been conducted and are being conducted by Australian officials.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be said, with respect to the allegations that have been raised, that there are several competing allegations. It appears that the source of them may be an article published in Der Spiegel in January-February. There have been several articles in it. Many of the news services, that of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in particular, seem to have sourced the articles they have put to air or published from Der Spiegel as a primary source. As I said in answer to the question yesterday, with reference to Der Spiegel we are concerned that allegations can be made at all. When they are made we pursue and investigate them.

I said yesterday, and I say it again today: We are assured, on the advice that I have and Minister Kerin has, that no diversion which offends against the Australian safeguards regime has been made. If the matters referred to in the several particular parts of the question by Senator Sanders are the same as the allegations made in Der Spiegel in January and February, those allegations in particular have been investigated. I am advised, on the basis of information available, that the transactions to which they refer are consistent with the Australian European Atomic Energy Community safeguards agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the report the Minister has alluded to does show that the allegations are true and that there are discrepancies in the safeguard arrangements, will the Government take steps to review its safeguard arrangements?

—As I said, the safeguards mentioned in Der Spiegel in January-February have been investigated. I have just given an assurance on what we are advised-that they are entirely consistent with Australian safeguards. Since many allegations are being made, and I have said that Mr Kerin will report on the outcome of those investigations, it is proper and prudent to wait for that report.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELECTRICITY TRUST OF SOUTH AUSTRALIA: LIABILITY

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the South Australian Government has introduced legislation removing all liability from the Electricity Trust of South Australia (ETSA) for damage it causes to property or persons, including damage caused beyond the South Australian border? Is the Minister aware that because of this legislation persons will be without claims against anybody for restitution and must now take out all insurance on their own behalf, which, even if obtainable, would be cost prohibitive? Is he further aware that should there be another disaster, such as the Ash Wednesday fires, the Natural Disasters Organisation and the Department of Finance would now not be refunded from ETSA's insurers as was the case previously? Is he also aware that there would have been $400m worth of bankruptcies in South Australia if ETSA had not been liable for Ash Wednesday and that, consequent upon this legislation, such an amount may in future be sought from the Federal Government as disaster relief? In view of the national implications of this legislation, will the Minister bring his influence to bear on his Australian Labor Party colleague, South Australian Premier Bannon, to withdraw this outrageous legislation or, alternatively, will the Minister give his assurance that the Federal Government will reimburse legitimate claimants for all damage caused in the future by ETSA, including in the event of major disasters? Will he also give his assurance, in light of the dangerous precedent established by this legislation, that the Government will remain liable for all uninsured Federal government instrumentalities now and in the future?

—The first part of the question was whether I am aware of legislation which allegedly the South Australian Government has introduced. The answer is no. The rest of the question, therefore, becomes non-applicable, except that since Senator Chapman is a South Australian who has displayed an interest in bankruptcy, I will table two pages from the September 1981 edition of the esteemed publication called News Sheet that I used to publish some years ago, referring to a contemporaneous South Australian bankruptcy.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the announcement in June last year by the Prime Minister that the Commonwealth Government would investigate the commercial viability of manufacturing the Sarich orbital engine in Australia. Has any action occurred on this matter? Is there any further evidence on the feasibility of the project? Can we expect an early decision on the manufacture of the engine in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Prime Minister's announcement last year, the Federal and Western Australian governments jointly established a committee to report on the potential for the manufacture in Australia of the Sarich two-stroke engine. The committee has now presented to the Government a detailed blueprint for the establishment of such a facility in Australia. That blueprint is dependent on two things. The report found that manufacture of the engine in Australia would be a feasible economic undertaking, provided, firstly, that the development of the engine is successfully completed-and it is not. It is alleged that there are some nine months to go to complete a satisfactory prototype. Secondly, the obvious requirement is that a substantial international market is found for the engine. These steps must be achieved before any manufacturer or consortium of manufacturers would make a commitment to the production of the engine. However, if the development of the engine continues on schedule, it will take about nine months for that necessary work to be completed.

ANSWER.PARA: Once that development stage is completed, it could take between five and seven years to progress the engine to the production stage. This timetable could be reduced, depending on the priority given to the project. Subject to the successful completion of the preparatory work to which I referred, progress to the production stage will depend on satisfactory purchasers being available. It is believed that the most likely end user would be an international vehicle manufacturer wishing to engineer a vehicle around the specifications of the Sarich engine. I am encouraged by the finding that it would be feasible to manufacture the engine in Australia but the proposal still has to meet the market tests both of getting a committed buyer and attracting private investment, to which I referred.

The committee, in its report, said it has received valuable support from the State governments and the trade union movement for the establishment of a facility. I should add that the development work of the orbital engine company has involved expenditure of about $40m over the last 15 years. Substantial contributions and incentives have been provided by the Federal and Western Australian governments, including funding of this study, I think to a total of about $15m. To assist companies genuinely interested in the establishment of such a facility in Australia, the report and blueprint will be made available through the Automotive Industry Authority in consultation with the orbital engineering company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time Senator Messner asked me a question about Mr Young's superannuation entitlements and his appointment as a consultant at Qantas Airways Ltd. I undertook to obtain an answer from the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has advised that on present understanding of the consultancy arrangements between Mr Young and Qantas it would not be appropriate to specify the position as a public office within the meaning of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973. The types of consultancy arrangements which Qantas has with Mr Young are not of a nature that would be appropriate for referral to the Remuneration Tribunal. The Tribunal normally fixes remuneration of directors, chief executives and senior office holders, not part time consultants. The Minister says that he is unaware of any part time consultant arrangements that have ever been referred--
—What about all the part time members of authorities the Tribunal deals with?

—I will complete my answer and then if the honourable senator has anything to add he may do so. The Minister is unaware of any part time consultant arrangements that have ever been referred to the Remuneration Tribunal. That may be in conflict with Senator Durack's views. In any case, there is considerable doubt whether the Act could apply at all to these arrangements. There are no discretions under the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act to reduce Mr Young's pension in light of his appointment by Qantas as a part time consultant. That Act provides that, where a former member who is entitled to a parliamentary pension also receives remuneration as a holder of certain offices of profit under the Crown, the pension must be reduced. The meaning of `office of profit', as defined in the Act, is exhaustive and contains no discretions.

—At Question Time yesterday, Senator Brownhill asked me a question concerning certain materials which I think he said were reported or made available to the parliamentary commission of inquiry into Mr Justice Murphy and he asked whether those same materials were made available to the coronial inquiry into the death of Mr Eustace. I was unable to answer that part of his question. I say now that the proceedings of the parliamentary commission of inquiry were in camera; therefore, I do not know what information was available. On the question of what information is now locked away, I refer Senator Brownhill to section 6 of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Act 1986, which specifically prohibits access to all documents the subject of inquiry to all persons, apart from the Presiding Officers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Walters asked me a question concerning a health promotion grant of $115,000, or more, to the Hobart Women's Health Centre to promote cardiovascular health in women. I would like to add to the answer I gave Senator Walters yesterday. It appears that her question was based on a recent article by a journalist called Margeuretta Pos of the Hobart Mercury-a newspaper, I observe, which is not well known for its extensive coverage of women's health matters. But to go to the questions raised by Senator Walters, she appears to have got the wrong end of the stick again. Of course, the Hobart Women's Health Centre has three voluntary staff. Their qualifications include bachelor of applied science medical technology, diploma of applied science nursing, diploma of social work and hospital nursing training. Their experience includes overseas and domestic nursing, social work in government and non-government organisations, family planning counselling and technical and further education teaching. The grant will enable them to be paid salaries-or perhaps Senator Walters is in favour of not paying women a fair return for their work.

ANSWER.PARA: The project for which the centre is being funded is not a research project; it is a developmental project. The Women's Health Centre is being funded to identify whether preventative strategies and behavioural changes can be effective in modifying women's risk of developing cardiovascular disease. The centre will run a series of workshops focusing on specific groups of women at high risk. The workshops will assess at risk behaviours and promote attitudinal and behavioural change. At no point did Dr Blewett say, as alleged by Senator Walters, that he would give the grant to the Women's Health Foundation until the centre was established. The Minister said that the grant would be managed through the foundation until the health centre group becomes incorporated. Incorporation of the centre is expected in the next few months. Data initially quoted by the Minister for Community Services and Health was based on Australian Bureau of Statistics and National Heart Foundation figures from 1973 to 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Steady on! Won't those figures be out of date?
—That data showed the trend of an increase in mortality rates from cardiovascular disease for Tasmanian women between 45 and 59 when rates for men declined in the same period.
—Why is he giving us old figures?

—It is correct that, in the short period since 1984, death rates from cardiovascular disease for Tasmanian women have come down-and at a faster rate than for other States, except Queensland. However, if we start from a high base with relatively small populations, a small figure decline equals a large percentage. All this debate about statistics obscures the main point: Tasmanian women have unmet health needs, including in relation to their cardiovascular health, which have been ignored by the State Government.
—You are using five years old figures.

—Cardiovascular disease is still one of the major killers for women, as it is for men. But efforts to reduce incidence of the disease have not been as successful for women as they have been for men. This grant will meet a direct need for Tasmanian women to help reduce cardiovascular disease and enable Tasmanian women to contribute to a reduction of the disease in women everywhere. I think the interjections from Senator Newman are the most eloquent testimony to Tasmanians that she does not really care about this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Haines asked me a question about the nuclear export issue based on articles in the Melbourne Herald. Although most of the points that can be made at this stage in relation to this matter have been made by Senator Cook on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in answer to questions in the last two days, I think there are one or two matters I should add for the record as I represent the interests of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in this matter, and in particular to respond to what was said yesterday about the Herald report.

ANSWER.PARA: Allegations have been made by the members of the European Parliament that the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and the West German nuclear firm Nukem arranged for Australian uranium to be converted into weapons grade nuclear fuel in contravention of the Australia-EURATOM nuclear safeguards agreement. The articles in the Melbourne Herald on 15 and 16 March, which echoed these allegations, were totally misleading. They did not accurately reflect either the statements made by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesperson or the system by which safeguards are applied to Australian uranium. These current allegations appear, as Senator Cook has said, to be the same as those which were made by the West German weekly magazine Der Spiegel in its editions of 18 January and 15 and 22 February. We have investigated the Der Spiegel allegations and are satisfied, on the basis of information available to us, that the transactions to which they refer were consistent with the terms of the Australia-EURATOM safeguards agreement. We are now investigating the latest allegations and honourable senators will be informed of the outcome.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE: OVERSEAS VISIT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

During my recent visit overseas I represented the Australian Government in valuable and productive discussions with heads and members of governments and other community leaders in Mauritius, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Kenya, Yemen Arab Republic, Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Israel, Maldives, Singapore and Indonesia.
These discussions canvassed a broad range of topics, including international and regional issues, economic and trade matters and official aid activities.
There were two particular points of significance about my visit.

The first is that the issues raised range across all our national interests and obligations: the Commonwealth and the Front Line States, for example; trade and aid; the Middle East dispute; the Gulf War and the arms race; human rights; and our immediate regional preoccupations.

In Lusaka, I attended the first meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers' Committee which was set up by the Vancouver Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in order to bring about Commonwealth action to hasten the end of apartheid.
The Lusaka meeting decided on a program of work to achieve two objectives.
One was to widen and tighten Commonwealth sanctions against South Africa.

Australia made an important contribution to this objective by presenting a report on work done by Australia towards the study (commissioned by the CHOGM) into South Africa's relationship with the international financial system.
This study will provide better understanding of possibilities for financial sanctions against the apartheid regime.
Australia will continue to contribute to this study, which will be considered at a future meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Minister.
The Lusaka meeting was not concerned solely with sanctions, of course.

Its second objective was to find ways in which the Commonwealth can play a constructive role in a range of activities: reducing the economic dependence of Front Line States on South Africa; assisting with their security needs; facilitating contact with groups inside and outside South Africa; supporting victims and opponents of apartheid; and counteracting South African propaganda and censorship.
The Front Line States opposing the apartheid regime bear a heavy burden, in the sense that their economic condition is in large measure determined by this regime.
This was a recurring theme in my discussions with leaders of Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique.
We make no bones about our concern for these economies.
Apartheid is the most deplorable example possible of infringement of fundamental human rights.
Unlike the Opposition, the Government will not tolerate compromise over this great moral imperative.
The Commonwealth has focused attention on the plight of Mozambique, a special victim of drought and famine complicated by campaigns of destabilisation by Pretoria.
The drought is particularly serious and international awareness of its effects is spreading at last.

Senior officials of the International Committee for the Red Cross and of the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees describe the refugee situation in Mozambique as the worst they have ever encountered.
The Commonwealth and the wider international community have therefore sought to respond out of humanitarian concern for the predicament in which the ordinary people of Mozambique find themselves.
Australia's capacity to help is obviously limited.
Our pledge of $100 million in aid over three years to the countries of Southern Africa (including Mozambique) is small compared to the commitments of Canada (for example) and the Europeans.
It is nevertheless an earnest of our commitment to a nation bordering on the Indian Ocean, which is a region of significance to Australia.
It allows us, moreover, to continue our close involvement in an international issue of fundamental concern and to assist Mozambique to cope with the consequences of South African destabilisation.
The Opposition's attitude on this point is churlish and shameful.
Let me make two points about this meanness.

One is that-for all the Opposition's indignation about aid to Southern Africa-the fact is that this level of aid will increase by a few cents to about 32 cents on average per head this year! Compare this to more than $95 per head spent last year in PNG (for example) or more than $100 per head in Vanuatu!
The second point is that most of it is in the form of food aid and at least three quarters of our food aid over the past four years has been spent on Australian produce.

If the Honourable Member for North Sydney, having heard this, still disagrees with the idea of giving humanitarian aid to the starving and the famished of Southern Africa, let him go and explain himself to the high-protein biscuit producers in New South Wales or the sorghum farmers in Queensland or the dried fruit growers in Victoria.

I found a clear wish in Mauritius, Kenya and Zimbabwe to develop closer trade and commercial links with Australia, particularly as these countries also strongly desire to reduce their dependence on South African sources.
I made it clear that Australian expertise and technology have ready application in a number of product and service areas.
In particular, my discussion in these countries identified agricultural development and minerals exploitation and processing as areas of great interest and commercial potential.

A trade mission of Australian business representatives will visit Zimbabwe and Mauritius in May this year to explore at first hand the opportunities for increased commercial contact between these countries and Australia.
To succeed in these countries, Australian corporations will need to be competitive and innovative in their approach.
The effort is worth making.
These are countries with an Indian Ocean focus in their worldview, a novel experience for Australian companies, and they offer long-term prospects for Australia.
Australia must recognise at the same time that these countries need assistance to develop their own export capabilities.
My Department for instance, will be extending such assistance to exporters in Zimbabwe to help them promote their products in Australia.
The Middle East is an area of primary trading importance to Australia, with two-way trade of almost $3 billion last financial year.
During my visit, I signed bilateral trade agreements with Jordan, Egypt and Israel.
These agreements will facilitate closer economic and trading relationships, an important aspect being the establishment of joint committees in which business will have a dynamic role.
In my trade discussions in the Middle East, I emphasised Australia's wish to strengthen and broaden our commercial relationship with the region beyond the present emphasis on commodity trade.
I was able to highlight the suitability of Australian technological expertise in a number of manufacturing and service areas of relevance to the region's development needs.

In addition, I was able to talk directly with customers in the $309.7 million a year market for Australian wheat in Egypt and in the $58.4 million Yemen Arab Republic market, for example, where our market share is under threat.

Moreover, at the meeting of heads of Australian missions in the Middle East-attended for the first time by senior officers of Austrade working in the region-we discussed integrated strategies to pursue Australian economic and political interests in the region.
Australia's influence on regional political events is naturally limited but we do have obligations and interests in these events.
One such development is the war between Iran and Iraq.
The continuation of this war threatens our important trading links with both countries.

It also imposes limits on our capacity to expand these links. It has to be said that the Iran-Iraq conflict is being complicated by the involvement of several nations in the supply of arms to both combatants.
This is an obviously important factor militating against solution.
It certainly emphasises the urgency and necessity of controls on conventional as well as nuclear weapons.
The conflict between Israelis and Arabs is especially significant to Australia.
Nearly half a million Australians of Jewish and Arab origin have a direct and often personal interest in this tragic and complex issue.
My visit to the region immediately preceded that of Secretary George Shultz and took place in the atmosphere created by his attempt to bring the disputants together.
The issue was therefore the most significant in the subjects of my discussion with leaders in Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Israel and with Palestinian representatives.

In these discussions, I made clear our realisation that we were marginal participants in events and that we were therefore not in the business of pressing prescriptions on those who were central to the issue.
I made clear also Australia's strong view that the Shultz initiative and those of King Hussein and President Mubarak should be taken up as rare opportunities to begin the process of settlement.

I was able to convey directly to Mr Shultz my impressions of the attitudes of leaders centrally involved and, in the light of these attitudes, to offer what I know our American friends appreciated as constructive suggestions.

While I was in Israel, I expressed to Prime Minister Shamir and Foreign Minister Peres (through a letter from our Prime Minister and in my own words) the deep concern felt in Australia-as a friend of Israel-about the continuing violence in the occupied territories.

I was able to see for myself in Gaza the legacy of hatred being created by the continuing inability of all involved to agree to solve the Palestinian issue through negotiations based on acceptance of the rights of Israel to exist within secure and recognised boundaries and of the Palestinians to self-determination.
During the return leg of my journey, I took the opportunity to visit Singapore and Indonesia and Maldives, our Indian Ocean neighbour.
My visits to Singapore and Indonesia were part of our commitment to maintaining regular contacts with these important regional partners.
They were also my first as Minister responsible for trade.
I ensured that my program reflected this new responsibility in the fullest measure, in my discussion with Ministerial counterparts and business representatives.
My visit in Jakarta, of course, offered the chance of another in the regular exchanges I have maintained with Foreign Minister Mochtar, who is a good friend to Australia.

A full agenda of discussion with Dr Mochtar included the issue of Kampuchea (on which Indonesia has continued to play a major role), progress on the Timor Gap question, the illegal entry into Australian waters of Indonesian fishing boats and access to Indonesia by Australian journalists.
In Maldives, trade matters were an important item of discussion with the emphasis on expanding our existing commercial links.
Our aid program was also discussed.
It was valuable to gain Maldivian views, particularly on topics bearing on our common interests in the Indian Ocean.
My visits to Maldives and South East Asia illustrate the extent and diversity of the regional diplomatic agenda for Australia.
We must focus simultaneously on both the economic and political level on the Indian Ocean, North Asian, South East Asian and South West Pacific areas.
The days are long gone when we could strike political postures against China, for example, while pursuing a trading relationship with China.

Striking the right balance, judging the trade-offs costs in competing national priorities, deploying scarce government resources in the maximum national benefit: these are complex, connected strands in our diplomacy which have to be pursued with sublety as well as energy if we are to protect and preserve Australia's vital interests.
This raised the second point of significance about my visit.
This is that the issue with which it dealt exemplify in many ways the complexities in the conduct of diplomacy nowadays.

By this I mean such issues as disarmament and Superpower relations, for example; the international economic and trade systems; human rights, the effects of racism and colonialism; and the condition of Australia as a multicultural community.

The recent speech to the Australian Institute of International Affairs in Hobart by the Leader of the Opposition demonstrated significant differences of view of foreign policy between the Government and the Opposition.
So have various statements by the newest spokesperson on foreign policy of the Opposition.
There should be no mistake about this.
There is an influential minority in Australia which either does not understand the current complexities in external policy or is frightened and confused by them.
Let me discuss a few examples.
One is the Opposition's view that the Southern African issue is irrelevant and (to use its word) peripheral to Australian interests.

I will not dwell on the Opposition's tacky philosophy (as shown in its statements on the Grey case in Mozambique) that humanitarian aid should be used as a tool of political pressure; as a form of ransom.
It is hard to imagine an attitude that could do Mr Grey more harm.

It is unfortunate that it is necessary to point out the seriousness to us of the situation in Southern Africa as an irritant in world affairs, as a major concern to the Commonwealth and a cause of growing insecurity in the Indian Ocean region.
I regret this because it is a reflection of the Opposition's unacceptably benign view of the doctrine and effects of apartheid.
With one or two honourable exceptions (such as the Honourable Member for Goldstein), the Opposition proclaims its distaste for apartheid but it opposes any Australian attempt to do anything about it.
This hypocrisy does Australia great harm in the Commonwealth and elsewhere.
Nothing could be better timed to show the inherent inhumanity of apartheid than the case of the Sharpeville Six.
Six people not directly involved in a violent incident are about to be hanged as a gesture towards the South African Government's attempts to prop up its apartheid system.
I regret also that the Opposition's position on Southern Africa shows a dangerous myopia about Indian Ocean affairs.
This is a region which is so important to our strategic interests and our trade and communications links that we consult annually with the United States on developments there.
These developments have great significance for us.
This is why we have increased our diplomatic and defence presence there since 1983.
It is why we have such an active interest in encouraging the work of the Indian Ocean Commission and the concept of the Indian Ocean Zone of Peace.
One searches in vain through Opposition pronouncements for some recognition of this.
The point will not be lost on Western Australians.

Another point of significance about the Opposition's reaction to the issues raised by my visit is the degree of misunderstanding-indeed, ignorance-about the conduct of policy towards the Asia-pacific region.
The Opposition makes typically vague and unsubstantiated allegations that the Government has ``dissipated'' its resources and energies in the region.
I think my friends opposite should be introduced to a few facts on this point.
Apart from my Department's specialist resources at home, almost half of all its policy staff overseas are working in this region.

There are, in addition, officers working in the region from such departments and organisations such as AIDAB, Australian Federal Police, Customs, Department of Industry, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Defence and Armed Services, Department of Primary Industry and Energy, and Department of Special Minister of State, Austrade, Treasury, Education.
Since this Government came to office, there have been 192 Ministerial visits to countries in the region and 144 visits to Australia by Ministers of Asian and Pacific governments.
In the first half of this year alone, continuous, active contact with the region has taken place or is planned.
I instance visits to China by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and the Minister for Trade Negotiations on the occasion of the Joint Ministerial Economic Commission.
The Minister for Industry, Technology & Commerce has also visited Hong Kong and Thailand.
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training visited Hong Kong and Korea.
Other activities include:

Trade discussions with China, Japan and Korea; further development of bilateral strategies for Japan and Korea; development of concessional financial arrangements with China to promote Australian commercial participation in Chinese economic development; and development of beef strategies for Japan and Korea.
I plan to visit Japan, Korea, Hong Kong and the Philippines next month and Japan again and China later in the year.

Later in the year, apart from visits to South East Asia by other Ministers, I plan to continue the Australian presence at the annual meeting of Foreign Ministers of ASEAN dialogue partners with their ASEAN colleagues-an activity to which the Government attaches the highest priority.

Australia has consistently supported the efforts of those Governments which are trying to find a practical and lasting solution to the Kampuchean problem, which is a major source of tension in the region.
The Opposition continues to express fear about the relationship with Indonesia, especially since the reaction by the Indonesian Government to Australian media criticism in 1986.
Despite this reaction, there has been continuous and productive engagement between the two countries since then at all levels.
There have been six visits to Indonesia by Australian Ministers, including two by me.
Defence contacts have continued; so have negotiations over the Timor Gap, which are making very encouraging progress.
Australian investment in Indonesia has increased.
Indonesia will be represented at Expo 88.
Access to Indonesia has now been granted to AAP and there is a reasonable prospect of access being given also to the ABC.
I plan to make a comprehensive visit to the South Pacific again this year.
This will repeat my visit to the area in 1986, when I visited all eight independent island states plus New Caledonia-the first ever such action by an Australian Foreign Minister.
I have made subsequent visits to this area.
Australia will continue to take part in the South Pacific forum meeting at the highest level.
We continue to play a full role within the Forum in developing regional institutions on security and other strategic interests in South Pacific countries.
We continue to co-operate with other Forum members on rationalising and strengthening regional organisations.

We have enhanced the trading prospects of South Pacific island nations by our comprehensive liberalisation of the SPARTECA Agreement and we are exploring areas of possible broader trade and economic co-operation.
We have significantly increased our aid to South Pacific island nations.
Papua New Guinea continues to be a principal focus for the Government.
The Prime Minister and PNG Prime Minister Wingti signed a Joint Declaration of Principles late last year which will guide the conduct of the bilateral relationship into the future.
Trade will be an increasingly important element in relations and the Government is actively engaged in a review of our trade agreement with PNG.

Despite problems induced by New Zealand's policy on United States ship visits ANZUS, which is such a significant factor in regional security continues to be fully in force between Australia and the United States and, separately, Australia and New Zealand.
We played an active role in creating the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone.
The Honourable Member for North Sydney has described this development as ``a nonsense''.
It shows how little he understands the region and how greatly he patronises it.
The Treaty is the result not just of the policy of the Australian Government but also the strongly-and widely-held views and desires of members of the South Pacific Forum.
Finally, the Australian Government has actively promoted constructive relationships between Western governments and the island states.
We strongly encouraged the US, for instance, to enter a treaty with the island governments to redress the problems of US tuna fishing in the area.
We have encouraged Japan to develop its relations-especially its economic co-operation-with the island states.
We have encouraged France to develop its relations in the area in a manner consistent with the interests of the people of the South Pacific as expressed through the Forum.
The Leader of the Opposition said in his Hobart speech that ``Mr Hawke announced in Singapore that he would welcome `constructive' Soviet political involvement in the Asia/Pacific region''.

The Prime Minister did say in Singapore that he would welcome a constructive involvement by the Soviets in the region but he went on to say that they would be judged in this not by their words but by their actions in (for example) Indochina and Afghanistan.
There is a world of difference in meaning and emphasis between the two.
There ought to be some kind of limit to the degree of liberty to distort allowed to the Leader of the Opposition who, after all, purports to be the alternative Prime Minister.
We have embarked on policies to increase the competitiveness and productivity of Australian industry.
We have set in train programs of structural reform in industry and greater flexibility in the economy.
These activities are designed to reverse Australia's traditional low export orientation so as to take advantage of the economic development taking place in this region.
The Government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a senior member saw the necessity for this but never had the courage to attempt it.
The point is important because one of the results of this activity has been continued export growth in a difficult trading environment.

Between 1983-1984 and 1986-1987, the rate of growth in exports (that is, export receipts adjusted for inflation) to China, for instance was nearly 30 per cent, more than triple the rate of growth over the period 1975-76 to 1982-83.

To Japan, the growth rate from 1983-84 to 1986-87 was nearly 5 per cent per annum, a significant improvement on the negative real growth rate of the 1975-76 to 1982-83 period and to Hong Kong exports grew by nearly 14 per cent over the period 1983-84 to 1986-87, well up on the 6 per cent per annum growth rate over the 1975-76 to 1982-83 period.

Exports to other countries have also grown strongly in real terms in recent years: to South Korea by nearly 9 per cent per annum and to the South Pacific (excluding New Zealand) by 3 per cent per annum.
Average annual exports to the ASEAN nations have grown by nearly six per cent, despite the problems experienced by those economies during this period.
The Opposition charges that all this activity constitutes neglect.

The kindest explanation for this is that its advisers have not kept it abreast of developments which are having such an influence on our developments as a force for economic and strategic progress and stability in our region.
While all this progress has been taking place, we have heard nothing but negativism from the Opposition.
It is constantly trying to denigrate the country and its economic performance-in the process, trying to instil uncertainty in quarters overseas which are involved in our now more open economy.
I am reminded of the Leader of the Opposition's speech in the US in July 1986 where he spent fully 20 minutes criticising his own country before an audience of foreigners.
It may be permissible (although I hardly think it advisable) constantly to denigrate one's own country at home.
But, to do so while overseas, is a shameful and unpatriotic act.
The Leader of the Opposition should still be embarrassed about it two years on.
Another regrettable Opposition misconception is that this Government has damaged the relationship with the United States with ``gratuitous criticism''.
The fact is that certain aspects of United States economic and trade policy directly affect and even jeopardise our industry, especially agriculture.
This has been recognised by the all-party delegations sent to the United States by this Parliament in 1986 and 1987.
It is certainly in line with comments by the OECD.
If the Government had not pointed this out to our American friends in a forceful but constructive way, it would have failed in its duty.

If the Government had not made the point-and lobbied energetically for it with both the Congress and the Administration-some elements of the United States Trade Bills with particular impact on Australia would not have been dropped or modified.
I refer, for example, to the failure of proposals which would have affected our exports of sugar.

In the meantime, we continue to be concerned with the protectionist tone of the proposed United States trade legislation which could increase the power of the United States aggressively to pursue bilateral solutions to trade problems.
I repeat: failure to continue vigorously placing our concerns before the U.S. Congress and Administration would be to neglect our primary obligations to protect Australian interests.
The Opposition appears to prefer passive surrender in a situation for which they obviously have no stomach.
Well, let them go and explain this to the farmers and others whose interests were and are under attack.
We make no apology for fighting for Australia's interests.
Failure to do so would be to neglect inexcusably a primary obligation to protect Australian interests.
The United States accepts this, even if the Opposition does not.
Admiral Hayes, United States Commander in Chief in the Pacific, understands it.
Only three weeks ago, he gave an enthusiastic account of the state of the United States-Australian relationship to the National Defence University.
``Security co-operation between the United States and Australia has never been better,'' he said.
``It is heartening to see the extent of mutual benefits that accrue from the alliance relationship.''
Mr Shultz himself has pointed out that the relationship is ``as strong and vigorous as ever, if not more so''.
The Government is working energetically to support efforts to improve the framework of world trade through the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations.

The Round has a very broad agenda, which Australia supports: market access across all sectors, for example, removal of non-tariff barriers and subsidies; trade in natural resource products; dispute settlement; rules for new areas such as trade in services and intellectual property rights.
The Government is also intent on ensuring that the Uruguay Round comprehensively addresses Australia's concerns for reform of agricultural trade.
This form of trade has never effectively come under GATT rules.
It represents one of the most distorted sectors of world trade.
Australia's active role in the Cairns Group is intended to ensure that our interests will be effectively represented in trade negotiations.
The final difference on foreign policy between the Government and Opposition which I wish to discuss today is probably the most important.
It concerns the timid, derivative and dependent outlook permeating the Opposition's policy, as displayed in its Leader's Hobart speech.
This is an attitude which the electorate quite properly rejected in 1983, 1984 and again in 1987.
Taken to its logical conclusion, it would oppose, rather than encourage, moves by the Superpowers to develop greater accord on crucial strategic issues, especially disarmament and arms control.
The Australian Government has done all it can to facilitate this process in multilateral forums such as the UN General Assembly, Security Council and the Conference on Disarmament.
We have actively encouraged the process which has produced the INF Treaty, the first treaty actually to reduce the number of nuclear weapons.
We welcome the treaty also because it sets important precedents for other arms control measures.
It applies asymmetrical force reductions, for example, and its verification arrangements are uniquely intrusive and co-operative.

Eliminating medium-range missiles in Asia as well as Europe, it has particular relevance to us in that it reduced the threat to Asian targets which are significant to us-for example, in China, Japan and the Philippines.
Moreover, it represents a significant improvement in Superpower relations which only ideologues and the most reactionary Cold War Warriors would deplore.
Mr Shultz has welcomed the constructive dialogue now taking place between the Superpowers.

The NATO communique earlier this month hailed what it called ``welcome signs of change'' in Soviet policies which created ``the prospect for greater openness in (Soviet) relations with their own people and with other nations''.
A summit meeting will be held in Moscow between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev probably in May at which arms control and disarmament issues will be prominent.
Mr Shultz and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze are meeting on a monthly basis in the meantime.
The Opposition's reaction to these positive developments has been moans and cries of alarm and suspicion.
The Australian Government does not hold these current signs of change with fear and loathing, as the Opposition does.
It welcomes the INF Treaty as an example of these changes.
It will co-operate actively with those nations which are trying to utilise the Treaty in the cause of further arms control.

Australia will (for example) continue to work actively for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, an agreement to eliminate chemical weapons, an agreement to prevent an arms race in space and to control and reduce the use of conventional weapons.
There is an important point here.
The Superpower relationship is not the only area of change in international affairs.
The whole field of international affairs is becoming rapidly more complex; its limits and its definitions are becoming ever more elusive.
Global power has become more diffuse; the loci of power have multiplied.
Issues have created themselves: human rights, for example, and its impact on the doctrine of national sovereignty and the domestic affairs of multicultural countries such as Australia.
There is not a conflict between states or an infringement of human rights anywhere in the world that does not resonate in some ethnic community in Australia.
There are many other complexities with which we must learn to cope.
We have at the same time the characteristics of a developing and a developed economy, dealing with a fusion of economic and political pressures.
We are a pluralist democracy in a region in which plurality and democracy can be alien and even dangerous concepts.
Such a time and such an environment call for creative response.

The Government and people of Australia are fortunate that they are served by professional officers who understand and demonstrate the necessary flexibility and adaptability to allow such policy responses to be developed.

I would like to place on record here the Government's appreciation of this. The Opposition reacts to the complexity and change facing us by diving into a funkhole hoping that great friends come to the rescue.
Its Leader's Hobart speech is redolent of this abject and lickspittle mind-set, unchanged from the 1960s.
All his attempts in Hobart to bluster and fulminate cannot hide it.
The Opposition clearly has no pride in this country, its capacities and the respect it has earned overseas for its actions.
This is why its Leader travels around, putting his country down here and overseas.
Australians as a whole on the other hand, are showing that they are prepared to accept the change confronting them as an opportunity for progress and development.
In this, they will receive the fullest possible encouragement and assistance from the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to this statement on behalf of the Opposition. The statement is really incredible. Of course, we have not had it long, but it does not take long to read. In fact, it has very little content. But what is most astounding about this statement on foreign affairs is the fact that it is predominantly--
—It is hollow.

—It is not only hollow but also predominantly an attack on the Opposition and, in particular, an attack on a speech that was given by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in Hobart recently which received wide acclaim in the media, speeches that he had previously given in the United States of America and, in fact, any other speech of the Leader of the Opposition that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) was able to find. I would have thought that all honourable senators would have been most concerned that a speech which was to relate to such important issues as southern Africa, the Middle East and South East Asia had as its dominant theme an attack on Opposition parties. I would suggest that it indicates how quickly and how far the pendulum has swung that the Minister feels that a campaign speech is necessary at this stage under the guise of a statement on important foreign affairs matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement superficially touches on the major issues that I mentioned-the issues of southern Africa, the Middle East and South East Asia-although, really, the Minister only dropped in to Singapore and Indonesia on his way home and it is, therefore, not surprising that that part of the statement that deals with South East Asia is even more shallow.

With regard to the subject of southern Africa, the Minister attacks South Africa but, unfortunately, he does not deal in any depth with the major political, economic or social challenges facing the southern African states. That was most disappointing. Consistent with the general theme of his statement he rather concentrates on an attempt at political point scoring. Let me refer simply to one example, on page 2 of his statement, where he says:
Apartheid is the most deplorable example possible of infringement of fundamental human rights.
He then adds:
Unlike the Opposition, the Government will not tolerate compromise over this great moral imperative.

What does that mean? The Government retains an ambassador in South Africa. Is that compromise? The Government still deals with South Africa on important trade issues. The Government is happy for De Beers to enter into relationships with Argyle over the diamond ventures in Western Australia. Is that compromising? What the Minister is really doing in this statement therefore is attempting to score political points on an issue that the Opposition would have thought was of great importance. That does nothing for his standing and contributes even less to this important debate.

On the Middle East, and particularly the Israeli-Arab conflict, the Foreign Minister said that he met Prime Minister Shamir and Foreign Minister Peres, and was able to give Mr Shultz good advice-whatever that might be-though he did not give us the benefit of the advice he gave, or of his discussions with the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Israel. There is no mention in the paper or statement of the complexities of the issue, of the constructive options that might be open to Australia, or the alternatives that we could consider in helping at the United Nations, at an international conference or in any other way. In other words, in an attempt to offend no-one on what obviously is a sensitive issue, the Foreign Minister rather abdicates his responsibilities.

Thirdly, we touch on the subject of South East Asia. In that regard the Foreign Minister's comments are even more shallow. In fact, in relation to Singapore the Minister said nothing more than that he visited Singapore. That is not particularly helpful to a constructive debate in the Senate on issues of bilateral concern to Australia and Singapore.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might have said that he did not visit Singapore, about which you could have made a long speech.
—I must say that that is a particularly helpful interjection, Senator. The Foreign Minister did help a little more on Indonesia, when he said on page 7:

SPEECH.PARA: A full agenda of discussions with Dr Mochtar included the issue of Kampuchea, on which Indonesia has continued to play a major role, progress on the Timor Gap question, the illegal entry into Australian waters of Indonesian fishing boats, and access to Indonesia by Australian journalists.

I ask you, Mr Deputy President: How much help is that? They are four topics of considerable importance to the Australian community, and all that we have in this statement, which is supposed to lead this important foreign affairs debate, is that the Foreign Minister raised those issues. That is totally unhelpful. He might as well, as Senator Button interjected, have not mentioned that he visited Indonesia.

One can only assume, therefore, that, as I have said, the priority of this statement was not to address the important issues that could have been addressed therein but rather to attack the Opposition. I suggest therefore that that does not reflect the type of leadership that this country should receive in the matter of foreign affairs. The Opposition has been critical of the Government's choice of priorities in this area and will continue to be so critical.

I remind the Senate that the Government set its own priorities when it came to office. I can quite clearly remember the speech given by Foreign Minister Hayden at a meeting of the Australian Institute of International Affairs in Canberra. He said that as a middle power of limited resources we can best make our contribution to a more just world, a world with less inequities than presently exist, by concentrating on our region. I remind the Minister and the Senate that some of the worst poverty in the world exists not far from Australia. I instance hundreds of thousands of people who are still in refugee camps in Thailand; in South Asia, Bangladesh I think still has the lowest per capita income in the world; even in East Asia, where because of the economic achievements of the newly industrialised countries in that region we sometimes tend to disregard or have camouflaged from us the extreme poverty that still exists within that region, many millions live a very basic subsistence existence. They are the areas which we thought, from the priorities that the Government had set for itself, that it would concentrate on. However, as we know in practice the Government soon failed its own priority test.

I do not know whether that was because of criticism that the Government engendered in the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) with its ham-fisted attempt to influence events in Kampuchea, which was its first attempt. I do not know whether that scared off the Government or contributed to scaring off the Government. Neither do I know whether it was because it considered the small Pacific states as too insignificant for the international status building that this Government wanted. All I do know is that, for whatever reasons, it neglected the region for other priorities-priorities which we know as world stage issues, such as international disarmament, Nicaragua which, I remind the Senate, the Minister visited soon after his appointment, the southern African debate, the Middle East debate and so on. They are issues with regard to which a Foreign Minister can dance the world stage and mix with, and perhaps lecture, the superpowers from the security of distance we have and the knowledge that we do not have the responsibility of a key player. In doing that, and therefore neglecting the priorities that the Government set itself for Australia's contribution towards the well-being of the region, I submit the Government should stand condemned.

Earlier this week we had the example of the Government delivering a statement on Commonwealth Day. That statement condemned the racist policies of South Africa, but failed to mention any other specific Commonwealth issue. Of course, that reflected the fact that the Commonwealth itself is very much becoming a one issue organisation. In Vancouver, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting was dominated by the South Africa issue, with each national leader attempting to outdo the last in the depth of his condemnation. As was particularly mentioned in debate earlier this week by my leader, Senator Chaney, the Opposition would have thought that that statement would have referred to Fiji. Last year, democratic government in Fiji-located in our region-was overthrown at the point of a gun and, of relevance to the Commonwealth, Fiji therefore ceased to be a member of the Commonwealth.

The Opposition would have thought that if the Government were not to exhibit distorted priorities, the statement would have dealt with such issues as Fiji. Rather, we find that the Government and the Foreign Minister tell us that Fiji is firmly in civilian hands, and they want to help Fiji return to the Commonwealth. By that statement I suggest the Government is showing the same naivety which it showed prior to and between the two coups. It is showing the same failure to read what is happening in the Pacific. Honourable senators will recall that, rather than having to pass political judgment on the new regime in Fiji, our Government changed its worldwide practice in relation to the recognition of states. That is a typical example of the Government's not being prepared to face up to an issue within our region.

If the Fijian Government is firmly in civilian hands, as Mr Hayden claims, why is Rabuka seen in military uniform at Cabinet meetings? The civilian Government of Fiji clearly exists at the pleasure of the military, which has twice shown that it will intervene to pursue sectional and racial interests, and would clearly do so again. I remind the Australian Government and the Foreign Minister, who claim that Fiji is clearly in the hands of a civilian government, that it still has no constitution. What I am saying is that Australia must face up to its relationship with that regime, but must do so on the basis of reality and not on a distortion of the facts. That is the type of priority that the Foreign Minister and the Government should address.

In relation to Indo-China and South East Asia in our region, and the earlier ham-fisted attempts of this Government to intervene, to which I referred previously, it is a matter of great regret to those of us on this side of the chamber that as a result of the discrediting of our Government in that exercise there would appear to be no substantive role that we can play in the peace process that is likely to be worked out in the near future. There may now be, for the first time, real hope for progress in Indo-China. There is reason for hope when one looks at the talks between Prince Sihanouk and Prime Minister Hun Sen; the continual reiteration of the Vietnamese that they will withdraw by 1990; and the emerging signs of change in attitude of the Soviet Union. Only today, Press reports indicate that the Soviet Union withdrawal from Pakistan has bogged down because of what is described as difficult matters. We can be sure that a Vietnamese withdrawal from Kampuchea will be as difficult to achieve. There should be a role for Australia to play in that withdrawal. But it is doubtful that Australia will have a role because our friends and allies in ASEAN simply do not trust us because of this Government's policies and practice. Mr Hayden's equidistant policy between Vietnam and ASEAN, which totally failed to appreciate the sensitivities of ASEAN's frontline states, particularly Thailand, resulted in a loss of their confidence. It will be a long time before that confidence is restored.

There are so many other critical issues on our doorstep to which this Government should give priority. Vietnam refugees travelling by boat are now being turned away from Thailand. Are we addressing the policy that Australia will adopt if there is another wave of boat people? This Government has badly let down Papua New Guinea (PNG). I remind the Senate again of the unilateral decision of this Government to cut aid to PNG so shortly after an aid package had been bilaterally negotiated and confirmed. I remind the Senate of the dismissal of the imaginative proposals of the Deputy Prime Minister, Julius Chan, to replace aid with a guaranteed trade package. I also remind the Senate of the somewhat platitudinous statement of principles that has just been entered into which is so strong on rhetoric and short on detail.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you possibly experienced the embarrassment of Prime Minister Wingti explaining that in some areas of trade development Canada has been more supportive than Australia. PNG democracy has been a great success story but I would suggest that the lesson of Fiji is that this should not be taken for granted. PNG democracy will remain fragile for a long time yet and this is another example of where our priorities should lie.

Indonesia, which was touched upon in Mr Hayden's statement, is a state of 160 million people on our doorstep about which most Australians know very little. I would suggest that this Government should be concentrating on fostering a better understanding of Indonesia, its people, languages, economy and aspirations and how we can better interrelate to that country in terms of trade, education, culture and many other ways. By doing so, this Government would be reflecting a better understanding of the real priorities that are facing Australia.

Let me refer briefly to another example-the Philippines, a country in our region strained by abject poverty, armed insurgency and entrenched human rights violations. We have a real opportunity to support Mrs Aquino in her efforts to return the Philippines to democracy and to show that we regard stability and democracy in the Philippines as important to us, important to security in the whole region and important to the security of the Western alliance. But our response was half-hearted. I have been critical in this place before of that half-hearted aid contribution that we have made to Mrs Aquino. Again, I would suggest that this attitude aptly reflects this Government's priorities which I suggest are wrong priorities.

If this Government could point to a record of achievement in our region, a record of advancing Australia's interests, of building friendships and alliances based on mutual interests, of a substantial contribution to alleviating poverty within our region as opposed to its appalling record of aid cuts, if it could point to a record that demonstrates an understanding of the significant changes that are occurring in the Pacific, the new alliances that are being formed and built-and I note the recent confirming of a formal structure in respect of the Melanesian spearhead group-perhaps we might have more respect for its attempts to leave its mark on the wider world stage.

No-one can question the coalition's abhorrence of apartheid or state entrenched inequalities in all facets of life based solely on race. I would have thought that our record in the past left that beyond any doubt. Of course, there will always be debates as to the best set of policies to influence the South African Government to take a better course, to try to find the right balance between pressure for change and inducement for change. But that is a different issue from the issue of condemning apartheid and searching for the right policy mix to influence change for the better.

As I said, our legitimacy within that debate is beyond question. We will continue, within our capacity to do so, to influence that change. But what we will not do is be totally preoccupied with South Africa so that all other priorities in relation to southern Africa suffer. We will look at the African front line states, cognisant of the critical role played by South Africa in terms of their development and their economic and political wellbeing, but not be blinkered by it. We find that so many debates in the United Nations and other forums are premised on the belief that the problem with the southern African states lies solely at the feet of South Africa. This is not so. The problems are a combination of so many things, including, in some instances, poor leadership which has the advantage of blaming South Africa for all of its regional problems, poor education, a lack of sound economic planning and implementation.

We have no doubt on this side that South Africa might contribute to a certain amount of destabilisation. I can remember when I was in Zimbabwe that one night half of the Zimbabwean air force happened to be blown up in mysterious circumstances. There is little doubt that South Africa, directly or indirectly, is contributing to the rebels in Mozambique. Nevertheless, we must go beyond that and see what can be done from within and without the southern African states to benefit them. A preoccupation with South Africa should not be used as an excuse simply to shut off all other available options. All economic development should not be stopped and I suppose, in some ways, Zimbabwe is an example of that. Regrettably, little is heard from the southern African states as to what they can do to help themselves. If we heard a little more from the leaders of such states about what they believe they could do, this would be of great assistance to Australia which supports aid and the aid debate.

It is a matter of regret to me that there was no development in this paper of any examination of the difficulties faced by such states as Mozambique. In comparison, Zimbabwe was left with a better infrastructure and a greater emphasis was put upon education of the indigenous black community when the new government came to office. The paper also should have examined Zambia, which has become too reliant upon one aspect of its economy. A worthwhile contribution to this debate by the Foreign Minister would have been an examination and comparison of these different states and, from that, we might have been able to find some way in which we could further constructively contribute. Of course, that was not the Minister's choice. Rather, he chose this opportunity to put down a paper in which he sought to condemn us rather than to be constructively helpful.

Within our resources, and subject to our world-wide priorities, it is clearly the policy of the Opposition that we should help. We should help to alleviate poverty wherever it occurs, as we were prepared to do in respect of Ethiopia, even though, in many instances, we saw the nature of the direct contribution that the Ethiopian Government made to that poverty. We have a normal humanitarian responsibility to act in this way. Within our priorities and resources we would also want to help with development aid in southern Africa. I have seen examples of this occurring. Some of the best examples have been the small ones, such as exchanges of teachers. Australian teachers have lived and worked in schools in Zimbabwe and helped to build up the educational standards of that country. They have also given us the benefit of coming back with a better understanding of the region and its problems.

There are many other ways-particularly in the non-government areas-in which we can contribute constructively, and not necessarily with high budget items. I am thinking particularly of our agricultural expertise and our land development expertise. Our drilling for water is one specific example that has been a great success story throughout Africa. I would have liked to see in this statement by the Foreign Minister an examination of the alternative ways in which we could aid and assist the southern African states rather than just simply a condemnation of South Africa and a condemnation of us for some reason that I do not understand.

On this trip the Minister also visited the Middle East. It is a matter of regret that his dealing with that issue in this paper was so superficial. It is also a matter of regret to us on this side of the chamber that Australia withdrew its helicopter force from the Sinai observer contingent where, as a nation, we were playing a constructive role in the only peace treaty that has held in the Middle East and where we were present at the wishes of both Egypt and Israel. That was a constructive, positive involvement by this country in efforts towards peace in the region. By withdrawing that force to the base at Townsville, as this Government felt necessary as part of its Fortress Australia policy, we lose a certain amount of our legitimacy to contribute constructively to the debate. When one is not prepared to help materially it is hard to make positive suggestions to which states will listen.

We in the Opposition accept that Australia will not be a principal player in the Middle East debate, but we also recognise that the Middle East is a key to stability and security of the whole world and therefore obviously we have an interest. We want a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East, one that requires resolution of the issues of the West Bank and Gaza. Israeli policy in relation to the West Bank and Gaza has clearly been one of damage control in recent years, but it seems now that the damage is getting out of control. Rather interestingly, it seems that that has occurred through the spontaneous action of rank and file Palestinians, rather than any particular leadership direction of the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) or anyone else. The tactics of industrial strikes and stone throwing are not easily countered by traditional military methods and when an attempt is made to use the military in such circumstances international anger is aroused, as has occurred in this instance.

Now that this level of protest has started I suggest that it will not be easily satisfied. One suspects that it will continue. For a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East, which we, of course, advocate and seek, a number of preconditions must be met. We have put them down in recent statements and I repeat them today, which is more than the Minister was prepared to do in his statement. First, the PLO and those neighbouring Arab states that do not recognise the state of Israel must give such unqualified recognition and they must also recognise the right of Israel, as such, to exist within secure borders. Secondly, there must be an acknowledgment of the Palestinians' right of self-determination and to a homeland. It is hard to imagine that that will occur other than in concert with Jordan, but this is not the time for that detailed debate. It is hard to imagine that such a homeland would not encompass the West Bank and Gaza.

The third precondition is the preparedness of the parties directly concerned to negotiate towards an agreement. We all know the difficulties as to who will represent whom, and again, unfortunately, there is not time for that detailed debate. As part of the wider world community, Australia can contribute through the mechanism of an international conference or, if that is not satisfactory, in some other way to bring the parties directly concerned together at the negotiating table and to give them the confidence to deal with each other. Hopefully, then one day we will also be able to contribute in supporting a peace settlement that might be reached. That is the purpose, as we see it, of these wider international methods-not to reach a solution in themselves because that can only be reached by the parties concerned, but to help bring the parties directly concerned together at the negotiating table.

Mr Hayden could have led a constructive discussion of these options but again, unfortunately, he chose not to do so. On this side, we reject the violent solutions to the Middle East problems that we have seen recently in Gaza and on the West Bank. These will not provide a long term solution. We urge both Israel and the Palestinian leadership to recognise the enormous benefits that could flow to each if they were able to make the necessary concessions towards ultimately reaching a comprehensive peace settlement. We appreciate the opportunity to put our position on important issues; we only regret that the Government did not use this opportunity to put its position-if it has one-but instead defended itself in circumstances where the political pendulum has swung even further than some of us realise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Government is quite pleased that our peripatetic Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) had such a wide-ranging tour on his last junket. But if this report represents the fruits of it--
—He is promising a few more.

—It is quite true; he does have some more coming up to the Pacific. The Government certainly has not received value for money from the Foreign Minister's report of his journey. I compliment Senator Hill on his response for the Opposition. His speech was a tour de force of the way the Foreign Minister has used this report to attack the Opposition. Perhaps he is getting fearsome at the prospect of the immediate future. But it is certainly not the right way to approach a report of his trip around the world to use it as a launching pad to attack the Opposition, which he does throughout the report. Like most Foreign Ministers in the world at the moment, he opened his statement with an attack on apartheid. It now seems to be mandatory to be part of the anti-apartheid industry. He explained away his gift of $100m from Australia to the front line states. He then moved on to the Middle East and followed in the penumbra of Mr Shultz. He seemed to enjoy basking in some of that reflected glory. I think he had his eyes opened when he saw the enormity of the problem there but, as Senator Hill has said, he did not offer any solutions; he wants Israel to negotiate on the Palestinian issue. He also wants Iraq and Iran to negotiate. I will deal with this matter later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister then moved on to a whistlestop tour of South East Asia and came home to slam the Opposition on its foreign policy, which I think is entirely unwarranted. To open his report with an attack on South Africa was entirely predictable. Like most of the anti-apartheid industry people, he is maddened and blinded by the policies of apartheid. I am sure that if these people came up with some suggestions as to what the South Africans should do about the enormous multi-racial and multi-national problem they have, the South Africans would be quite happy to listen. And if the suggestions were practicable or realistic, I am sure they would be welcomed and implemented. The policy being followed will foment revolution, insurrection and bloodshed over there. There is nothing more certain than that. If the policy is not changed, that will happen.

I remember on one of my trips over there I ran into Chief Jongilanga. He was the education Minister in one of the homelands called the Ciskei. I asked him what was the thing that he found most offensive about the apartheid policy. He said, `Integration; we have to have integration; it is the most important thing'. I said to him, `That is a very big step. Perhaps you could get the ball rolling. Right next door to you people are three-quarters of a million Indians. How about you integrate with them and get it all started?'. He said, `Oh, no, no, we must integrate with the white man'. So I just kept looking at him until he realised the enormity of what he had said and he just burst into laughter and said, `Don't worry about it. The white man will fix it'.

Mr Hayden has taken just a superficial look. He does not realise the relationship that exists between those front line states and South Africa. He does not realise how dependent they are on each other and how these front line states have one voice for the world stage and another one when they are talking at home. South Africa helps them with the management of their ports and the control of their diseases. Many diseases have got out of control to a large extent since the independence of these nations. The tsetse fly, the rindepest and malaria are all running wilder than before. South Africa helps them with their weights and measures and the training of their civil servants. A lot of the workers who come in from those countries, particularly Mozambique, are paid three-quarters of their wages in gold so that their countries have some gold with which to run themselves. For example, Zimbabwe is landlocked and has to do all its exporting through South Africa.

I am surprised to hear that the South Africans may have had some complicity in blowing up most of the Zimbabwean air force. I am surprised to hear that South Africa is maintaining rebel raids into Mozambique. I thought it was rather the other way round and that the African National Congress had bases in Mozambique and were raiding South Africa. I have not been to South Africa for some years, but I find it surprising that South Africa would deliberately destabilise Mozambique. There is no need to destabilise it very much because it is under a communist regime, which I am sure is responsible for a lot of these problems. This is not recognised in Mr Hayden's report. He says it is all due to drought and famine. But that is not so; it is due to bad organisation. It did not have droughts and famines before. Lourenco Marques, as it was, was one of the tourist ports of the world. But now it is derelict, as is the country, and the people are in desperate straits. But one can hardly blame South Africa for that and one certainly cannot blame apartheid for it.

Suggestions from the Minister for the removal or reduction of apartheid would have been very welcome if he had taken the trouble to have a deeper look at it all. As has been said later in his report he talked about China and said that we have to have a delicate diplomatic relationship with that country. If one switched the name of China for South Africa, one would see the duplicity of the attitude of this Government to the two countries.

Returning to the South African scene, there are six or seven nations of blacks. The Zulus outnumber the others. There are the Xhosa, the Venda, the North and South Sotho, the Swazi and the Tswana. They all speak different languages and they cannot speak to each other or understand each other. I do not know how one can expect to run a democracy in a country with a lot of people who cannot understand each other. Some of them can speak their own language and English or their own language and Afrikaans; but there is no common language for them all. Altogether there would be about 25 million Bantu; Bantu simply means the people, but they are all different peoples. Of that 25 million, half of them are still tribal people.

I think that the women will take a great role in the elevation of the black nations. They have adapted a lot better than the men have to an economic mentality and a cash economy. They have realised the importance of education for their children; some of them even go without food for that education. I do not think we give enough credit to the people of South Africa, white and black, for getting to work on their own problems and sorting them out. Standing outside and just calling for revolution will not solve the problem.

We had a big debate here yesterday about the Sharpeville six. These are mentioned in this report and Mr Hayden says that they were innocent people plucked from a crowd and that they are to be executed after a summary trial, for electoral purposes to show that the South African Government has not gone soft on the black people.
