That is entirely wrong; I made that point yesterday. These people were the leaders in the crowd that was attacking the mayor of the town. As was said here yesterday, the first guy threw the first stone which knocked the mayor on the head and knocked him down. The second guy wrestled him on the ground and took away his revolver with which he was trying to defend himself. The next guy poured petrol on him. The girl who was there slapped the face of the lady who was saying, `Please, please, stop this riot', grabbed a placard and started bashing the man. The next guy poured petrol on him. The next guy lit him and then burned the house down. These people were involved intimately. In deciding on the murder, all the judge was saying that he could not decide on was which one had actually killed the man. So they are all going to suffer. That is the way it is in South Africa.

In South Africa the first law is the security of the state. Anybody who threatens it has to suffer the consequences. They do not live under Western law as we do; they live under Roman law, and people should understand that. One of the things that people do not realise about the blacks is the religious problem. Many of them are what one would call bread and butter Christians. When the Catholics are there one day saying, `Here is health education, welfare and spiritual guidance', they say, `Yes, boss, we Catholics'. The next month when the Protestants are there offering the same thing, they say, `Yes, boss, we Protestants'. But all the time they are Moslems because Islam suits them very well. Polygamy particularly suits them. An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth suits them.

People complain about the fact that workers there have to go miles to work in the mines and are not allowed to take their families with them. It would overstrain every facility if the workers took five wives and 30 children around the country with them. They just cannot afford to do that sort of thing. I do not want to go into that fully; we need to take a bigger and deeper look at this problem. South Africa has a good relationship with the countries around it. When the front line states speak to the rest of the world, they speak with another tongue. I think a lot of countries are hiding their own problems by blaming a lot of things on apartheid.

The Minister moved on to the Middle East, had a look at the Iran-Iraq war and said, `These two countries had better get to negotiating quickly'. That really is a superficial way to look at the problem which has been there for centuries-for millenia. If two sides to an argument both think they can win, there can be no negotiation. It is hopeless to say that Iraq and Iran have to start negotiating. Of course, a similar situation exists between the Israelis and the Palestinians. The solution suggested by Mr Hayden talks about independence for Israel, independence for the Palestinians and their own land here and there. If apartheid were included, the same solution as is being offered to Israel and Palestine would be offered. So no help was offered there at all.

I do not want to go on with this except to say that this is a very predictable statement after a superficial run round the world. The statement opened with the mandatory comments about South Africa and apartheid and went on to deal with the Middle East. It offered nothing. I might mention the $100m aid to Mozambique for drought and famine relief. Plenty of drought and famine relief is required in Australia. Some areas have had one drought after another. Our farmers in those areas are not bad farmers and they are not crippled because of a downturn in world prices. They are crippled by drought, and drought alone. They could use a bit of help, but that is not forthcoming from this Government. They are not asking for handouts; probably they are just asking for an extension of time to pay back their loans.

The statement represents a sad result to a long trip. I know that the Foreign Minister said that he intends to travel through Association of South East Asian Nations countries and hopes to maintain Australia's position in the Pacific. I think that we have a good position in the Pacific. The Minister said that the ANZUS Treaty was in good shape. However, we do not actually have one any more. We have a treaty with the United States and another one with New Zealand. The Minister talked about the nuclear free zone in the South Pacific, which is a zone unable to be policed. He attacked the Opposition for its attitude to that. The statement represents a superficial report of a big junket which has not done the country a lot of good, and I do not think that it was worth the money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senators Hill and Sheil that the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) is a very thin and superficial document. It is virtually his travel diary with an occasional remark-not always very perceptive-inserted into the travel diary. His only other approach seems to be `When in doubt, attack the Opposition, whether relevant or not'. That does not seem to be a very useful performance from a Minister reporting to Parliament on his overseas tour and the conduct of our foreign affairs, for which he is responsible to this Parliament. This particular Minister seems to be all over the place in more ways than one. He has just visited Mauritius, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Kenya, the Yemen Arab Republic, Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Israel, the Maldives, Singapore and Indonesia. Next month he is to visit Japan, Korea, Hong Kong and the Philippines. Later in the year he will go to Japan again, China and the Association of South East Asian Nations countries. If we are to have a Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade doing this and, presumably, not administering his Department while he is doing so, why do we have ambassadors? Why are we constantly denigrating our ambassadors who could do this job? It is not helped by the appearance of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade dashing in, making a few flippant comments and dashing out again. We want to get a proper administrative structure. I do not believe that we will get it under this peripatetic Foreign Minister. He is a very dangerous man.

SPEECH.PARA: The maxim that Mr Hayden seems to be following is that now he has lost sight of his objectives, he must redouble his efforts. He is redoubling his efforts all right, but his purpose, direction and coherence are totally lacking. He seems to have a most peculiar hang-up about South Africa. The Government even managed to insert into a Commonwealth Day message a few days ago a vilification of South Africa. What is extraordinary is not that it criticises South Africa-it deserves criticism-but why there is so much on that particular country and that particular system and so little on others that are almost equally abhorrent. I must make it clear that I believe that apartheid is an absolute outrage in human affairs. My problem is, the nature of the Afrikaners being what it is, I cannot see how South Africa could possibly have a peaceful transition from apartheid to a system where there is accepted dignity and equality on the basis of race, ability and politics. I just do not see how it could happen because of the nature of the Afrikaners. I would like to think that had I been a black South African I would have been a revolutionary. I would not mind too much where my submachine gun came from-whether it was a Russian one, a Western one or an Israeli one, I would want one-because there is no way in which there will be a peaceful transition to a fair and equitable system in South Africa.

The problem is that if one looks to the models in Africa to which perhaps South Africa might be changed, would it be a better and fairer system than the totally unfair system it has now? Since decolonisation, the performance of African countries has been deplorable in terms of peace, prosperity and stability. Twenty-nine of the 52 countries of Africa were poorer in 1986 than they were in 1960. Africa has the highest illiteracy rate-75 per cent-in the world and the shortest life expectation, 47 years. Twenty-eight of the 52 countries of Africa are classified as impoverished. It is customary, although I think most misleading, to blame the colonial legacy for this. Certainly there was much that was bad and divisive in the colonial system. Nevertheless, in nearly all the colonies of Africa, they were left a system of ports, roads, railways and schools which gave them a chance to have something to build on. But because of the political system-the approach they have adopted-nearly all of those have been wasted away.

Let us take one country-Zaire, the former Belgian Congo. In 1960 it had 85,000 miles of reasonable roads. Now, after 25 years of Marxist rule, it has 12,000 miles of usable roads. The figure has gone from 85,000 to 12,000 in 25 years of Marxist rule. The level of political stability has been very unsatisfactory. Since 1958 there have been 20 major wars in Africa and 42 coups. Half of the world's 10 million refugees are in Africa. What has been happening, for reasons that one could argue about, is that nearly all African countries have adopted a socialist Marxist approach to their problems which has proved an utter disaster. In Africa at the moment 50 to 55 per cent of the people work for the government. Since 1960 employment by the state has increased by 160 per cent, but agricultural productivity has declined by between 20 and 25 per cent. Most of the countries have chosen the wrong path to peace, good government and prosperity. I would like to look at two countries that chose different paths-Tanzania and Kenya. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from a World Bank report. I have shown it to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Kenya and Tanzania became independent, decolonised, at roughly the same time-1961 for Tanzania and 1963 for Kenya. They have similar populations and, roughly, a similar climate and geography. However, each chose a different path politically and economically. The results have been very dramatic. If we look at the geography of Tanzania and Kenya, we see that Tanzania has one of the highest averages of arable land per person in the world, whereas Kenya is desert and semi-arid. The government system adopted by Tanzania was a one-party socialist state. Kenya adopted a capitalist economy, although it has been a one-party state, a capitalist state, since 1982. Tanzania, disastrously, nationalised land and introduced collective farms. Between 5 million and 6 million people were forced onto collective farms, which was a total disaster. They are now dribbling back into their previous farms and occupations. Kenya privatised land.

SPEECH.PARA: In every other area the comparison of two countries of equal potential is a dramatic example of what happens if the wrong political path is chosen. The table I incorporated in Hansard showed the social and basic economic indicators. In every respect Kenya is doing incomparably better than Tanzania which was once held up as the ideal of an African socialist state. Kenya is doing better in everything-infant mortality and the child death rate, the number of physicians and nurses, and primary and secondary school attendance. In every respect now Kenya is way ahead of Tanzania. The gross domestic product of Kenya has been growing twice as fast as that of Tanzania. Agricultural production has been growing more than three times as fast in Kenya. The inflation rate in Kenya is half that in Tanzania. I make these points because when we are asked for aid we have to be clear on what sort of aid we are giving. In many cases we are propping up thoroughly incompetent, wrongly directed governments. We should be working to get those governments and their systems functioning properly so that they can look after themselves.

Some countries in Africa-not many, but some-are going reasonably well. I mentioned Kenya before. Ivory Coast, a small country with a population of 9.5 million, has done extremely well. Cameroon is also working successfully. Malawi, a country with almost no resources, which has privatised its activities, decentralised its government and removed the dead hand of government, is prospering. In Senegal, there have been five scrupulously fair elections since 1963. That is a country which deserves our admiration. The final success of Africa is Botswana, a country which, by the way, has been much pilloried but which has had an extraordinary success rate with a growth in gross domestic product of 11 per cent a year since independence in 1966.

We must recognise that the problems of Africa are not, as we seem to be told, the result of the old colonial history. It was a factor, but not much. Those countries have had plenty of time to sort themselves out since then. In fact, in most cases the colonial powers left these countries with a fairly good infrastructure. The problems do not result primarily from drought, although drought does affect these countries. The reason that drought affects these countries so badly is that their governments and farming systems are in such a shocking state. The problems do not arise primarily because of South Africa, although the activities of South Africa in Mozambique and Angola are extremely destabilising for those two countries. They are very comparable to, for the same reasons, the activities of Israel in the Lebanon. They are an attempt to try to root out or suppress potential terrorist groups operating from outside their borders. Such South African activities are destabilising but, on the other hand, South Africa does give a great deal of economic support to the so-called front line states. I think that on balance the activities of South Africa are helping more than hindering the other countries of Africa.

If the problems do not result primarily from things such as drought, the colonial legacy and South Africa, what are they a result of? The dominant reason is the political system-the governmental and administrative system-that these countries have adopted. Our greatest assistance to them-I do not think it would be easy to do-would be to persuade them that they must adopt a more open, freer and more efficient society. They will then not need the aid they now need. Much of our aid at the moment is going to prop up inefficient governments. We have to help people in this world who are starving. But what we must also do at the same time is try to get their governments to organise things so that they will not continue to need the aid.

The only other point I wish to deal with concerns the remarks of the Foreign Minister in regard to Israel and the Palestinians. We are not a direct party to this but we have 60,000 Jews in Australia, most of whom have a deep feeling for Israel and we have something over 100,000 Moslems in Australia, many of whom also are bound up in the same problems. What we must do if we are urging solutions-as we do from time to time-is recognise that we cannot invite Israel to commit suicide. No country can possibly contemplate any action which would involve its suicide or which it might reasonably think would do so. We have to look at the security of Israel. Israel has an enormously powerful, almost unquestioning, ally in the United States. Nevertheless, Israel is a tiny country and one has to take into account its genuine security problems when looking at any possible solutions.

I think that we must press for two things to be done simultaneously if our influence is to be effective. One is that the Arab states, and the Palestinians in particular, must give an undertaking that they will accept and respect the right of Israel to exist. That includes refraining from any terrorist attacks or comparable things that make life unbearable in a small country. Simultaneously, in fairness, the Israelis must accept that the Palestinians on the West Bank of the Jordan and in Gaza have a right, as they claim for themselves, to self-determination. Ultimately, whatever mechanism is produced, the problem will have to be solved by face to face negotiations between the representatives of the Israelis and the Palestinians. I do not think it is sensible or appropriate for either side to attempt to veto who those representatives should be. Once we start saying that people will not be acceptable because they are former terrorists or control terrorist operations, the ranks on both sides will be substantially thinned. That is not appropriate when negotiating. The point is that such people must be representatives. I think that point should be made very clearly.

A final point and, in many respects the most difficult, is that somehow the Israelis have to sort out the rights of the Palestinians who lived in Israel but fled in the various wars-most of them in the first war in 1948-and who are now not allowed to return to their homes. That is a very difficult problem because their homes have been expropriated. I believe that they have a right to return or, if they wish, to have compensation in place of a right to return. This will be very difficult to negotiate. I think that we have to look at this whole problem. It is not our problem; it is not a problem to which we are a principal party. However, if we are asked for advice we want to give sensible advice that is fair to both sides in an immensely complex problem. That is all I wish to say about the issues.

The Foreign Minister has given us a sort of Cook's tour of his mind which would have been of absorbing interest but for the abysmal darkness that seems to exist there. He has not told us anything. All he has done is give us a narrative of his tour. Unfortunately, it has been a very superficial and occasionally flippant account of his visit. I think that this Parliament has a right to a better report on foreign affairs from the Foreign Minister responsible to this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the views put by my eloquent colleagues in describing the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) as shallow, superficial, lacking any depth or any sensitive insight into the events referred to in it. At the outset I would like to refer to the first part of the ministerial statement in which the Foreign Minister referred to apartheid. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In Lusaka, I attended the first meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Committee which was set up by the Vancouver Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in order to bring about Commonwealth action to hasten the end of apartheid.

By any measure that statement is breathtaking in its arrogance, in the simple assumption that sanctions inevitably, certainly and absolutely will bring an end to apartheid. Of course, there are those people who take quite a different view. In so doing, they take a quite proper view. I always find it interesting to see that those who plead the cause of sanctions are invariably people who are both isolated and insulated from the effects of those sanctions. They are isolated from the economic, political and, of course, the inevitable social effects of those sanctions. I can only imagine that it is their subliminal guilt that causes them to be absolutely stunningly silent on the devastating effect of sanctions on those whom it is intended to help.

As long as the United States of America, Great Britain, West Germany and Japan, just to name four countries, are not prepared to accept the imposition of serious and substantial sanctions, we can be certain that our efforts, at best, will be a token gesture of alleged righteous indignation. I suppose there is no more absurd example of that than the Government's decision to terminate landing rights in Australia for South African Airways. That action has done nothing except increase the passenger load of Qantas Airways Ltd planes flying into Zimbabwe. Of course, the Government understands, though it is silent on it, that 90 per cent of passengers flying from Australia to Harare are travelling to South Africa. They disembark in Harare and promptly fly into Johannesburg with airlines operated by the black African nations or, alternatively, they take a flight operated by South African airlines which travels regularly between the so-called front line states and South Africa itself.

The Australian Government's action does absolutely nothing other than considerably inconveniencing South Africans and Australians. Of course, the reason that one is able to fly regularly between the so-called front line states and South Africa is that those nations are very much dependent on South Africa for their economic survival. In fact, the economies of those countries are deeply integrated with the economy of South Africa. If sanctions are to prevail, if they are to work, if they are to have a significant effect upon the economy of South Africa, of course it is inevitable that that will have devastating effects on the economies of the front line nations. The survival of those economies is dependent upon the strength, vitality and virility of the South African economy. Another aspect is the millions of dollars that flow from the people of front line nations working in South Africa back to their homelands; they repatriate a significant part of their salaries back to their homelands. If sanctions have the desired effect, the first thing that will happen is that those people will find themselves on the unemployment list, on the scrap heap, and they will be repatriated back to their own countries without money and without hope. That will further plunge those nations into economic chaos.
One cannot help noting the comments that are made by Mr Hayden about apartheid in his statement. In a very subjective, emotional and bigoted way he states:
Apartheid is the most deplorable example possible of the infringement of fundamental human rights. Unlike the Opposition, the Government will not tolerate compromise over this great moral imperative.

To me that is a classic example of the subjective and arrogant nature of the Australian Labor Party, and in recent days that arrogance has plunged it into the political chaos in which it now finds itself. The arrogance of the Government is absolutely breathtaking. The Government suggests that anyone who does not agree with sanctions must support apartheid.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your position?
—I am opposed to sanctions and I am opposed to apartheid.
—How are you going to change it?

—So far sanctions have not prevailed and there is no indication that they will. However, if they do prevail, it will certainly plunge into economic chaos those people in South Africa whom we are seeking to relieve of the economic, social and political disadvantages of apartheid. They will be the first people hurt.
—But they want the sanctions; they are asking for them; they are demanding them.

—Senator Maguire says that they are asking for sanctions. Public opinion polls that have been conducted by international bodies among black South Africans, both employed and unemployed, show that more than 70 per cent of those people are opposed to sanctions. They understand that, basically because they are the least skilled, they will be the first to lose their jobs. Of course, that will have a devastating effect upon their capacity and ability to sustain themselves and their large families. It is not without significance that, without exception, the front line states utter private support for sanctions, but they conspire with South Africa to maintain the strength of their economic links with that country. So, while on the one hand they publicly and in principle support sanctions, they are not prepared to contribute to the imposition of sanctions. Those governments, whether they be dictatorships-by and large they are-or, with exceptions, democracies, would come under enormous pressure from their own people in view of the economic consequences of such an action.

SPEECH.PARA: For me the sad thing about this debate is the obsessive subjective bitterness that prevails upon those of us who have a view that sanctions will be debilitating and non-productive in achieving the objectives which presumably all of us in this chamber would wish to see achieved. I judge the debate on South Africa and apartheid to be perhaps the most intellectually barren debate that has been conducted in this Parliament in the eight years that I have been a member of it. We are all agreed that we are opposed to apartheid. What we are not agreed on is how to overcome the problem. The great debate that rages in this chamber is about method. We all accept the disease; we simply argue about the medicine to combat the disease. It seems that if anybody in a logical, objective, intellectual way puts the proposition that sanctions will not help, that they will only hinder, it is immediately assumed by those who have a different view that that person supports sanctions. By any measure that assumption is barren on intellect and reeks of arrogance. It seems to me that people who make that assumption do not have the will or the capacity to debate logically the implications of such a proposition.

Some time ago I was moved to say that it is all right for Archbishop Tutu to call for sanctions, but those honourable senators who have driven through the area where he lives will have detected the mansion in which he resides, which by any measure would be recognised in Australia as an exclusive residence. He is insulated from the effects of his call for sanctions. He has the privilege of knowing that at the end of the day he will still be the Archbishop. The same cannot be said of the poor souls who kneel in his church with heads bowed and who will starve and whose families will starve if the call that he makes prevails. I have yet to hear an intelligent proposition put in this chamber about overcoming the problems of the millions who will starve, be dislocated and deprived if the effects of sanctions are to prevail, as would be the wish of this Government.

It is a great pity that this Government is not prepared to apply itself in a more constructive way. We have to ask about the Government's object or purpose when we learn that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in this Government has never met the South African Ambassador. So much for dialogue and communicating one's point of view. So much for persuasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not going to change their view, though, are they?

—We can only ever hope. I would have thought that there would be something to be said, if we are relying on world opinion to persuade South Africa, for acknowledging those steps, modest as we in our country might think them, that have taken place in South Africa in moving towards dismantling apartheid, whether it be the mixed marriage Act, the carrying of cards or the dismantling of apartheid in public transport and in shops, restaurants and hotels-the sorts of things we take for granted. Perhaps that is why we are blind to the significance of them to those people in South Africa who have lived without them all their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are prepared to acknowledge that South Africa has moved towards dismantling apartheid and, in some part, has responded to world opinion, there is some hope and prospect that it will take a further step. But because there is a democracy among the whites, the Government of South Africa has to be always mindful of its own constituents. I cannot imagine any altruistic issue which would cause our Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to so legislate that it would cause him to lose government-with his knowing that he would do so. He is quite capable of legislating to lose government without knowing it. But we are asking the South African Government to lose government on an issue. Perhaps there is something to be said for being there to fight another day, in as much as a government can move only as fast as, or marginally faster than, its electorate will allow.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only a minority electorate.

—Of course that is true. In terms of those who vote it is a minority electorate. But the truth is that for the time being those people are the economic heart and political soul of that country. They are the people who will decide in the short to medium term whether apartheid prevails in South Africa. They are the people we have to appeal to. There are people in South Africa who, for whatever reason, are not happy with the movement of that Government, who see that the response of the rest of the world is to show more rigidity, demonstrating to South Africa that it is more isolated than it was at the beginning of the day, and who will simply go back into the laager and assume that their efforts are in vain. Perhaps the answer for this Government is more dialogue with South Africa and recognition of the steps it has taken, while being prepared to condemn it publicly for the steps it has not yet taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move on in a general sense to some other matters raised by Mr Hayden in his statement. This Government has taken great credit for its level of compassion and its concern for the underprivileged, whether at home or away. Let us not forget that it was Mr Hawke and Mr Hayden who presided over the most severe cuts in Australia's aid program since World War II. In the five years of the Hawke Government, the annual aid budget has been slashed progressively to its lowest level in 25 years. Our aid is now a mere 0.36 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). That figure means that Australia, for the first time, will have slipped below the international average for donor countries of aid. Our aid is only marginally above half that recommended by the United Nations of 0.7 per cent of GDP.

Yet it was Mr Hawke who drafted the 1982 statement in the platform of that year. He promised an immediate target of 0.5 per cent of GDP by 1985. Although aid was given in 1984-85 up to 0.5 per cent of GDP, the Hawke Government since has presided over real cuts of 4.8 per cent in 1985-86, a massive 12.4 per cent in 1986-87 and 3.4 per cent in 1987-88. Of course, as we all know and as has been the subject of considerable debate in this Parliament, aid to Papua New Guinea (PNG) has been cut back dramatically in 1987-88 to levels below that of 1983-84. Expenditure has been cut back from just over $325m in 1986-87 to $300.9m in 1987-88. The decision to cut back aid to PNG is inconsistent with the recent decision of Mr Hayden to give $100m to the so-called African front line states. On the one hand, while we are cutting back by about $25m to PNG we can find $100m to give to these front line states.

It is interesting how we have made that commitment just prior to Mr Hayden's visiting Mozambique. There is an Australian missionary, Ian Grey, there who, from the information I have, by any measure is thoroughly innocent of any act. He is in gaol and was to go to trial without a lawyer. Mr Hayden, with his cheque book in his pocket, could not even get to say hello to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —He simply passed by on the other side.

—That is right. He could not even get to see him. Mr Hayden tells us about human rights abuses in South Africa. He should have spent more time in Mozambique looking at its economy and its economic and political structure. Budget Paper No. 4 tells us that a major initiative in southern Africa will commence in 1987-88 and, at the same time, that aid for the South Pacific region has been cut back from $69.7m in 1986-87 to $68.2m in 1987-88. This is the last year of the five-year arrangement in which Australia pledged $300m for development assistance to the South Pacific region. The nature of future aid arrangements for the region is still to be considered. We can only speculate as to what that might be.

SPEECH.PARA: Tragically for all of us, the Hawke Government has taken the South Pacific region for granted. It is time we started concentrating on acting like a regional partner. There must be a reorientation of Australia's aid program in the South Pacific. We have spent something like $400m in the last decade in the Pacific islands without any marked improvement in their economies or social conditions. I cannot help but notice what the public accounts committee of the Western Samoan Parliament had to say. It has recently described our gift of a patrol boat to the country as a burden as it would use more fuel in one year than the entire country's police force. Of course, this patrol boat is one of a number that have been given to the South Pacific islands and in one case we know that they tried to send them back, but a little political muscle put a stop to that. They are not wanted, they cannot be manned adequately and effectively and, of course, these countries simply cannot afford them. But we are telling these countries-and we are good at this-what is good for them, and they are finding that they have to accept our gifts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that not built in Perth?
—I thought it was subsequently built in Queensland. Am I wrong?
—No, it was not.
—I think it was built in Queensland. There was a great deal of contention about the boat. The honourable senator might remember that a tender was accepted from a plan sight unseen.
—I thought they were being built in Cockburn Sound.

—Not that group, if my memory serves me correctly. This statement has nothing of substance in it. It does not express a definitive point of view. It is simply a catalogue of trivia as to the places the Minister travelled to. Rather than being a statesmanlike and objective document it is simply an opportunity for the Government to seek to score cheap political points in a very inadequate way. If this document is to be the fruit of Mr Hayden's visits, we can only despair for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not normally rise to speak on a matter of this kind but, having received a copy of the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) in the other place during the luncheon period-there was no luncheon break today, it being Thursday; there was not even any lunch available today, as I recall-I really feel that I must record a few views about it. As Senator Hill, who opened the debate on this matter from our side of the House, said, it is really hard to know quite what to make of this statement by a man who, after all, is the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Commonwealth of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have read this document in full. It runs to 20 pages, and there is nothing in it. There is a recitation of where Mr Hayden has been and, as Senator Hill again very tellingly said, there is a tirade of abuse-I think it is fair to describe it as no more than abuse-of certain views in the foreign affairs area put forward particularly by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and, most notably, in Mr Howard's recent speech in Hobart. It is a deplorable document for a ministerial statement purporting to describe what the Minister then effects to portray as a series of important and significant discussions in 13 separate countries conducted recently during his visits to them.

As Senator Crichton-Browne has very properly pointed out, the document contains what has now apparently become the ritual breast-beating on the Government's part about South Africa. I should say that that is not confined to the Government. Yesterday the Senate was held up for a couple of hours by a process of that kind initiated by the Australian Democrats and there is no party more active than the Democrats when it comes to breast-beating. On the first page of the statement we have in that regard some stuff of a totally imprecise kind about sanctions and how the Government is concerned about them. But it is not explained in Mr Hayden's statement what exactly the Australian Government's initiative-which he refers to in three or four paragraphs-is meant to do or what effect it is likely to have. The only conclusion to which one is led is that this study, which is what this Government contributed to this great matter when in Lusaka, `will provide better understanding of possibilities for financial sanctions against the apartheid regime'. Bully for you, Bill. Mr Hayden goes on to say:
Australia will continue to contribute to this study, which will be considered at a future meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers.

It is rather like a Canberra inter-departmental committee. One study leads to another. What are we really supposed to obtain from all that verbal posturing? There is a further instance of a rather different technique on page 9 of the statement. There is a reference to a matter which was actually the subject of considerable discussion here yesterday-the matter I have already referred to initiated by the Australian Democrats-of the unhappy case, to use no stronger words, of the six black people in South Africa who are under sentence of death there. This is what the Minister for Foreign Affairs has to say about that matter on page 9 of his statement:
Six people not directly involved in a violent incident are about to be hanged . . .

I leave aside entirely, because it is not the subject we are debating this afternoon, the question of the appropriateness or otherwise of those matters. That was debated at great length yesterday afternoon and I have no more to say about it; but I have something to say about the presentation of that matter by Australia's Minister for Foreign Affairs. He says:
Six people not directly involved in a violent incident . . .

What a total travesty of the truth. Yet this is set down in a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. One would think from that statement that these people were not even present. As I have said, I do not want to continue on that subject. I raise it only to draw attention to the total misrepresentation of the truth by our Minister for Foreign Affairs and to underline the point made earlier by Senator Crichton-Browne about the extent to which discussions of these matters have gone on in this country today where a Minister of the Crown can put himself in a position like that on a matter of such seriousness and gravity.

The Minister refers in passing to the situation in Mozambique, one of the so-called front line black African states. On page 2 of his statement he describes briefly the terrible position in that country-it is a terrible position-a position made the more terrible by drought and by the continuing state of insurrection. At no point does the Minister for Foreign Affairs refer to the fact that that country is under the control of, not a Marxist regime, but a communist regime. Let us call these spades spades. I hope that honourable senators will not think that a pun is intended in that usage. But the leader of the Government in Mozambique, Mr Machel, was well known as one of the most violent black African leaders in that unfortunate and unhappy continent. According to a statement put down today in another place by our own Minister for Foreign Affairs, one would think that we are describing a respectable government in whose interests our heartstrings should be plucked.

While I feel great sympathy for the unfortunate people of Mozambique, I feel no sympathy whatsoever for the administration of that country and the tyrants who are in charge of its affairs. For Australia, through the instrument of Mr Hayden, to be announcing during the course of his visit to southern Africa a foreign aid program amounting to $100m over the next three years is shameful in view of the kind of regimes to which that money will be directed.

It is interesting and I think significant that in discussing Mr Hayden's visit to Mozambique as such on pages 2 and 3 of his statement he at no stage refers to the tragic case of Mr Grey, which was also referred to earlier by Senator Crichton-Browne. It is true that Mr Grey's case is mentioned later, on page 8 of the statement, but only by way of what the Minister for Foreign Affairs is pleased to call, `the Opposition's tacky philosophy (as shown in its statement on the Grey case in Mozambique)'. Mr Hayden goes on to describe that philosophy as one whereby `humanitarian aid should be used as a tool of political pressure'. However, we are not talking about humanitarian aid but, rather, aid to a front line African state which, directly or indirectly, will be used by that state to maintain its present levels of armed pressure upon its own citizens, as well as to maintain its covert and overt activities against the neighbouring country of South Africa. Leaving aside that total misdescription of what we are talking about, one would at least have hoped that where the life of an Australian citizen is concerned, Mr Hayden would not have thought it appropriate to describe even the use of humanitarian aid in an attempt to save a life as being a tacky philosophy.

Later in the statement the Minister for Foreign Affairs said that in the course of other discussions in Mauritius, Kenya, and Zimbabwe in particular, he and his officials identified agricultural development and minerals exploitation and processing in those countries as areas of great interest and commercial potential in which Australia could be of assistance to those countries. A few paragraphs later on page 4, Mr Hayden said:
My Department for instance, will be extending such assistance to exporters in Zimbabwe to help them promote their products in Australia.

We have an interesting situation whereby the Government's policies towards land use-a matter that was discussed in the Senate earlier today, yesterday and the day before during the debate on the heritage legislation-include closing down Australia and denying land use to miners, timber workers, farmers and others. Yet despite those policies it is about to embark upon a process of assisting agricultural development and minerals exploitation in those African countries. I very much hope that in the course of that process our Government will not undertake any rape or pillage of the environment in those countries--

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope they do not find any uranium.

—I very much agree with Senator Sheil in hoping that they do not find any uranium. Already our uranium industry has lost sufficient ground because of the activities of governments in this country, particularly the Whitlam Labor Government as well as the present Government. We do not want any more handicaps or competition in that field.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that on page 5 of the statement there is one paragraph in which honesty breaks through. Mr Hayden concedes, `Australia's influence on regional political events is naturally limited'. That is a most remarkably uncharacteristic touch of modesty from any representative of this Government. However, having made that concession, I have to say that further into his statement the Minister rather quickly forgot that restriction. On page 7 he said:

Striking the right balance, judging the trade-offs costs in competing national priorities, deploying scarce government resources in the maximum national benefit: these are complex, connected strands in our diplomacy which have to be pursued with subtlety as well as energy if we are to protect and preserve Australia's vital interests.

That is rather redolent of Paul Keating talking about the way he is playing monetary politics like an organ these days. Is there no limit to immodesty by Ministers of this Government? What pomposity there is contained in such a paragraph. On the same aspect I turn to page 17 of the Minister's statement where he talks about the nuclear disarmament process, a matter in which for some time now the Government has attempted to strut the international stage, but in which it has no place at all, and about which nobody takes the slightest notice of it despite its having spent a great deal of money on it for five years now. However, in passing, I notice that that particular section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is now in the process of being cut back; not nearly enough to size, but to at least something like half of its previous magnitude. The Minister said:
That Australian Government has done all it can to facilitate this process-
that is, the process of multilateral nuclear disarmament-
in multilateral forums such as the UN General Assembly, Security Council and the Conference on Disarmament.

I suppose, taken quite literally, it is true that the Government has done all it can. However, the truth of the matter is that the Government cannot do anything. As it has done nothing, it has therefore done all it can. So, literally that is a factually accurate statement. Mr Hayden said further:
We have actively encouraged the process which has produced the INF Treaty, the first treaty actually to reduce the number of nuclear weapons.

I am well aware that everyone in this chamber greatly welcomes that treaty, although perhaps it is not nearly as much the answer to all our prayers as some would have us believe. Nevertheless, it is very much to be welcomed. What does our Minister for Foreign Affairs say about it? He said, `We have actively encouraged the process'. Well, one can only say that if that is the full sum and achievement of our efforts it does not say much for the millions of dollars that we have spent in the process of maintaining a separate ambassador for peace and disarmament and having a major section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade directed simply to regurgitating or reshaping pieces of paper produced elsewhere in the world.

As my reference a moment ago to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, as the Department is now called, indicates, it is now, of course, appropriate for the Minister to refer not merely to foreign affairs issues but to trade issues. On page 14 of his statement the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade waxes somewhat eloquent on the significant results, as he sees them, of the policies of this Government in achieving significant growth in exports, particularly to countries within our region. The paper contains a set of statistics as to the rate of growth of exports. These statistics relate to China, Japan, Korea and the Association of South East Asian Nations during the period 1983-84 to 1986-87, compared in each case with the period 1975-76 to 1982-83.

Despite all this, our balance of payments situation today continues to be in a fearsome mess. Indeed, it would be in an even greater mess were it not for the fact that our international terms of trade have improved by something like 7 per cent in the course of the current financial year. But for that development, our balance of payments deficit this year would be even worse than it was last year. We have a situation where our net international debt reached $86.77 billion at the end of last December and is still rising quite fast and where, of course, the cost of servicing that debt is rising commensurately.

I suggest that before representatives of this Government, including the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, start boasting about the success, if that is what it is, of our export performance, they should have a look at the bottom line, which is the balance of payments deficit. There are two sides to the merchandise trade account. One is exports and the other is imports. Of course, the current account deficit also contains not merely merchandise trade but trade on services and the net deficit on property income and other income.

There is an important statement in this document. On page 19, the Minister speaks of the increasing complexity of his task and his Department's task-and I would not necessarily want to reject that view. But in supporting it, the Minister says something which I think is perhaps more significant than he has realised. He says:
Issues have created themselves: human rights, for example, and its impact on the doctrine of national sovereignty and the domestic affairs of multicultural countries such as Australia.
We should think about that paragraph. Mr Hayden goes on to say:
There is not a conflict between states or an infringement of human rights anywhere in the world that does not resonate in some ethnic community in Australia.

I think that is true. I think it is profoundly true. What I think it suggests is that this Government should begin to think very hard about the policies of so-called multiculturalism to which it and, indeed, its predecessor Government have committed this country, and the longer term consequences of many of the divisive aspects of those policies. This is not the place to pursue that line of thought, but I want to put it on the record in this place that I think those two paragraphs in this statement represent almost the only passages in it which generate thought. I can only say that I rather doubt whether, in putting them down, the Minister realised quite what thoughts they might generate.

Finally, I come to the heart of this statement. The heart of it is, as Senator Robert Hill quite properly stated in the opening remarks of his speech on this statement, the attack that it contains on the Leader of the Opposition. On page 15 the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade refers to a speech made by Mr Howard-I think in New York but it may have been Washington-in 1986. In that speech the Leader of the Opposition made some perfectly proper and accurate remarks about the economic performance of this country under the Hawke-Keating Government, or perhaps we should now say the Keating-Hawke Government. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has seen fit to say that to make remarks of that kind while overseas is a shameful and unpatriotic act. I think it was Samuel Johnson who said that the appeal to patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is indeed that scoundrelly approach which has been adopted in that remark by our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

On page 19 of his statement the Minister, with that penchant for the well chosen phrase for which he is renowned, says that Mr Howard's recent Hobart speech `is redolent of this abject and lickspittle mind-set'. I do not have any objection to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade criticising Mr Howard's speech. It is perfectly proper for him to do so; he is perfectly entitled to do so. However, if I may say so, it would have been preferable for him to do so in rather less vulgar language than that and on the basis of reasoned argument and not merely the abuse which is contained in that phrase. The piece de resistance in this area with which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade concludes his remarks is the following statement:
The Opposition clearly has no pride in this country . . .

This comes from a Minister in a government which has done more to foster the growth of the guilt industry in this country than any other entity in Australia. Not so long ago our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), at a time when he was still talking about the off the top of the head idea that he voiced in Alice Springs about the compact-or was it a treaty or form of words?-with Aboriginal Australians, spoke in the House of Representatives about the shame which we should all feel in this country.

We have had a whole industry built up among members of our academic fraternity, prominent among whom is the husband of Senator Reynolds. I do not think we should blame Senator Reynolds for her husband, but it happens to be the case that Professor Reynolds was one of the leaders of the pack which set upon one of our most distinguished Australians, Professor Geoffrey Blainey, a couple of years ago when Professor Blainey had the courage to raise the immigration question in this country. That question has become a great deal more topical since and will become more topical in the days to come. In the course of doing so, Professor Reynolds and his colleagues gave a tremendous boost to the guilt industry in Australia, to how Australians should feel ashamed of themselves for their performance and achievements-that is my word, not his-over the past 200 years. For the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to tell us that the Opposition clearly has no pride in this country was a fitting note on which to end a speech as lacking in substance and as hollow in rhetoric as his was.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

There are several reports within this paper relating to the Australian Capital Territory: the annual reports of the Consumer Affairs Council, the Consumer Affairs Bureau, the Administration of the Credit Ordinance and the Administration of the Sale of Motor Vehicle Ordinance. I specifically wish to refer to the Administration of the Credit Ordinance, which came into being, I think, in 1985 and was subsequently amended. It is one aspect of the amendment which is causing difficulty, not just to the industry but also to people who seek to borrow money. One of the requirements of the 1987 amendment was that any transaction had to be witnessed by people who were not in any way associated with those who were borrowing money. Of course, it meant that employees of a financial institution could not act as witnesses; it meant, in theory, that others who were clients of the same financial institution could not act as witnesses.

I think it has been agreed by the Australian Finance Conference, its members and everybody concerned that this has been ill thought through and that it is not operating as people intended-that is, to provide greater protection for those borrowing. I believe that it is generally agreed that it needs to be amended so that it can operate in a way which is less restrictive for all parties concerned, particularly borrowers and those who want access to loans in a way which is convenient to them. So far, there has been no response from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in producing an amendment. The Credit Amendment Ordinance No. 4 of 1986 amended the original ordinance in relation to the signature of documents. The Finance Conference wrote to the Minister for Territories on 12 February 1987 pointing out in considerable detail the difficulties that were being experienced with the new section which came in in 1986, which required that the signature be witnessed and that the witnesses should sign as witnesses. That section adds:
A person signing on behalf of the debtor shall expressly state in writing that he or she does so by authority of the debtor.

It is quite clear what was intended: people were attempting to intervene to ensure that borrowers had an opportunity to be sure of what they were doing. I do not think any of us would disagree with the concept. But as I said it has turned out to be inconvenient not only for those lending money but also for those seeking to borrow. The provision requiring the independence of a witness means that members of a financial institution, whose number may be vast, are ruled out as being a witness to a document for a person seeking to borrow.

I ask the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) to give this matter his attention. This report refers to the changes, the objectives and what has gone on. I would not be critical of what is contained in the report but this is an aspect of it which has emerged and which has been brought to the attention of the Department and the Minister. I suggest that an amendment to the Ordinance should be dealt with quickly in consultation with the industry so that the present situation can be relieved and the business of borrowing and lending can proceed in a way which does not cause as much inconvenience to all parties as is the case, at present.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a document of about 170 pages entitled Local Government Initiatives: A Strategic Approach. There are some 52 recommendations contained in the document. It deals with a number of questions that I think most of us have considered for a period-that is, how best to deal with all the organisations and persons who are interested in ensuring, in this time of fairly high unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, local employment initiatives. I think the Senate would agree that one of the major problems that is not being faced up to at present when consideration is given to unemployment statistics is just where the unemployment is and amongst whom it is most significant. If we look at the figures we see that in the country districts both unemployment and youth unemployment are high.

This paper attempts to solve one aspect of the problem-that is, local employment initiatives. It deserves to be read by all honourable senators because in the time which I have I would not do it justice if I sought to go through all of the points. But in passing I mention that it goes into some schemes and initiatives that have been undertaken internationally, such as the Mondragon experiment, which of course is no longer an experiment but a very successful operation, in the Basque district of Spain. I take the opportunity to mention this since the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, is in the chamber and I know he knows about this matter.

We know of a person in Tasmania who has $80,000 to give away for a local employment initiative. One of the problems is that, while the bureaucrats realise that this is unique, it is so much so that they do not know how to handle it. Normally people go along to them and say, `We want a loan for this, that and the other thing to set up this particular employment program'. Here we have a man-a consulting engineer and a successful building surveyor-who is a public spirited gentleman, motivated by Christian social principles who wants to give away $80,000. All he asks is that both State and Federal governments match that so as to establish a manufacturing plant for youth, hopefully in the Huon district.

As I have said, the people in the Public Service just cannot handle that. There is no guideline into which that sort of thing fits. It is a unique situation. I am sure that my friend and colleague from Tasmania, Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, also appreciates this. It is important to deal with this matter as a unique matter. In addition to all of those Commonwealth and State funded projects that are available to any entrepreneur, if matching funds could be given by Federal and State governments in a case such as this, where a person is prepared to put in money with no strings attached provided that it goes to a properly determined local employment initiative, it could well be that other people with money to spare would follow such an example. I just raise that in the expectation that that will assist Senator Tate to do something.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY BUSH FIRE COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The 1986-87 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Bush Fire Council is a most comprehensive document which deals with the activities of the Council. It indicates that staff attended 98 fires during this period. Of course, the Council has several employed firemen, but they are predominantly volunteers. It has 200 volunteers on its books and it provides a very valuable service to this community. Of course, there is a lot of rural area in the Australian Capital Territory which is subject to bushfires and, as I have indicated, they do occur. I want to refer specifically to the item on page 5 under the heading `Vehicles, Plant and Equipment'. Under the signature of the Chairman, Mr Val Jeffery, the report states:

A major replacement programme for firefighting apparatus has not been possible as the capital expenditure allocation has always been insufficient. As new items become available the displaced older equipment has traditionally been issued to Volunteer Brigades to cover the areas not manned by paid personnel. As a result about 25 per cent of the major fire suppression fleet is now over 20 years old. The cost involved in maintaining safe and efficient equipment is increasing dramatically as the fleet ages and labour costs increase.

I suggest to the Senate that it is important that proper equipment be available for firefighting in the rugged areas that the men have to go into. It is important that adequate funds be made available for a proper replacement program. It is very easy-this is not the first case where we have seen this-to cut back on maintenance and replacement programs when money is short. I can understand that. But, in the end, it really is false economy and one is not then able to provide the service as well as if the equipment had been properly maintained.

It would be a pity if the activities of the Bush Fire Council were impeded by reason of its not having equipment of the necessary standard. I am not suggesting that everything be thrown out and replaced. But, when we are warned in this report that a major portion of the fleet is over 20 years old, we need to take notice of it and not just let this report pass through the Senate. We need to make sure that proper arrangements are made for the funding of real maintenance and real replacement as it is necessary.
On page 7, under the heading `Publicity', there is one sentence which may not mean a lot to some honourable senators here. It says:
Alexander Bunyip has been adopted as Council's mascot and was seen at many public events.
