DEBATE.TITLE: DIPLOMATIC AND CONSULAR PRIVILEGES AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will amend both the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1967 and the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 which give legislative effect to the provisions of the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations and the 1963 Vienna Convention on Consular Relations respectively.

The Bill provides that tax imposed under any of the various sales tax Acts is not payable in respect of goods intended for the official use, and not resale, of a diplomatic mission or consular post of a prescribed overseas country provided the goods are purchased from a registered sales taxpayer.

These amendments have become necessary due to increasing criticism which Australia has received in relation to our interpretation of particular provisions of the two Vienna conventions. Under those conventions the personnel at foreign missions and posts are exempt from direct taxes but must pay indirect taxes of a kind which are normally incorporated in the price of goods or services.

The Government has consistently maintained that the Australian sales tax system is, due to its manner of operation, an indirect tax and as such is payable by foreign missions and posts. However, the Government also takes the view that the sales tax and value added tax systems operated by the United States of America and certain Western European countries are direct taxes from which Australian personnel are exempt. This interpretation has been disputed and on a number of occasions other countries have sought to collect sales and value added tax not only from Australian personnel but also from missions and posts. In order to maintain our exemption overseas it may therefore be necessary while maintaining our interpretation of the conventions to grant certain countries exemption from Australian sales tax in respect of their official purchases.

At the present time it is not possible to accurately determine the financial impact of these amendments. However, it is the Government's intention that a foreign state will only be proclaimed a prescribed overseas country where Australia is receiving a reciprocal exemption from sales or value added tax and where the cost of providing sales tax exemption in Australia is outweighed by the financial benefits of such reciprocal exemption. Therefore, the Bill is not expected to have an adverse effect on government finances.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (SHARE INCREASE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up an increase in its capital subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Honourable senators will be aware that the main activity of the bank, which was established in 1947, is lending to developing countries.

In 1984 IBRD governors agreed to implement a $US7 billion special capital increase. Capital increases allow the bank to expend its borrowing on the world capital markets and it is these borrowings which largely finance the bank's activities.

Under this special capital increase, Australia was entitled to subscribe to an additional 745 shares. In addition, Australia received a further allocation of 70 shares under the first phase of a related supplementary share allocation designed to allow countries which had suffered a fall in their relative voting power under the special capital increase to maintain their proportionate share of capital stock.
Australia has subscribed to these additional shares, and payment authorised under the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Act 1986 commenced in December 1986.

In May 1986, governors approved a resolution authorising a further share allocation in the final phase of the supplementary share allocation. Australia was one of the countries affected by this resolution.
The text of the resolution, including the number of shares to which affected members are entitled to subscribe, is included in the explanatory memorandum to this legislation.

Australia voted in favour of the resolution authorising the final phase of the supplementary share allocation. Members, including Australia, are entitled, but not obliged, to subscribe to this authorised increase. Even though most of the concerned members are developing countries they have indicated their willingness to take up in total about two-thirds of the authorised increase of 1,528 shares. Australia is entitled to subscribe to 178 shares.

Under this capital increase, 8.75 per cent ($US1.88m) of the subscriptions is to be paid-in and the other 91.25 per cent is to remain on call. Of the paid-in portion, 10 per cent ($US0.19m) has to be in the form of gold or United States dollars, while the balance ($US1.69m) can be in Australian dollars. This $US1.69m can be paid by means of a promissory note which is drawn down over a period of about 4 years.

The initial 10 per cent cash payment would be made by 1 September 1988. Subject to agreement with the Bank, the promissory note would be encashed in eight equal biannual instalments of $US0.21m over the four financial years commencing 1988-89.

In 1986, following the adoption of a revised standard of value for bank capital, maintenance of value payments were reintroduced by the bank. These payments have the effect of adjusting the value of national currency subscriptions to bank capital to allow for long run changes in the relative value of national currencies and the United States dollar.

Maintenance of value obligations are calculated annually based on amounts outstanding on national currency subscriptions. A promissory note denominated in Australian dollars would attract significant maintenance of value payments by Australia. It is therefore proposed to utilise a United States dollars promissory note which would not be subject to maintenance of value.

The callable portion of Australia's subscription to the supplementary share allocation (91.25 per cent valued at $US19.59m), which acts as security for the bank's borrowing, is most unlikely to be called. No calls have ever been made on this part of bank capital.

The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries, and it plays an important role in the South East Asian region. This has been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the bank's establishment.

Up to the end of June 1987, the bank had lent about $US120 billion to its member countries. This money was largely borrowed from international financial markets. The cost to taxpayers in member countries in terms of paid in capital subscriptions was only $US7.2 billion.

Projects financed covered all the major sectors of economic development with an emphasis on infrastructure facilities in the transport and communications, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. The World Bank and its soft loan arm, the International Development Association, have a comprehensive and systematic project evaluation system which shows that most bank and IDA projects-85 per cent of those evaluated in 1986, for instance,-achieve all or most of their objectives. The estimated average return on projects evaluated in calendar years 1985 and 1986, measured by the flow of net economic benefits over time, was 14.8 per cent.

Australia's membership of the IBRD brings substantial commercial benefits. On a cumulative basis Australia has received more from procurement by the IBRD including IDA than it has given in contributions to the bank and IDA.
I believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue its policy of support of the IBRD by taking up, in full, the increase in our capital subscription to which we are entitled.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators, and I now present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DUTY FREE SHOPPING FACILITIES: KINGSFORD-SMITH AIRPORT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Senator Puplick:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to raise what is yet another example of the Government's maladministration of the tendering process. The matter arises in relation to the duty free concession which operates at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith international terminal. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that some years ago a tender was awarded under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act for the operation of a duty free shop at Kingsford-Smith airport. The successful tenderer on that occasion was a foreign firm by the name of Allders International Pty Ltd. It was successful on the basis of a tender which was awarded after tender invitation No. N668 which closed on 30 August 1983. The lease authority, which was an appendix to the tender document, said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth its officers servants and agents shall not be answerable to the Concessionaire for any loss of profit or diminution in business resulting from any relocation extension or redesign of the airport or the terminal building . . .

Subsequently it was decided that the duty free shop at the airport should be relocated. The concessionaire, Allders, approached the Government and said that, under those circumstances, it believed it was entitled to some compensation. The report before us, which was prepared by Mr A. F. Rainbird, a Deputy Secretary of the then Department of Aviation, records that what Allders said to the Government was:
Allders suggested that this compensation-
that is, compensation for the relocation of the shop-

would take the form of either relief from concession rent during the period of disruption; or a period of extension to the contract to enable the concessionaire to recoup revenues lost during the period of disruption.

In the event, the period of disruption was zero. The shop was moved and relocated overnight. Nevertheless, the Government proceeded to give Allders a two-year extension to its contract without calling any competitive tenders. Mr Rainbird at page 8 reports:

The Australian Government Solicitor's office advised on 2 June on the question of the Commonwealth liability for payment of compensation if Allders was prevented from trading from premises covered by its existing lease.

I wrote to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) and asked him for a copy of the advice received from the Australian Government Solicitor and indicated that I was making a Freedom of Information Act request. The Minister wrote back and told me that I was not entitled to have the document. Under this Government, freedom of information is a fairly delicate flower; it is constantly abused. However, the Minister did indicate one extract from that advice from the Australian Government Solicitor which is in the following terms:
My view-
presumably, the Australian Government's Solicitor's view-
is that should the Authority, in effect, prevent Allders from trading from the demised premises then some compensation could be claimed and might well be payable.

The facts of the matter are simply these: Allders won a contract according to a tender document which clearly indicated that the Commonwealth was not liable for any loss if there was to be a relocation, extension or redesign of the airport. Allders was asked to move. It moved. It suffered no loss because it moved overnight and resumed trading the following day. Nevertheless, without calling tenders, and I believe in breach of the provisions of the Airports (Business Concessions) Act, the Minister or his Department granted a two-year extension of the contract to Allders-an extremely valuable commercial resource. It is true that Australia has the best duty free shopping in the world. An article by Gareth Powell in the Sydney Morning Herald in 1986 indicated:
And some of the best duty-free bargains in Australia are to be found in Sydney.
Most of the credit for this splendid state of affairs lies with Sterling Nicholas Duty-Free-
which pioneered off-airport duty shopping. I agree with that. Yet, the same year, in an article in the Daily Telegraph, we were told:
Incoming travellers buying duty-free alcohol and cigarettes at Sydney Airport pay up to 90 per cent more than they would at similar shops in the city.

So it cannot even be claimed that the Sydney airport concessionaires are providing the best service at the minimum cost. I am concerned about the way in which this matter has been handled. It is another example of the cavalier approach which this Government takes to the very important process of government tendering. A contract was let which I believe should not have been let. I believe that the Minister should be required to give a far greater explanation to the Parliament and to the disadvantaged concessionaires than has been given. I believe that this is quite clearly an example of continuing problems with government tenders and specifically the maladministration within the Minister's Department-like the Amann affair-and any number of examples one cares to bring to mind at the moment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 March, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We move now to an entirely different debate from the previous one. The report of the Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia is very interesting and extremely informative. It deals with the folklife of Australia which includes things such as children's games, rhymes, family sayings, old yarns, tunes, stories, songs, poems, birthday and marriage customs, popular superstitions, old recipes, craft skills, dancing, Christmas ceremonies and all other parts of the living cultural tradition of Australia. It is an excellent report and I very much commend the authors for it. For instance, it contains something that I have never seen before-the original words written by Banjo Paterson to Waltzing Matilda. These words, in fact, are not well known and, if one tries to sing them, are virtually incomprehensible, given the current music. Nevertheless, the report brings forward several important recommendations. I refer in particular to the recommendation in regard to the conservation of folk art in Australia. I think that this is worthy of very considerable and favourable examination. However, I must say that I profoundly disagree with the main thrust of the recommendations of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Folk traditions cannot be institutionalised in the way in which many arts and art forms can be institutionalised. Folk traditions have a natural and organic quality. Occasionally, they die out. Indeed, part of the process of the renewal of folklife and folk art is the occasional dying out of traditions. I believe that they should not be required to be incorporated into some false system of preservation in a way which in fact no longer renders them truly folk in their character. We cannot preserve folk traditions by institutionalising them in the way in which I think this report basically suggests. Equally I do not believe that one can teach folklife in the way in which this report suggests in chapter 4. It is something one is either born into or is brought up with by one's parents and grandparents, community leaders, community elders and community peers. It is not something which is capable of being taught in the way in which this report discusses the teaching of folklife.

I think the report also is slightly deficient in three areas. One concerns the integration of folklife in to the broader stream of Australian cultural and artistic activity. Secondly, the report fails to discuss the nexus between the folk traditions of Europe and Asia and the folk traditions of the Aboriginal people-although I concede that that was not central to its terms of reference in its charter. Thirdly, as in many such reports it is slightly dismissive of what one might describe as the Anglo-Celtic folk traditions. For instance, there is a great deal in the report about recipes and food and all the rest of it, but no mention of roast beef and Yorkshire pudding as if they do not constitute as much of a folk tradition in many ways that the more ethnic foods are described as doing. I refer also in this respect to Morris dancing or the traditional English Christmas carols and customs which are just as much part of a folk tradition as those which come from other parts of Europe. In that respect I find the report somewhat disappointing.

As I said, there are a number of specific recommendations in the report. Time does not permit me to go into many of them but there is one with which, again, I indicate my significant disagreement. I refer to the recommendation that the National Film and Sound Archive review its priorities with a view to placing greater emphasis on documentary records of Australian life. I do not believe that the primary responsibility of the National Film and Sound Archive is for documentary preservation in that sense. Our film heritage and our sound recordings are at the stage that they need much more urgent attention in respect of preservation than some of the documentary material in the possession of that archive.

Nevertheless, having said that I fundamentally disagree with the thrust of the report and in particular, the institutionalisation of folklife and teaching of folklife-the institutional, financial and bureaucratic solutions which are profferred in the report-I believe that it is a valuable resource document. It is an extremely good work of both scholarship and investigation. It deserves careful reading and understanding. I believe that it puts before those of us who are particularly interested in arts policy and matters of our cultural heritage some very significant issues which need to be addressed. It has some very significant discussions of important parts of Australian life, particularly those which are relevant to communities maintaining some degree of original or folk identity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

DEBATE.TITLE: MILK AUTHORITY OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

When one reads the 1986-87 annual report of the Milk Authority of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), one finds that it is signed by Stuart F. Wilcox, Chairman of that Authority. One will find on looking further into the report that Mr Wilcox was:
. . . reappointed for a three years term commencing 20 March 1987 . . .

However, the fact is that today as we consider this matter, he is no longer the Chairman of the Milk Authority. In my opinion that is a matter which requires some comment. I think it is also necessary to thank him for the work that he did while he was on the Authority and from the time he was appointed Chairman in 1981. All Canberrans will know that during the time he was Chairman the price of milk in Canberra was significantly lower than in places surrounding the ACT. That is something that we have been very grateful for indeed. I think that we owe him a great debt for the work he did as Chairman.

The reason that he is no longer the Chairman of the Milk Authority arises from an incident that occurred during the last election. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) claimed considerable credit in a television advertisement for the contracts negotiated between the milk producers in his area and the Milk Authority. This was done in a way that made it look as though somehow he had some particular influence with the Authority and that he had achieved all that. The Chairman of the Milk Authority, in my opinion quite properly, made a statement denying that there had been any such interference and claiming that the Authority was independent and had acted quite properly.

It was quite obvious to everyone who knew the then Minister for Territories that this would get the Chairman of the Milk Authority into considerable trouble. In the end, prior to the Chairman being dismissed by the Minister, he tendered his resignation. The position became vacant on 2 October. It was an incident that ought not to have occurred. He was quite properly explaining the Authority's position on a matter he ought to have been explaining. In doing so, he ought not to have run foul of the Labor Minister. As I have indicated, it was not surprising to many of us that having placed the matter on the record this would in fact result. It was to the loss of the community here that Mr Wilcox is, as a consequence, no longer chairman of the Milk Authority. Other people have been appointed to the Authority. Ms Rosemary Follett was appointed in November 1986. As stated in the report, she is an officer of the Commonwealth Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. She is also President of the ACT branch of the Australian Labor Party. One might wonder which of her occupations was the most influential in her being appointed to this position.

This sort of situation has arisen before in Canberra. In October 1987 the terms of two members of the Canberra Theatre Trust expired, quite properly. One of them was Mrs Elinor Grassby and the other was Ms Libby Smith. As was stated in the Canberra Times of 25 October 1987, Ms Smith was a long time and tireless worker for the performing arts in Canberra. Interestingly enough, Mrs Grassby's term on the Trust was renewed. Ms Smith received a short note from the Minister, as others have done, which indicated that she was not to be reappointed and, presumably, that her services were to be terminated. Having consideration for her qualifications for the job and the expertise that she brought to it, the two appointments that were made to the Trust were very surprising. She was replaced on the Canberra Theatre Trust by Mrs Ingrid Murphy. So, the sorts of things that happened in Canberra under the ministerial responsibility of the former Minister, not the present Minister, made the incident that occurred with the Milk Authority regrettable but expected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Patterson.
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling of the annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation provides me with an opportunity to speak about research in Australia in general and the CSIRO in particular. Honourable senators should be aware that the CSIRO has been operating on a succession of reduced budgets in real terms over the past 10 years; also that chiefs of divisions in the CSIRO have been encouraged to increase the external sources of their funding, and that that has implications for the research being undertaken by the CSIRO. The funding for the divisions of the CSIRO has also been redistributed away from rural research to manufacturing and information technology research. These factors are seriously affecting Australia's ability to be first in the field of scientific developments and, in particular, in developments in agriculture and the rural area.

SPEECH.PARA: Funding of the CSIRO, unlike many other areas of government expenditure, has the potential for financial return. A recent example given by Dr Peacock of the CSIRO-by the way, he was the recent winner of the 1988 Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd award for the Pursuit of Excellence in Science-is the development of a new variety of cotton called siokra. The breeding program cost $2m to $3m over the past 10 years and has netted the Australian economy $45m in the past year. It is estimated that this financial year that figure will be significantly larger. That is one example of how such expenditure can reap large gains.

I wish to add my concerns to those of some of the senior research staff in the CSIRO about the perception which prevails in some government quarters that continued investment in agricultural research is likely to be of little benefit to the Australia economy. I wish to take this opportunity also to express my concern at the current climate of an emphasis in our research institutions, including the CSIRO, on applied rather than pure research. I acknowledge the value of external funding to research institutions, but I wish to highlight the concomitant and inherent danger or risk of an overemphasis on applied as opposed to pure research-an emphasis on short term goals and outcomes at the expense of long term goals and outcomes.

I conclude my remarks by congratulating the staff of the CSIRO on its achievements during the 1986-87 period, despite a reduced budget in real terms. As is indicated in the annual report, the divisions in the CSIRO are to be restructured. As we all know, restructuring of this nature and of such a magnitude is disruptive to the research endeavours of the staff in the Organisation. It is very wearisome for one to be torn away from research to pay attention to the minutia of administration. I strongly concur with the statement of Dr Peacock of the CSIRO which was quoted in the recent article of Mr Grahame O'Neill in the Future Age entitled `Australian Scientist: Excellence in Adversity'. That statement reads:
If we stifle opportunities to carry out longer term research, we condemn Australia to a second class future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Patterson, I have some concerns about the research priorities of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Even if we appreciate that the budget allocated to the CSIRO is similar to that of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-we could perhaps put it in terms of 8c a day-we still need to be sure that the programs, priorities and the administration of the CSIRO are very effective. The report that has been tabled, which bears the signature of the Chairman of the CSIRO, Neville Wran, QC, states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is vital not only that CSIRO operates at maximum effectiveness but that it gets its research priorities right.
Further on in his report Mr Wran states:

There will be tighter monitoring of research to maximise its economic or social value to the Australian community, while maintaining the scientific excellence for which CSIRO has a world-wide reputation.

I am concerned that in that tightening and monitoring process we should not lose sight of long term objectives and that we should not lose sight of those industries which have come to depend for their very future on the work of the CSIRO, which has been so excellent in the past. For example, in the Northern Territory funding for rural research undertaken by the CSIRO has just been slashed very heavily. Research into tropical horticulture has been totally reviewed and is to be downgraded, replaced and changed about. This action is very short-sighted and out of kilter with our expectations for our economic future and the relationships that we hope to have, particularly with the Asian markets in the area of grains and grain crop development. The Northern Territory Grain Growers Association has expressed very serious reservations about the course that the CSIRO is taking. The Association has entered into discussions and correspondence with the CSIRO. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter written by the Northern Territory Grain Growers Association and the reply from a Dr E. F. Henzell of the CSIRO.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
NT GRAIN GROWERS ASSOCIATION
Dr E. F. Henzell
Director
Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures
CSIRO
Brisbane
Dear Ted,
I wish to express my concern at recent remarks made by yourself on the ABC Country Hour program of Thursday, 4th February, 1988.
In the course of the interview you linked the question of the viability of the Grain Growers to your organisation's decision to withdraw from the Northern Territory.
Such statements, coming from yourself-an acknowledged expert in the field, has had a dramatic effect upon my members and their commercial suppliers, particularly financiers.

As you partially acknowledge in the interview, the reasons for the CSIRO withdrawal from the North have very little to do with the probable financial future of the grain industry, and I quote ``. . . its' just that we can't justify a continuing effort unless we see more commercial development. These days CSIRO has to be hard nosed like the rest of the community where it spends its money''.
The future of the grain industry is only being assessed this year, and I believe it is not possible to make any definite statements on viability, as you have done, until that analysis is complete.
Your remarks, while reflecting your concerns for the future, were quite unfounded, detrimental to our industry and damaging to the credibility of individual farmers.
I hereby request your clarification of the CSIRO withdrawal and a retraction of your comments regarding the viability of the grain growing industry.
Yours sincerely,
JOHN VIDLER
President
PO Box 225, Dickson, ACT 2602
Telephone (062) 48 4211
Telex AA 62003
Facsimile (062) 47 3832
CSIRO
Institute of Plant Production and Processing
Limestone Avenue, Canberra, ACT
Director
E F Henzell
DGT:PR
Mr John Vidler
President
NT Grain Growers Association
PMB 55
WINNELLIE NT 5789
Dear John

Thank you for your letter of 11 February 1988 about the remarks I made on the ABC Country Hour program on 4 February concerning the decision to phase out grain crop research in the Northern Territory by the Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures.
You ask for clarification and for a retraction of my ``comments regarding the viability of the grain growing industry''.

First, I wish to make it quite clear that I do not question the viability of the existing grain growing industry in the Northern Territory. There is a significant, though small, industry meeting the important needs of the local market. My concern is that there is little scope for expansion through exports. This is an aspect that I am sure has engaged your Association for some time, and I am also sure that you have been disconcerted by the heavy production and delivery costs removing the competitive edge on the export market.

For CSIRO to justify continuation of its grain research into the 1990s, it would have to see good prospects for a much bigger industry than there is now. Quite frankly, we think it will be extremely difficult for Northern Territory farmers to make a good profit from exporting grains such as maize and sorghum. I hope for Australia's sake that we are wrong.

The reason why I was forced to phase down the grain research and other work was simply one of economics. During the last few years, Government funding for the Division's work has declined steadily, and the prognostications are that the Divisional appropriation budget will be further reduced between now and 1990. The lead-time required to cease rural research activities without waste is inevitably long, and unless I took action when I did, the Division would be in increasing difficulty over the next three years. The cuts I initiated before transferring to Canberra will be felt throughout the Division, in Queensland as well as in the Northern Territory.

I trust that this clarification will help your Association to understand my position. Again, I wish to make it quite clear that I continue to support a grain industry to supply the local market in the Northern Territory. My views on that have not changed since the AD 2000 discussion.
