TALK.START.PARA: —These letters highlight the fact that the Northern Territory Grain Growers Association is relying heavily on the continuation of the research projects, particularly those being undertaken into tropical horticulture in northern Australia. In his reply to the letter from the Northern Territory Grain Growers Association, Dr Henzell said:

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why I was forced to phase down the grain research and other work was simply one of economics.

It is disgraceful that that is the way in which research projects have had to be approached. I foreshadow some questions that I would like the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to address very seriously, in particular about the CSIRO. If the answers to these questions are not forthcoming before the Senate examines the Budget Estimates, I will certainly pursue them at that time. For example, what was the basis of the decision to close down the Tropical Crops and Pastures Division of the CSIRO? What degree of consultation has taken place with the industry and the relevant government departments over the closure? What alternatives were looked at? What arrangements are in place to ensure that the Northern Territory continues to have access to CSIRO crop research? Was any consideration given to transferring equivalent resources to other CSIRO divisions working in the north of Australia? How does the CSIRO address research into adjustment issues faced by rural industries generally and the Northern Territory specifically? How has the CSIRO extended the results of its research into agricultural industries? Has it been done in a manner that has permitted the timely adoption of new technologies with integrated farming management practices?

I believe that these issues have to be addressed very seriously. Looking at the scant resources applied in northern Australia by the Government, let alone the CSIRO, the fact that the CSIRO has been forced by economic issues to pull back and rein in on this area makes me very suspicious of the motives. It is certainly one area where we must put the CSIRO under the microscope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be well and truly noted in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation report, which is before us today, that the cuts that have been made in the CSIRO budget in the environmental, scientific and mining sectors are very worrying to everyone. I think they are rather short-sighted, to say the least. I think Senator Tambling has already made some mention of that. I do not think this Government has taken into account the valuable work that sections of the CSIRO have done. There is virtually nowhere else in Australia that research work can be done of the nature and magnitude of that done by the CSIRO. Its work in areas such as blowfly control, pesticides, the effect of chemicals on the environment and animals and parasite control-not to mention its research into environmental issues such as ozone depletion and the weather pattern-is of enormous to the rural sector. If works such as this do not continue Australia will fall well behind in rural production at a time when we have a great need for rural production to make sure that our balance of payments is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: This annual report paints a very rosy picture for the CSIRO and its various divisions but it marks the fall in morale that has occurred with the cutbacks and with the political appointment of Neville Wran as the Chairman. I think this appointment was a particularly inappropriate one, given that Mr Wran has no background in things scientific and there is no previous evidence of his interest in such work. Neither did he, as a Queen's Counsel, have any particular expertise or flair in the business world. So his appointment must be seen for what it was-a retirement bonus for an old Premier. I doubt whether the incoming National-Liberal Party government will provide a similar position for Barrie Unsworth when the election in New South Wales is won by the coalition on Saturday. However, it is interesting to note that the Australian newspaper this morning showed a large photograph of Mr Wran, the CSIRO Chairman. The article states:
Mr Neville Wran came to Canberra yesterday to blow the CSIRO's trumpet.
Instead, he was persuaded to wax lyrical about other subjects including jobs for the boys . . .
As far as jobs for the boys are concerned that is a very well known subject in Canberra at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he said they were right into it, too.

—They are right into it, too. He also mentioned that the Australian Labor Party would have trouble losing the election on Saturday because of the redistribution that he put through. Of course, he has also waxed lyrical about that over time. But at least he is sticking to the things he knows about, which are jobs for the boys. He would not even make a good public relations officer for the CSIRO when he comes to Canberra as he talks about politics rather than about the CSIRO.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, the report gives Mr Wran little space and it is probably just as well that that has happened. The report talks about the new challenges and the bright prospects for the CSIRO but, with some subtlety, it gives an inkling of the anguish present when the Chief Executive says, `The year has been a particularly difficult one for me'. I suspect that that statement is something short of the full story.

Of course, the trend in the CSIRO is to become more industry and profit oriented. I have already alluded to what is happening to research in the rural sectors. I can accept that statement but I am concerned that because the rural research projects are not as commercially viable as others, such as robots for car manufacturing plants, these other projects will take precedence. My concern is shared by research scientists and people in the rural industries. I think the Government has engaged in penny pinching. Even its own Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, bleated loud and long about how appallingly the CSIRO had fared in budget cutbacks. The people in rural Australia are concerned. If the Federal Government does not pay more attention to the functions of the CSIRO the annual report next year will say nothing; it will just refer to a few challenges ahead of us. It might well say how the CSIRO has been forced to close down.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO GRAIN STORAGE, HANDLING AND TRANSPORT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Chaney.
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pointed out last night that the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport is probably the most important royal commission we have had into the agricultural industry for quite a number of years. I will point out briefly again the proposed savings that the Commission found on the handling and transport of grain. The figure for New South Wales was $10 per tonne; Queensland, $15 per tonne; South Australia, $6.50 per tonne; Victoria, $11 per tonne with perhaps another $1.50 per tonne if we can clean up the disputes on the Australian waterfront and another $2 per tonne if we get foreign ships to stop treating Australia as a war zone when they are loading grain. Those savings are stretched across a broad Australian base. I am taking Australia's grain production of wheat, oats, barley, et cetera to be about 22 million tonnes, so a saving of $15 per tonne represents an immediate saving of $330m for the agricultural areas of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this came about because of something that we on the western side of the continent have always known and about which we have always told various governments: we need deregulation of our transport along with deregulation of the bulk handling authorities. In that part of Western Australia where grain transport was deregulated in that transport was not limited to rail but was opened up to road transport tendering, we got an immediate drop of 20 per cent on grain freight rates.

The Commission has also recommended that we deregulate the grain handling authorities. In all six States the handling authorities have had sole rights up to date. In fact, in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, the State governments own the handling authority installations so that is an added burden in terms of regulation. The Royal Commission recommended that the governments in those three States get rid of the bulk handling authorities to some private concern or to co-operatives, as is the case in other States. That will not be the end of those handling authorities because even though they will be deregulated, they will be in a far better position to compete in the market for the handling and storage of grain as the installations are already there and paid for. So there will be no worries on that score. Of course, certain co-operatives in Western Australia, South Australia, and probably Tasmania-I am not quite sure of it-own the bulk handling authorities. In a lot of places, given time, many of these co-operatives turn into dictatorships as is the case with the Western Australian handling authority. No doubt it will start shooting from the hip immediately that it should retain control.

We have got to the stage with this Royal Commission where a lot of recommendations have been made and we have been shown lots of places where costs can be saved and money remitted to growers or not taken from growers at all in the first place. It is one thing to find out what is wrong and another thing to recommend what can be done, but, of course, the most important and final thing is to implement the findings of the Royal Commission. My strong message to the Government and the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is that, the Royal Commission having sat for two years and having cost a vast amount of money, the Government should appoint a person responsible, perhaps Mr McColl himself, for seeing the recommendations through to fruition and satisfactorily overcoming the problems that have existed in grain handling, transport and storage for many years throughout Australia. I recommend to the Government that it do exactly that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport has been awaited by everyone for a long time. The Royal Commission has uncovered some major shortcomings in the present system of grain handling. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the most part, the current system of grain distribution does not meet the criteria of economic efficiency, cost effectiveness and integration, the three assessment criteria provided in the Commission's terms of reference.

As a wheat grower myself I am aware that quite considerable costs are associated with the handling of grain. I could quote for example industry charges for a wheat crop from my particular area. The bulk handling authority charged $16.70, freight charges accounted for $20 a tonne and there are other charges. Consequently many people have considered how the grain handling system could be made more efficient. I have heard talk that at a national level the improved efficiency could result in a $10 per tonne reduction in resource costs if some of the Commission's recommendations were implemented. The report states:
A detailed, quantitative evaluation suggests that, from a national perspective, resource costs savings of approximately $10 per tonne can potentially be achieved by the adoption of this system.

The basic changes involved in the system included the removal of the requirement that the bulk handling agencies have the sole receival rights for the major grains and the removal of restrictions on the road transport of grain. That latter aspect could result in considerable problems if much more grain transport was conducted by road. That would result in damage to roads, and any government has to be mindful of the fact that money would have to be put into roads if grain were transported by road rather than by rail. The report refers to the introduction of charges for port services and sea transport which reflect the actual costs of these activities to growers and other participants in the grain distribution system.

Some people say there will not be an instant $10 saving. A report on a meeting held on this matter recently referred to the mood of the observers after attending the Federal Government's Rural and Allied Industries Council in Melbourne. It said that grain growers hoping for instant savings of $10 a tonne in the storage, handling and transport of their grain will be disappointed. If people of the quality who attended that meeting are worried about the $10 coming through the system, I also am worried. As Senator Panizza mentioned, one of the problems with grain handling is that of industrial relations, particularly at the ports. It has been estimated that work practices in Australian ports delay ships by some 25 per cent, costing something in the order of $100m a year to all industries on the seaboard. The Maritime Services Board has listed 99 restrictive work practices which, if overcome, could save between $15.5m and $28.5m. It is worth noting that port workers were granted a $4.6m second tier wage deal last December.
On the subject of industrial relations the report said:
However the underlying factor which has allowed this to develop and continue is the shielding from competitive forces of many of the organisations in the distribution system.
I believe most probably there is a place for privatisation of some parts of the handling chain. The report continued:

There is no legal doubt that the statutory authorities are owned by the State governments and could be sold off if desired. However, a case may be made on equity grounds that growers should share in the ownership of any future organisation.

In New South Wales, of course, most of the grain handling system has been built with funds provided by grain growers. If there is to be any return to the grain growers they should not have to pay for that. Rather, the grain growers should have the facilities returned to them free of charge so that the grain can be handled in a more efficient way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN HERITAGE COMMISSION (NOTIFICATION OF OWNERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 24 February, on motion by Senator Walters:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-While the Labor Party organises itself, I will make a brief statement. I inform the Senate that when the Bill is considered in the Committee of the Whole, I intend to move an amendment to insert a new clause to define ownership. I have asked that the amendment be circulated so that honourable senators participating in the debate are aware of the proposed definition.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.20 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not support the Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill 1988 or the amendment which I understand will be moved by Senator Walters. We feel the Bill is absolutely unnecessary. In fact, the Bill would impede greatly the already necessary actions of the Australian Heritage Commission. I think it is essential in discussing this Bill to establish exactly what the Heritage Commission does and what it was set up to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Heritage Commission was established in 1975. Incidentally, at that time it was recommended that it should have a staff of 50. At no time since then has that recommendation been fulfilled. In fact, generally it runs on about half of that staffing level. Another difficulty in terms of the operation of the Commission is that the number of technical advisers who actually assess the environmental values of areas to be listed is limited to only three at present. Only three people are actually employed to look at the various factors, and they are heavily overworked. If the Government were really serious about its environmental concerns and commitment, it would take immediate steps to upgrade the staff of the Heritage Commission and in fact fulfil the original intention of the government of the day to staff the Commission with 50 people. So I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is not in the chamber at the moment, to take that into account. Even though the Heritage Commission does an excellent job, it would do a far better job if it had its full complement of staff. In some cases, the Commission is 11 years behind in investigating nominations simply because of a lack of staff.

The Heritage Commission has provided the Government with most of its technical advice on major environmental issues, such as the Franklin dam, the Tasmanian forest issue, the wet tropics and Kakadu National Park. The Commission identified the wet tropics area as having World Heritage value at a time when the Government did not recognise the incredible diversity of the plant life and the uniqueness of that environment. The Commission fulfils its responsibilities by preparing and maintaining a Register of National Estate places, by advising the Commonwealth Minister responsible for the environment and other Commonwealth Ministers and departments on all matters relating to the National Estate, and by developing policies and programs for research, professional training and public education. A part time chairperson and six part time commissioners with various skills and interests in the natural and cultural environment, all of whom are appointed by the Government, make up the Commission. The Commission is supported by a small number of office staff based in Canberra.

What about the Register of the National Estate itself? Much has been made of this Register and listing on it. We have heard in this chamber and certainly outside it-in the Press and in the streets-great concern, alarm and furore over listing on the National Estate. What does it really mean? It appears that the implications, or perceived implications, of having a place listed on the Register have led to much of the criticism of the Commission in recent times. The Register is the national inventory of Australia's National Estate-that is, it is a list of places defined in the Australian Heritage Commission Act as:

. . . those places, being components of the natural environment of Australia, or the cultural environment of Australia that have aesthetic, historic, scientific or social significance or other special value for future generations as well as for the present community.

Compiling the Register is a lengthy process and it will take many years to complete. There are now 8,290 places listed on the Register and there are another 390 on the interim list. The chief value of the Register is that, as a national reference for places with the National Estate values described earlier, it is a resource for planners, researchers and decision-makers. It means that planners and decision-makers, who have long taken economic, social and other data into consideration, can now refer to National Estate data before making their decisions. This should help reduce the loss of places from Australia's heritage, destroyed simply because their value was unknown.

What about listing on the Register? This is the contentious point. It is the point that Senator Walters's Bill would make far more difficult and perhaps impossible, as we shall see later. The process of listing a place on the Register of the National Estate combines both democratic and scientific elements. Anyone, including Senator Walters, can nominate a place for listing on the Register, provided it is within Australia or its Territories, the territorial sea or continental shelf. However, after doing this, the nomination then goes through a very detailed process of assessment by specialists, according to particular criteria. This is the area that I mentioned earlier in which the specialists are few in number and highly overworked. The Commission's staff first check that they have detailed information on the place proposed for nomination. Then, the National Estate significance is assessed. This is done by referral either to an expert panel or to government or voluntary expert bodies, or by review of existing information.

What about the implications of a listing? We have heard over and over that National Estate listing deprives people of their rights over their property, that it is fascist, socialist or whatever, and that it amounts to a takeover of property. Actually, once a place is on the Register, it does not mean that it is then subject to numerous constraints and controls. In fact, no particular form of land use is imposed by entry in the Register. There are no legal constraints on owners of private property or on State or local government caused by the entry of a property in the Register. One wonders why Senator Walters and those on her side of the aisle are so vociferous about this listing. In fact, it is an honour to be listed because it identifies one's property. I would be quite proud if my house or a patch of land I owned were listed. In fact, I would want it to be protected anyway. But if it were listed, I would still have the right to do anything I wanted to the land. I think that that is unfortunate in many instances, but that is the law. Senator Walters and her friends have no cause to be alarmed about a listing in the Register of the National Estate because such a measure will not affect them in any way. If they want to tear down a building which has been listed and put up a block of flats, they would be absolutely free to do so under the Commonwealth legislation.

The Commonwealth Government is the only level of government subject to legal restraints on any of its actions which may affect places on the Register. Section 30 of the Act requires Commonwealth Ministers and bodies to ensure that their actions do not adversely affect National Estate values of places on the Register, unless there are no feasible or prudent alternatives, and to consult with the Commission about any proposed activities which could affect such places. The importance of the Register lies not in any large scale formal prohibitive function, but in its being an alert to all Australians of the existence of places of National Estate significance. So one wonders why Senator Walters is really proposing this Bill. In fact, owners are now notified in the Press and, even if they cannot be found, the listing in no way inhibits development of their property.

Why is Senator Walters actually bringing up this Bill? What does it mean? The Bill would seem to be an attempt to thwart National Estate listing because, under the Bill, if one owner cannot be found the area cannot be listed. For instance, if one could not find, say, one owner out of 50 families living on a rural property, the area could not be listed under this Bill. In fact, this has been pointed out by the National Environmental Law Association of Australia, which commented on Senator Walters's Bill. This organisation states:
However, the Association foresees significant practical problems where owners cannot be identified or contacted.

Under your amendments, the listing of a property could be invalidated by the failure to notify the owner. You will agree that it is often impossible to identify or notify all owners of property. This may mean that listings which ought to be made could not be made, simply because an owner or owners could not be contacted. In the Association's view, your amendments would require to have included in them a provision to the effect that failure to contact any owner or owners after a bona fide attempt to do so will not invalidate any subsequent listing.
The Association does not believe that the provisions in your amendments permitting owners access to the Commission's files are appropriate.

This organisation has serious doubts about this legislation. So does the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties. One of the main thrusts of Senator Walters's Bill was to preserve civil liberties. In fact the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties commented adversely on the Bill. It said in a letter:

There are, however, two drafting problems I foresee with the Bill. The first is that it does not appear to provide for the service of notices. Presumably, service can be valid if it is effected by post to the owner's rating address. This should be expressly provided. Secondly, persons who are tenants, share farmers or owners of profits a prendre may be equally affected by the listing of the property. Perhaps there should be an obligation on owners, once they have been notified by the Commission, themselves to notify such persons of the Commission's proposal.
The letter went on to say:

I should add that none of the above should be taken as a reflection upon the Australian Heritage Commission. I do not know whether they presently undertake these tasks, and if the Commission's decisions affect rights then it is probable that if no opportunity for a hearing is given then the Commission's conduct would be reviewable by the courts in any event.

So neither the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties nor the National Environmental Law Association of Australia is enthusiastic about this Bill. Therefore, the Australian Democrats join with the Government in opposing this Bill. We see it as nothing but a fairly thinly masked attempt to thwart the Heritage Commission in identifying places of national importance and putting them on the list. We feel-as I am sure the Government feels-that the people of Australia have the right to have their heritage preserved and they certainly do not deserve to have this right taken away from them by a Bill which would make it almost impossible to make any future listings on the National Estate.
Motion (by Senator Tambling) agreed to:
That the documents quoted from by Senator Sanders be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill, which amends the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The Bill, which has been put forward by my colleague Senator Walters of Tasmania, is extremely important and eminently reasonable. Therefore, I am disappointed to hear the comments of another Tasmanian colleague, Senator Sanders, that the Australian Democrats cannot agree to this Bill and believe it is unnecessary. While it might be good to have a national inventory of the National Estate, this Bill does not intend in any way to thwart the listing of property; it is just an attempt to obtain a procedure which acknowledges common courtesy-that if a property is listed there is notification to the landowner. That is one of the basic thrusts of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Not everybody in the country has a daily paper delivered; not everybody reads the Press, particularly the sorts of columns where these things get listed. When one looks at some of the descriptions such as `approximately 4.5 hectares located nine miles south-west of a certain area comprising that part of a reserve lying between a straight line joining AMG points 8413' and so on, even the ordinary landowner might not identify his own property from that sort of description. Therefore, although there is a listing of properties in the Press, in most cases I would say that the ordinary property owner is not aware, until some time later, that his particular property has been listed on the National Estate. I believe it is an act of discourtesy. Furthermore, I think it is wrong that the Australian Heritage Commission will not advise the landowner of the reasons why his property has been listed. If it is good enough for the Australian Heritage Commission to list that particular property it should be good enough for it to give reasons for that listing if the landowner requests them. Thus, I believe that Senator Walters's Bill is important and eminently reasonable.

As we have been told, the Bill seeks to amend the principal Act in such a way that it will require the Australian Heritage Commission and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to notify landowners in writing of any intention to include their property on the National Estate Register or an interim list for consideration for inclusion in that Register. I am aware of people who after six to 10 years suddenly discover their property is on the Register. It is true that some people might be proud that their property is on the Register but that is not the point. The point is that there should be adequate notification. I would go further and say that the reasons should be stated for that particular property being listed. I can see no justification whatsoever for any opposition to this Bill which seeks only to guarantee what should be a very basic right and a common courtesy-that is, the right of landowners to be advised of changes in the status of their property in the eyes of the Federal Government.
In a document produced by the Australian Heritage Commission which describes how the National Estate operates, a notation has been made that says:
The identification and protection of the National Estate is the responsibility of every Australian.
That is fair enough. It continues:
You must decide which places in your community should be kept for future generations of Australians.

That has a certain ring to it. It is really more than an inventory because the assumption is made that it should be kept for future Australians. If a person is not advised that his property is on the Register-and it might happen to be an old barn-what is to stop him quite easily bulldozing that barn down? He might have been completely unaware of its listing. If it were listed, being a genuine guy, he would be more likely to keep it than put the dozer through it. Apart from the common courtesy reasons, I think there are some practical reasons why people should be notified. The document continues:
You must ensure that the places worth keeping are not destroyed.

If one is to accept this statement the logical concomitant is that the property owners must know of the listings, particularly if it is a common responsibility for every Australian to ensure that these places are worth keeping and are not destroyed. Therefore, the property owner must know and should be told of the listing so they can be preserved. The whole concept of the National Estate is undermined if there is a situation where the owner of land is unaware of the listing. Surely, if we are to preserve certain areas of importance it is fundamental that the owner should know of this. The fact is that existing procedures for the notification of a National Estate listing are quite inadequate. That listings have occurred without the knowledge of the property owner testifies to this. I have already given an example of a couple of people who were unaware of the listing of their properties-one for six years and the other for 10.

I will give a couple of examples in my State as it is full of cultural heritage properties. It has not been uncommon in Tasmania for landowners to find out years later that their properties have been listed on the National Estate Register. It has come as quite a blow to a number of people who have owned and cared for their properties for decades. I would like to quote some comments from just two Tasmanians who have had that experience and been bold enough to put it in print. For example, Ned Terry of Dairy Plains said:

I feel quite bitter and disappointed by the way the Australian Heritage Commission goes about their business. Have all the ethics and unwritten laws of common courtesy gone by the board in this day and age?
Another, Jeffrey How of South Mole Creek, said:

I have just recently learnt that approximately half my property at South Mole Creek is already in National Estate along with parts of properties west of Liena and bounded by Liena Road and the western tiers. There are controls on timber harvesting on private land and Crown Land in this area, but what about fully developed rural properties? I wonder what sort of controls we can expect to see placed on it?
The uncertainty and disillusionment created by the inadequacy of existing arrangements is so easily remedied just by passing this Bill. There are no problems with it.
I turn to the growth of the National Estate. Already in Tasmania 31.7 per cent of the State is included on the Register of the National Estate-a very large proportion indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very special State.

—It is a very special State and a very important State. Senator Richardson will always be welcome down there. One need only look at the revisions of the Australian Heritage Commission maps of Tasmania to see how this area is constantly growing. If we see a continuation of this trend, private land and property will more frequently be proposed for listing on the Register. So, naturally, all property owners are starting to become a little concerned. This in itself is a little bit disconcerting because I believe there may be some unnecessary reaction to this. While the constraints imposed on Commonwealth Ministers and agencies with regard to National Estate listing remain unchanged, unfortunately there is a hidden agenda because the implications of such listings are now evolving.

SPEECH.PARA: There are concerns that the listing on the National Estate is the first step in the chain of introducing greater restrictions through other means. This is the hidden agenda that we all should be aware of. Experience in Tasmania has shown that great pressure can be brought to bear on property owners, industry and government to prevent the development of National Estate areas. Public demonstrations by a vocal minority seek to prevent any development activity in National Estate areas. Community perceptions of the National Estate are being transformed. We have to acknowledge that. This is despite the fact that the Australian Heritage Commission maintains that the National Estate `is not directed at actions of State governments, local government or private owners and institutions; nor does it imply a particular attitude by the Commission to the ownership, management or the use of the place'.

The Bill presented by my colleague Senator Walters merely seeks to remedy an anomaly. It is anomalous that private land, including a private home, can be listed on the Register of the National Estate without any reference to the owner, without the owner's prior knowledge or without the owner being given any chance to make a submission to the Commission, either to support the inclusion of the land or to object to it. I would have liked Senator Walters to provide in her Bill that the reasons for the inclusion of a property should also be notified to the owner. I do not think Senator Walters has gone as far as that, has she?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Perhaps that should be the next step. Senator Walters, in her second reading speech on this Bill, concluded with a reminder that this is about a great principle that this chamber, and indeed the Parliament and the people of Australia, are renowned throughout the world for holding high; that is, the principle which we call natural justice. The average Australian is known for several characteristics. He is known for his egalitarian or classless attitude. He is known for his tolerance of the points of view of others. Above all, he is known for giving the other person a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will give landowners-I think all senators fall into this category, as do millions of Australians-simply a fair go. It will give landowners the right to know that their property is under consideration for registration on the schedule of the National Estate. There is a great deal of concern within the community on this issue, particularly in my State of Tasmania where such a large proportion of the island is on the national Register.

The passing of this Bill would be one step in the direction of allaying some of those fears. I therefore urge all senators, including the Australian Democrats, to recognise the anomaly in the present Act and the confrontation that this anomaly has fuelled. The unfortunate part is the confrontation that it has aroused and will continue to arouse. I appeal to the Minister and strongly urge him and his colleagues to support this Bill. I for one commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill 1988 presented by Senator Walters and to indicate the Government's opposition to it. In doing so I would like to indicate what has gone on in the last few weeks in the lead-up to this debate. It gives an appropriate tone to tonight's proceedings. In a letter dated 29 February 1988 Senator Walters wrote to all local government councils across Australia. I add that the letters were all addressed `Dear Sir'. It might have been appropriate for her to have at least acknowledged the possibility that someone in authority in all of the local government areas right across Australia could have been a member of her own sex. Nevertheless, the third paragraph of that letter is worth reading:

SPEECH.PARA: Inclusion of property on the register of the National Estate of Australia imposes severe limitations and restrictions on the future use of the registered property.
I find the current situation completely alien to our way of life and contrary to our basic human rights of property ownership.

It is that sort of furphy and misrepresentation that renders this Bill useless. Having listened in the last few moments to Senator Watson, proof of that was provided by him. I do not need to rely on Senator Sanders or anyone in the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Heritage Commission, I can rely on Senator Watson; he is a very reliable fellow. Senator Watson said that he is aware of people who suddenly found out that their properties had been on the Register of the National Estate for six or 10 years. I think they were his words. If their properties had been on the Register for 10 years without their knowing about it, I wonder just what severe limitations and restrictions had been imposed upon them. For 10 years they did not know about it and continued on with their lives and their property was just fine. However, suddenly, after 10 years they found out that their property was on the Register and I am led to believe by Senator Walters's letter that severe limitations and restrictions had been placed upon them all along. Apparently, in those 10 years they were labouring under the terrible yoke of oppression that this registration had brought, however, they were never aware of it. I have to say that this yoke of oppression must have been a light load indeed, even for a Tasmanian.

It would be of some assistance if we could get some perspective into this debate. Registration on the National Estate means nothing more than having a property appear on a register of special places. It means that there is a recognition, at a national level, of the significance of a property. As far as I am concerned, that is something of which people should be, and most often are, very proud indeed. There are people who display their certificates of registration on their mantelpiece. There are citizens all over this country who are delighted to see their property put on this list. But for those who are not delighted, one wonders just what impositions are placed upon them. In spite of questioning person after person who has complained about this to me, no-one has ever been able to nominate even one of those restrictions and limitations. That does not surprise me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not been Minister long enough or you have not been listening.

—I have not been a Minister for very long. I have been a Minister for about eight months. That is a lot longer than Senator Walters will ever be a Minister. During that time I have probably learnt a little more than Senator Walters. I must say that tonight, once again, she is likely to display just that to those who are unfortunate enough to be listening to this debate. When Senator Walters wrote that misleading letter-that letter which contained, I think, some inappropriate misrepresentations-to all those councils, a false impression was created. One example of a council which might have believed in what she had to say was the Wollondilly Council in New South Wales. One would have thought that a council in New South Wales would have known better. However, it wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently properties can be included on this Register without the owners notification. Because of this owners can be denied their right of objection to the inclusion of their properties.
That totally denies the existence of the three-month period specified in the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! They would have to be able to see it in a newspaper.

—I assume that most people can read newspapers. It may well be the case that those who vote for Senator Walters would have difficulty in doing so. I want to quote from two organisations which have offered comment on Senator Walters's proposed legislation in a somewhat different way from the local government body which I quoted a few moments ago. The first is the National Environmental Law Association of Australia which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Association foresees significant practical problems where owners cannot be identified.
Under your amendments-
this is in writing to Senator Walters-

the listing of a property could be invalidated by failure to notify the owner. You will agree that it is often impossible to identify or notify all owners of property. This may mean that listing which ought to be made could not be made, simply because an owner or owners could not be contracted.

In the Association's view, your amendments would require to have included in them a provision to the effect that failure to contact any owner or owners after a bona fide attempt to do so will not invalidate any subsequent listing.
Perhaps I should elaborate on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you be good enough to incorporate the whole of the letter?
—I do not have a copy of the entire letter on me, but if someone wishes to table it he or she is more than welcome to do so.
—I will seek leave to incorporate the full text of the letter.

—Leave will be granted with glee. There is a problem when it comes to identifying all owners of property and it is a problem which I have experienced in recent times. Personal experience is often the best kind in these situations. I think that most honourable senators-even Senator Walters-would have heard of the World Heritage listing of the wet tropic rainforests in north Queensland. Senator Walters might also be aware that the Queensland Government was not all that happy with the proposal; nor were some of the local government bodies in north Queensland.
—Is that right?

—It is indeed a sad but true fact, Senator. As Minister, I asked officers of the Department to go forth and multiply to ensure that they notified all the owners of property in north Queensland for which World Heritage listing was being considered. The difficulty was that the State authorities gave no assistance whatsoever in helping to identify those who have an interest in property. I do not want to be too exact about this, for fear of misleading the Senate, but I think that three or four--
—Too exact for fear of misleading us!

—Fear of misleading! I note these days that misleading parliaments does tend to get one in a bit of strife. Three or four councils out of 13 would not cooperate at all. Therefore, it was impossible to identify all those who owned or had an interest in property. Despite that, I made sure that officers of the Department went out in vehicles of all descriptions to attempt to find, to identify, those owners. That is not always easy to do. Nonetheless, I think that we succeeded admirably and almost all were notified. A tremendous effort was made. But I would hate to think that the World Heritage listing could have been invalidated because we missed a couple in an area as big as that. Yet, when it comes to National Estate listings, if we were to agree to the Bill which Senator Walters has proposed tonight, that is what would happen. Listings would fail, not because the Australian Heritage Commission attempted to act behind closed doors to keep what it was doing a secret, but because it would be physically impossible to identify every owner. That sort of imposition on any statutory authority, such as the Heritage Commission, would be impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to a letter from the Fremantle City Council. Its Manager, Mr G. J. Pearce, wrote to me on 10 March and referred to Senator Walters's letter. I think that reading three paragraphs of that letter might be of assistance to the Senate. The letter states:

It is our understanding that the Australian Heritage Commission takes all reasonable steps to notify owners of an intention to include a property on the register as well as advertising this intention in newspapers throughout the country.

All local government authorities would know that where the registered proprietor of a property is a corporation or other entity, or is a complex group of beneficiaries such as a family estate, or is long since deceased, it is difficult or even impossible to effect the delivery of a notice.

The imposition of obligations of that kind would impose a serious burden on the Commission and would have the effect of precluding the registration of places where the owners are uncertain or cannot be located. It seems to us that this does-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the intention of the Bill.
—Of course it is the intention-

SPEECH.PARA: nothing for property rights, but rather relieves the Commonwealth of an obligation to protect places which should be part of the National Estate.

That is the nub of the problem. The reality is that Senator Walters's proposal-I am even led to believe that Senator Puplick, the Liberal Party's champion of the environment, agrees with her-is a ruse to render the Heritage Commission unworkable and to make sure that the National Estate cannot be added to. The Fremantle City Council knew that the Heritage Commission had cooperated, in terms of work and money, in some enormous endeavours over the last couple of years not only with the Bicentennial but also the tremendous work that was done there for the America's Cup and the facelift that was given to Fremantle. A close working relationship developed between the Council and the Heritage Commission. It is no wonder that it would reply in the terms which I have just indicated.

Let us go to exactly what Senator Walters is about. Her legislation would change the Act so that the Commission would be required to provide a copy of the public notice of intention to enter a place in the Register to all owners. It is interesting to note the need already for a public notice. This is part of the consultation process. The Commission would have to give reasons why such action was proposed and give owners the opportunity to examine any material it might have and to make submissions concerning the proposed entry.

In the time available to me, I will look at just some of the arguments that can be mustered against Senator Walters's proposal. My first argument is that the Bill is both pre-emptive and premature. It is well known that a review of the Heritage Commission is currently under way. In fact, it will be placed before Cabinet in the next couple of weeks. Not only are we not dealing with something way off in the future; we are dealing with something that will come about very quickly indeed. The results of that review are in fact before Government Ministers now. I think that at least a number of the issues canvassed in this debate will be dealt with in the review. I hope to be able to announce the Cabinet's decision on that very shortly.

The major implications of the proposed amendments for the Commission will be that the process of compiling the Register will be totally dependent on the identification of owners, irrespective of significance. That is what Senator Walters is about. I am afraid that it is just not on. The prospect of registrations being rendered illegal or void is real and alarming. No-one with a concern for the National Estate can afford to ignore that. One would hope that that would include Senator Puplick. There are no provisions in the Bill to cover a failure to advise the owner, even if all reasonable efforts and attempts have been made by the Commission to identify that owner.

Senator Walters appears to ignore the current situation where the Commission writes to identifiable owners just before a notice of intention to register is published, provided a copy of the data is presented and owners are advised of their right to object. I must say that one particularly annoying thing about this Bill is that there is a total failure to acknowledge what the Heritage Commission has done for years and years-that is, to ensure that whenever an owner can be identified that owner is provided with all relevant information. In fact, any people who query the Heritage Commission about a nomination are provided with the information that they ask for. The Commission has always done that as a matter of course. The effect of Senator Walters's proposal would be to make that current practice mandatory and, presumably, void listings where the owner is not properly advised.

I do not know how often it will be necessary to tell Senator Walters-it is very often necessary to tell her the same things a number of times to get her to understand-but she will need to understand at some stage that there is a very real concern right across the country that any attempt to water down the National Estate listing will be seen for what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—Senator Stone has arrived in the chamber. I find that interesting indeed because those of us who have witnessed Senator Stone's actions in the short time he has been here have just discovered that he has an interest in the National Estate. That is an interest that has never been displayed previous to this. I am delighted to see Senator Stone's interest. I hope that we can see it time and time again. I look forward to his informed contribution to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission cannot be locked into a requirement to notify owners of nominated properties. People of course can nominate, and occasionally do nominate, whole suburbs for the National Estate. One wonders how the Commission would then go about identifying all of these people who own or have an interest in property in the suburb. I think that that would impose something of a difficulty on the Commission. However, it gets worse. There are those people who propose whole cities. Indeed, I am led to believe that at times the Commission has received some applications to have States and even Australia entered on the National Estate. I think that at that stage of the game we would start to get into very real difficulties in notifying all of the owners. Let us face it: a lot of them are overseas these days. That in itself would require a pretty extraordinary effort on the part of the Commission.

It should be noted that the recording of changes in title and interest in properties is, in most cases, the responsibility of local authorities. It is not instantaneous. It is time consuming. For the Heritage Commission to have to chase owners of so many thousands of properties, as is the case in some places, would place on it a ridiculous burden. There are some suburbs in some of our major cities which have particular heritage value where, as an example, the preservation of historical buildings may mean a great deal. If in some of those spectacular suburbs there were to be a nomination of even a section of that suburb quite obviously the effect of Senator Walters's Bill would be to make the job of the Commission impossible. It would not be difficult to contrive to put in spurious nominations to make sure that the Commission's job was impossible. I would like to think that that is not even in Senator Walters's mind. I would hope that regardless of what is in Senator Walters's mind that is something to which she might give some consideration. The whole question of national heritage would be skewed completely if Senator Walters's Bill were ever implemented. It should be noted that the vast majority of land that has been entered on the Register of the National Estate is in fact crown land in one form or another. Not much of it at all is private land. The Commission expects those ratios to remain the same in the future. There is not a great likelihood of that sort of ratio changing. If we were then to go into private land in the way that Senator Walters has suggested I think that we would be putting a pretty stupid bias in the process. It is not what is happening. It is not what is intended to happen. I would have thought that that is a good enough reason not to commit the Commission to that sort of role in the future. I referred earlier in my introduction to a rejection of Senator Walters's contention that entry to a property on the National Estate imposes severe restrictions and limitations on the owners. It has to be remembered that the listing of a property on the National Estate imposes no obligation whatsoever on the owner.

TALK.START.PARA: —It imposes restrictions on them.

—It imposes no restrictions either, unless the owner of the property is the Commonwealth of Australia. I would have thought it appropriate that if in fact the Commonwealth of Australia were the owner of land it would be quite reasonable for the Commonwealth to wish to take heed of its own Act and act accordingly. In fact, in recent weeks I have asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to write to all Ministers to make sure that that practice is kept up. There are times when even the Commonwealth has not, in my view, acted entirely properly in that respect. There have been some examples of that in the recent past.

SPEECH.PARA: Listing does impose obligations on the Commonwealth to look after the National Estate. Those responsibilities do not extend to private owners. Therefore, that makes me wonder why we need Senator Walters's Bill. It has to be remembered too that places are removed from the National Estate if, for any reason, there is no longer a real purpose in including them. At the moment in Tasmania there is a property which has been destroyed by the State Government and, therefore, there is not much point keeping it on the Register. There will be no difficulty for anyone who might own that property because it will be taken off. It we turn to the State of Queensland, from which Senator Stone very recently comes, we get an even longer list of properties that were entered on the Register of the National Estate which subsequently were destroyed and which have since been removed.

This talk of owners' rights being affected is just nonsense. What I would really like to hear in this debate from Senator Puplick, who will champion Senator Walters's cause in a moment, is some examples of how these restrictions operate. I will be fascinated. I can only wonder at what sort of a mind can conclude that the process is, as Senator Walters said, completely alien to our way of life. I would have thought that the great majority of Australians had a respect for their history and their heritage and that they would always like to see that heritage, in so far as is possible, notified so that the community may understand the significance of it.

I point out also that in some respects Senator Walters's Bill is technically defective. It will not even do what she wants it to do. The Walters proposal in proposed new paragraph (aa) of section 23 of the Act regarding the copy of the public notice of intention to register is confusing. What does that provision require? Does it require the sending of a copy of a public notice that has already been published? If that is the case, property owners will be placed in a much worse position than they are now, because under the regime proposed by Senator Walters the property owner will read in the newspaper about what is proposed and then hear about it from the Heritage Commission. Because of the way in which the Heritage Commission currently operates, that owner would have already received from the Commission a letter in which all of the details would have been explained.

I wonder whether Senator Walters is really doing property owners a favour in battling on. If she intends to propose these sorts of Bills, she should at least have some idea in her mind of what she is trying to achieve and she ought to ensure that the Bill is drafted in such a way as to achieve it. It we were to adopt this proposed Act, the net effect would be that the Commission would have to write to the owner three times in the ordinary course of events: prior to entering the listing following a decision being made, after interim listing to provide the notice, and at the time of registration. One wonders what sort of burden this will place on the Heritage Commission. It is not a body with abundant staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs more staff.
—It badly needs more staff, as Senator Sanders and others have said previously. I will see what I can do about that in the course of the discussions that I will have over the next few weeks.
—Why not? It is not your money.

—No, it is certainly not my money. However, it is, at least in part, made up of money that I have paid in taxes. One wonders how much avoided tax Senator Stone really ever wanted people to pay. I conclude by pointing out that the additional tasks to which I have just referred and which Senator Walters would like to see imposed on the Heritage Commission would make impossible the task of continuing to compile and keep a proper Register of the National Estate. The integrity of that Register has never been more important as an inventory of those places in Australia, both natural and built, that are of importance to our heritage. We always need more reminders of them. If the Heritage Commission can ensure that more Australians are made aware of those places, it will indeed have lived up to every inch of the charter which the Whitlam Government proposed for it 15 years ago. I hope that nothing done in this Parliament, either tonight or in the future, will ever in any way weaken that charter.

SPEECH.PARA: I should have referred earlier to the amendment that Senator Walters moved at the beginning of the debate. Once again, it is just another attempt to make the job of the Commission impossible. The Bill which has been introduced by Senator Walters and which will be supported by some honourable senators during the debate is yet another attempt to ensure that National Estate legislation is watered down. Those people do not like the Register of the National Estate; they do not want it to be kept and they will do anything to prevent that from occurring. However, I am more than hopeful that once again they will fail in the Senate tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental issue being addressed in this debate is the need to balance-that is a word which one hears frequently in debates about conservation and the environment-the rights of properties to be protected and of the nation to have its heritage protected and the rights of individuals to enjoy the use of private property in a sensible and constructive way. When one has to balance rights, it happens to be my belief that the rights of individuals ought to be regarded as a primary right. In the course of this debate I propose to address some remarks to that aspect, as well as to specifics of the legislation which is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I start, therefore, by commenting briefly on a couple of remarks that Senator Sanders made in his address. He said that this matter was about the status of listing and the processes of listing. I do not believe that is an accurate assessment. As I have said, I believe this debate is about the rights of individuals. He went on to say that the simple entry of an item onto the interim list or onto the Register of the National Estate did not affect the use of that property. Indeed, that may be technically correct. However, it does not address the question of the value of that property, both in a commercial and, indeed, in a very real sense, once it has been entered on an interim list or on the Register, because the value of a property may in fact be substantially affected by the mere inscription of, or the indication that there is an intention to inscribe, that property on a particular list.

Both Senator Richardson and Senator Sanders said that a mere listing does not in fact mean that things cannot be done to a property. That may be technically correct, but in that context I wish to refer to a very specific case. I live in a property that I happen to own; that is to say, the bank happens to own it. However I reside in a property which was constructed in 1904. The local council for the area in which I live has in place regulations which state that those properties which are listed on the Register of the National Estate, or its equivalent in New South Wales, can be dealt with only in a certain fashion. Specifically, for my particular purposes, such properties can be painted, for instance, only in what are described as heritage colours. I cannot paint the property in which I live in colours other than those which are prescribed as heritage colours by the local government authority for the area in which I live because that property has a certain National Estate listing. That is the sort of situation which specifically arises. I was asked by the Minister to give an example; I give an example from my own very personal recent experiences.

I come to a couple of the points that Senator Richardson made. I start by addressing a threshold question which applies just as much to this Bill as it applies to the protection of the tropical rainforests of north Queensland. Where one can achieve protection of the environment without frightening and upsetting the citizens directly affected, one will get more adequate and committed protection. To the extent that the whole approach adopted by the Government is one which causes fear, uncertainty and distress and which threatens economic loss or threatens people with the loss of their personal rights and freedoms, the real security of, and the real capacity to protect and conserve, that environment is significantly reduced.

All Senator Walters's Bill is attempting to do is bring about a situation in which those areas which are listed on the Register of the National Estate will have an element attached to them which they currently do not have, namely, a degree of support and a degree of commitment from the people who are directly affected. Under those circumstances, the preservation of that built environment will be considerably greater than it is under current circumstances.

Senator Richardson quoted from a letter addressed to Senator Walters by the National Environmental Law Association of Australia. During the debate he admitted that he had only an extract from that letter which he quoted. By selectively quoting he has misquoted because the second paragraph of that letter reads as follows in terms of its introduction:

The Association, while not commenting in detail on your amendments, has no objection in principle to their tenor; the amendments aim to give statutory recognition to what the Australian Heritage Commission already does.

Mark those words: `has no objection in principle'. Similarly, Senator Sanders, who was anxious to imply that there was some opposition to the legislation from the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties, failed to quote this sentence:

For very many years my Council has supported legislation which confers upon persons affected by Government decisions the right to know the nature of the decision and the right to make submissions to the relevant decision maker.

Again, selectively quoting or, indeed, implying something when the substance of the letter, taken as a whole, says otherwise, is disingenuous to say the very least. In order to set the record straight-Senator Richardson has already indicated his consent-I seek leave to have copies of these two letters incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-

Dear Senator Walters,
Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of
Owners) Amendment Bill 1988
Many thanks for your correspondence and for giving this Association the opportunity to comment on your suggested amendments to the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

The Association, while not commenting in detail on your amendments, has no objection in principle to their tenor; the amendments aim to give statutory recognition to what the Australian Heritage Commission already does. However, the Association foresees significant practical problems where owners cannot be identified or contacted.

Under your amendments, the listing of a property could be invalidated by the failure to notify the owner. You will agree that it is often impossible to identify or notify all owners of property. This may mean that listings which ought to be made could not be made, simply because an owner or owners could not be contacted. In the Association's view, your amendments would require to have included in them a provision to the effect that failure to contact any owner or owners after a bona fide attempt to do so will not invalidate any subsequent listing.
The Association does not believe that the provisions in your amendments permitting owners access to the Commission's files are appropriate.
We hope that these comments will be of some assistance to you in your continuing deliberations on this Bill.
Please note that a copy of this letter has been sent to each of Senators Richardson and Haines.
With best wishes,
Yours sincerely,
JOHN TABERNER
Secretary
NEW SOUTH WALES COUNCIL FOR CIVIL
LIBERTIES
149 St Johns Road, Glebe 2037
