15 March 1988
Senator Shirley Walters,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator,
Re: Australian Heritage Commission(Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill 1988
Thank you for your letter of 4 March 1988 which we received last week.

For very many years my Council has supported legislation which confers upon persons affected by Government decisions the right to know the nature of the decision and the right to make submissions to the relevant decision maker. Indeed, even in the absence of legislative provision the courts will frequently infer such rights under the umbrella of the rules of natural justice. Your Bill gives expression to these rights by providing the machinery for their exercise.

There are, however, two drafting problems I foresee with the Bill. The first is that it does not appear to provide for the service of notices. Presumably, service can be valid if it is effected by post to the owner's rating address. This should be expressly provided. Secondly, persons who are tenants, share farmers or owners of profits a prendre may be equally affected by the listing of the property. Perhaps there should be an obligation on owners, once they have been notified by the Commission, themselves to notify such persons of the Commission's proposal.

I should add that none of the above should be taken as a reflection upon the Australian Heritage Commission. I do not know whether they presently undertake these tasks, and if the Commission's decisions affect rights then it is probable that if no opportunity for a hearing is given then the Commission's conduct would be reviewable by the courts in any event.
Yours sincerely,
TIM ROBERTSON
Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Senator Richardson approached this debate in a very cavalier fashion when he said, `There have been proposals to list whole cities, proposals to list whole States, proposals to list the whole of Australia on some sort of a register and we could not possibly notify all the owners and, as a result, the process of listing will somehow be set at nought'. To approach the debate with that sort of attitude I think is simply symptomatic of the way in which Senator Richardson has addressed all these matters in terms of the environment debate-the flip, smart alec remark intended to divert attention from a real, significant and individual problem by trying to confuse and by trying to make ridiculous a situation which is of real substance, and I reject that sort of approach entirely.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson came into the chamber and said to us during this debate-I think these are his exact words-`Australians should have more respect for their history and their heritage'. Let us just examine the sorts of things his Government has done about the built environment in the last couple of years. As part of the assets sale mentality a large number of properties of relevance to Australia's heritage are to be sold off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like what?

—For instance, Shaftston House in Brisbane, Amity House in Brisbane, Nos 5-7 Hickson Road in Sydney, the property known as Nangunya in Melbourne, the Williamstown rifle range, Point Nepean and Swan Island. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) asked, `Like what?'. He will get a few `like whats' as far as this is concerned. Shaftston House in Brisbane is a single storey house of rendered masonry built in 1883, which happens to be a particularly important townhouse, which happens to have important townscapes and is visible from the Brisbane River. Amity House is significant historically for its associations with Thomas Welsby and its architectural style and design are typical of the 1890s. The area in Sydney, 5-7 Hickson Road, which is known as the former Australasian Steam Navigation Co. was built in 1883-84 to the design of the significant architects, William Wardell and Walter Vernon. In Melbourne, the Italianate mansion known as Nangunya has fine ornamental detailing in cement render and is an important surviving example of the decoration of the late Edwardian period. Let us look at comments in an article in the Australian towards the end of last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of Australia's oldest military establishments and foreshore lands may go in a $300 million defence property sell-off aimed at reducing the federal Budget deficit.
The list includes such historic sites as Victoria Barracks in Melbourne, part of the barracks at Manly overlooking Sydney Heads and the Artillery Barracks at Fremantle in Western Australia.
Studies have already been completed on the redevelopment value of the Melbourne site. Its NSW namesake, Victoria Barracks in Sydney, is also thought to be under threat for its land value.

There was a report in the Australian newspaper in May last year about the significant development on Swan Island, including the historic lighthouse. I look at the February 1987 issue of Victorian Trust News dealing with Point Nepean, which says in part:

The Trust also became aware that the Commonwealth Government has investigated the possibility of subdividing land in the north-west section of the Park, which includes some of the Quarantine buildings.
The Trust is extremely concerned at the implications of these proposals for the management of the Park as a whole, and the access problems they may create.

We have not even started the debate about foreshore parkland around Sydney harbour. So for the Minister to come into this chamber, full of pious views about the extent to which the Commonwealth wants individuals to be more sensitive and more respectful of their history and their heritage when, under pressure from Senator Walsh he has engaged in a significant sell-off of large parts of Australia's heritage, I think is important. I am grateful that the Minister for Finance is in the chamber this evening to confirm the extent to which he is precisely pushing in this direction and is anxious to cover up some of the financial mismanagement which he and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have engaged in by making this asset sale of various significant Australian heritage properties a part of the way in which they want to cover up for their own financial mismanagement in this matter.

Let me take another example which arises from Senator Walsh and Mr Keating-that is, the application of the fringe benefits tax to properties and to people who are involved in conservatorial work in national heritage buildings. After all, if a trust owns an historic property and a person is put in as a guardian or conservator in order to ensure that the place is protected from vandals, whether they happen to be financial vandals like Senator Walsh or some other form of vandal around the place, that trust will end up having to pay fringe benefits tax on the notional value of providing the accommodation for that person, and this is despite repeated assurances from Senator Richardson that he was going to fix this matter up. He may be very good at fixing up the Enmore branch of the Australian Labor Party but he is certainly no good at fixing up Mr Keating or the Minister for Finance when it comes to discharging his responsibilities as the Minister who is actually supposed to be in charge of the protection of Australia's heritage. This Bill raises a certain number of other issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't fix things up in Balmain.

—My colleague Senator Stone says that Senator Richardson has been good at fixing things up in Balmain! I would not be in the least surprised when the Labor Party loses the seat of Balmain on Saturday to Dawn Fraser if the Minister sends in the bulldozers in order to make sure that the whole thing is properly dealt with in the usual sort of approach that the Huns and the Visigoths always took to areas once they had slipped from their allegiance. But as I have said, this debate allows me an opportunity to make a couple of comments about the operation of the Australian Heritage Commission and about significant issues in Australian heritage policy. I do so not only as a participant in this debate but also because this will be an important commitment and centrepiece of the Opposition's policy on matters of heritage which we will put in place after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I make it absolutely clear that the Australian Heritage Commission Act will be rewritten lock, stock and barrel. It has to be. It is not good enough for Senator Richardson to say that there will be a review, that he will get a report shortly. We have been hearing that sort of drivel about Australian museums for the last 15 months, and we know precisely what is at stake there. We know that Senator Richardson's Department and Senator Walsh's Department each have conflicting views about the commitment of resources to Australian museums and collections. Because of that conflict the review has been stymied.

It is simply not good enough for Senator Richardson to come along and say, `Well, at some time in the not too distant future I hope to take to cabinet a submission about the Australian Heritage Commission Act'. The Act needs to be repealed and it needs to be totally rewritten. The key point of rewriting it will be the need to establish clear priorities within the list. It is simply not good enough to have a list which places all the buildings, all the sites and all the significant places on some sort of equal footing. There are areas of absolutely unique significance which should be protected at all costs. Conversely, there are items on the list which ought to be taken off the list, and taken off quickly. Further, the list ought to be reviewed regularly.

It is an absolute joke for Senator Richardson to tell us that items are de-listed. They are de-listed when they burn down, when they fall over, when they are vandalised because it is too expensive to employ a caretaker, or indeed when some further evaluation takes place. However, insufficient attention is paid to maintaining the currency of the list. The reason is that the resources which the Minister insists on providing, or not providing, for the commission are devoted primarily to building up lists, rather than evaluating the significance of what goes on the list or what should go on the list. Towards the end of last year the Heritage Commission's newsletter reported that there were now 8,290 places listed on the register and another 390 on the interim list. It may well be that there are now far more than that number.

I bear in mind also in terms of the Commission and the departmental personnel who are responsible for things of this nature a speech that was given by Mr Galvin, a former head of the Department some time ago. He addressed a meeting held in, I think, Estes Park, Colorado. Mr Galvin basically said that he did not believe that development and conservation were compatible values. The permeation of that sort of attitude throughout the bureaucracy over which Senator Richardson presides, albeit temporarily, seems to me to be indicative of a significant problem which will need to be addressed. It certainly will be addressed by the incoming coalition government.

A number of other heritage matters need to be addressed. One of the most important-I say so emboldened by the presence of my colleague Senator Stone-is the necessity to examine more carefully the integration of the taxation regime and taxation incentives with the capacity to maintain and improve the status of the National Estate. In the United States of America the operations of the Economic Tax Recovery Act 1982 have been particularly beneficial to the owners of private property. It has encouraged the redevelopment of properties within urban areas and ensured that the problem of urban blight-a major problem in the United States, though fortunately not yet a problem in Australia-is significantly addressed.

A number of reports have been prepared on the subject. I refer particularly to people such as Peter Edwards and Norman Thompson who wrote a report entitled: Economic Activity: Regeneration Through Heritage. That report was published in Adelaide in October 1986. One of those authors is a management consultant and the other is the Dean of the Faculty of Economics at the University of Adelaide. In June 1985 they presented a report entitled: Fiscal Incentives for Heritage Conservation. In November 1986 a report was prepared by a working party to the Planning Ministers Conference held in Sydney in November 1986. That report was entitled: Tax Incentives for Heritage Conservation.

I do not believe that the Government has significantly addressed itself to this matter. I believe we could encourage very substantial private sector investment in heritage conservation. That would not only be an economic benefit to the nation as a whole but also would represent a significant transfer of power out of the hands of bureaucracies and government departments. Further, it would provide an incentive to the private sector by which I believe these properties could be more effectively managed; indeed, not only managed but also kept as part of the living community by their being made an economically valuable resource. At present there is no incentive for that to happen. That matter will have to be addressed.

This is important legislation. I make perfectly clear that although this is a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Walters, it has the complete support of the coalition parties. It is a private senator's initiative, but one which is enthusiastically supported by both of the coalition parties.

The aim of the Bill is fundamentally to restore and preserve the rights of individuals. It is not surprising that that principle should ultimately turn out to be one that fundamentally divides the Liberal Party and the National Party on one side from the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats on the other side. That of course, is of itself a litmus test of the differences in philosophy and approach between the political parties.

On the one hand, the Bill seeks to give primacy to the rights of individuals, and at the same time in no way derogates from the capacity of the community as a whole to identify those parts of the national estate which are significant and relevant in the historical or aesthetic sense to large numbers of Australians. On the other hand, the arguments advanced against the Bill by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats are that the rights of some amorphous body known as `the community' or indeed as `the National Estate' should somehow be preferred over the rights of individuals, and should be given primacy over the rights of individuals.

We say that the rights of individuals and the protection of the National Estate are not incompatible values. The Government and the Democrats say that they are. Because the Government believes the values to be incompatible, it suggests that one side has to be the winner and the other side has to be the loser. That is a typical Labor Party approach: one side has to win and one side has to lose. A priori, one knows full well from the Labor Party that the rights of the collective will prevail and the rights of the individual will be set aside. We do not believe that is proper. We do not believe that is in accord with the way in which we should do things in Australia. Equally we believe that is also fundamentally destructive of the heritage and the environment which is sought to be protected. That sort of attitude will only divide. It will only cause bitterness. It will only cause resentment. It will only cause animosity. Further, in the long run it will lead to the destruction of the very values and indeed the actual places which the proponents of such a view claim they are seeking to protect.

As I say, Senator Richardson's approach to this debate has been to misquote, to quote selectively a number of sources and references and to attempt to make light of a problem which is indeed serious, and to claim for the Government a degree of virtue in this matter which, on the basis of any objective test that may be applied, it simply does not possess.

I am pleased, therefore, to support Senator Walters's private senator's Bill and to indicate that the Opposition will be supporting and voting for the Bill. In Government, we shall be making quite significant changes to the Australian Heritage Commission, to its Act, and to the way in which it goes about its business. Meanwhile, we shall be continuing to keep under the closest of review those areas in which the Government has clearly failed-where it has failed on the question of selling off parts of the National Estate; where it has failed to look at ways in which the private sector can be more productively involved in the protection of the National Estate; and where the Government's own rapacious tax measures, such as the fringe benefits tax, have led to some threat being posed to the National Estate which need never have been posed. Therefore, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I commend to the Senate the passage of the Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-As Senator Puplick has said, the Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill 1988 is a litmus test of the differences between the two major parties. As has already been stated many times tonight, there has to be a balance between individual rights and collective rights of the community. The Liberal Party, a coalition party, believes that the rights of the individual are paramount. Government members and, indeed, the Australian Democrats, believe that the community rights are paramount. If we need anything to remind us of that, I have only to quote what Dr Blewett said when he was speaking at the South Australian Labor Conference in June 1986, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

That is the essence of why this Government and the Democrats are opposing this Bill. They have no concept of, and do not agree with, rights of ownership of private property. That was so clearly put by Dr Blewett at that South Australian Labor Conference-a `bourgeois right' to privacy `that is very much associated with the right to private property'.

I have only a few minutes left this evening for this debate. As I shall not finish my speech, I shall continue it at some later stage. However, it is important for me to pick out a couple of very important matters about which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, spoke to the Senate. As Senator Puplick has said, Senator Richardson made great play of the fact that there was no requirement in the Act that one's property must be treated in a certain way once it is on the National Estate Register. Senator Richardson said that I had misled local councils by saying that if one's place was on the National Estate there would be restrictions. Senator Puplick has pointed those restrictions in describing the restrictions placed on his own property. But I can give another instance in which a landowner whose place was merely on the interim list-he was not told about that; he just happened to find out-rang the local council and said, `What restrictions would you place on my property?'. The council said, `We would not allow you to subdivide'. I hope that the public servants sitting in the chamber who have given the Minister information are taking note of what is being debated here, because they may they have misinformed the Minister. The Minister either is not telling the truth in this place or has been misinformed by the public servants. There are restrictions. There are severe restrictions, and the letters I wrote to local councils were completely correct.

Senator Sanders, who spoke this evening, also made that comment-but he does not understand; he does not know; he did not even bother to look at the Bill. Senator Richardson's excuse could be that he has not been a Minister for long; but he swears that he knows all about his portfolio. The point is that he does not listen. He made his speech in this place and then walked out; so he has not listened to the debate. He did not stay and listen to Senator Puplick. He did not stay to hear. He challenged us to give examples, and then walked out; he did not listen to the examples. We have given him examples tonight of exactly what happens. Senator Richardson brought forward a letter from the council of the City of Fremantle. I wrote and sent my Bill to local government bodies in Australia. I have received very many letters in reply. Only one letter from a local authority opposed my Bill. That was from the City of Fremantle. I wonder why that particular city council would oppose my Bill. Let us look at who is the Director of Planning of the City of Fremantle. It is Jeremy Dawkins, brother of John Dawkins, a Minister in this Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really! Who?
—It is Jeremy Dawkins, the Planning Director of Fremantle City Council. And what else is Jeremy Dawkins?
—He is John Dawkins's brother.

—Apart from being John Dawkins's brother, what else is he? He is a member of the Heritage Commission, and Senator Richardson announced in December last year that Mr Jeremy Dawkins has a two-year appointment. Is it any wonder that I received a letter from the City of Fremantle saying that it does not agree with my Bill, and that it is the only local government council from which I received such a letter? Is it any wonder that Senator Richardson, who had just appointed Fremantle's city planner to the Heritage Commission, reads out that letter in this Senate? What a travesty! What a disgrace that Minister is! John Dawkins's brother, a couple of months ago appointed by the Federal Minister, writes me that letter, and is it any wonder?

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Minister trying to pull? Did he think that we would not know? Did he think that we would not understand what he was doing? No wonder the Minister did not stay in the chamber. No wonder he walked out as soon as he had had his say. Is it any wonder that the Opposition side of the chamber treats him with such disdain?

This evening from the Democrats we have had Senator Sanders, not knowing what he was talking about, reading the original Bill from cover to cover because he wanted to fill in a few minutes to make it look as though he had made a speech. He said that he would be honoured if he owned a home or property that was listed. Indeed, so would I. But I should like to be told about it. I should like to be told that my property was being listed on the National Estate. I believe it is part of the education of Australian people to be told, `You have a beautiful property. It is so good we want to put it on the National Estate list'. If this were done, the people who own those properties would take pride in them. They would then make sure that their property was treated properly and was not destroyed in any way.

The trouble is that the Big Brother government in this place does not trust people. It does not want them to know that they own something of value. The Big Brother government here does not believe that people should own private property for a start. It does not believe in the right of the bourgeois to do so. The Big Brother government does not trust the people, so it will not tell them. It will not allow this chamber to pass legislation under which people will be told that their land is to be put on the National Estate list.

I would like to put to rest a few other things that Senator Richardson has done. Senator Richardson also said tonight that very few private properties are listed. I asked for a list of the entries on the Register for Tasmania. Senator Puplick said that there are something like 8,290 entries on the Register. There seem to be a tremendous number in Tasmania. As I said, Senator Richardson said in this place tonight that there are very few private properties on the Register. Let me read from the first page of the list, which sets out the entries for the Bothwell Municipality. The list includes `Strathbarton'; Thorpe Mill; Mitchell's Cottage; `Cluny Park' homestead; `Ratho' homestead; Clifton Priory; the former tannery, now a residence; `Fort Wentworth'; Wentworth; stone residence and outbuildings; St Michael Church; the store and the shop; Bothwell Emergency Control Centre; Bothwell stores; stone cottage; Llanberis', formerly Carlton Hill; `Sherwood' homestead; St James Church; Steppes State Reserve; the post office and residence; Dr John Brennan's surgery; the barn on Steddles; `Strathborough', St Luke's Uniting Church; and the old post office.

I turn to Hobart. I will not stick to Bothwell because that area might be an exception. Let us look at the properties that are on the list in respect of Hobart. The list includes the Girl Guides Association building; `Cananore' and the brick wall behind St Michael's School; `Talune', which is also private; St Anne's Hospital old buildings; cottages, the general post office; `The Belfry'; the antique shop; `Westella', Prospect House; the Baptist Church; Davis College; the Union Steam Ship Co. building; the old Marine Board building; St Peter's Hall; St Mary's College; St Mary's Cathedral; and the H. Jones and Co. building.

Does the Minister want me to go on? There are lists and lists of private properties. Yet, the Minister stands here tonight and tells us that there are very few private properties. There is the Royal Engineers' building; Gifford's bulk store; A. G. Webster's building; the Town Hall; Ingle Hall; Alexandra Hotel; the Commonwealth Social Services building; the Deanery; St David's Cathedral; the Derwent and Tamar building; the J. Walch and Sons building; the Tasmanian Club; the stone buildings of the Perpetual Trustee; the Queen Mary Club and Legacy House.

What on earth is the Minister talking about? I have only just started to read the properties in Hobart. Yet, the Minister tells us that there are very few private properties on the list. If the Minister trusted the people of Australia, if he was prepared to allow the Heritage Commission to inform the owners, the owners could be very helpful. An owner came to me and said, `The limestone caves on my property have been put on the heritage list, but they did not know the best ones. If they had asked me, I would have shown them the better ones. They have listed a couple that are not nearly as good'. As I said, the Minister will not trust the people of Australia.

What is wrong with allowing people to know that their property has been put on the National Estate list? What is wrong with allowing people time to appeal, if they so wish, because the information may be incorrect? This has happened in the past. I know of an incident where a home was put on the list for the wrong reasons. The owners did not appeal because they did not know about it. When they finally found out they were able to prove that what had been said was not true. But, by then, it was too late to do anything.

What is wrong with allowing people to understand that they own a valuable property? What is wrong with allowing people to know that their property has been put on the interim list of the National Estate? What is wrong with letting them know that their home or property is to be listed on the National Estate if it is decided that such a step is worthwhile? The only thing wrong is that the Big Brother government in Canberra-the Labor socialist government-does not trust the people sufficiently to let them have that information.
I indicated earlier that I intend to move an amendment at the committee stage. My foreshadowed amendment reads as follows:
Page 2, after clause 2, insert the following new clause:
Interpretation
``2a. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting in subsection (1) the following definition:
`owner', in relation to a place, means:
(a) in the case of a place that is the property of a State or the Northern Territory-that State or the Northern Territory, as the case may be; or

(b) in any other case-a person who has an interest in the place that is registered under the law of the State or Territory in which the place is situated relating to registration of interests in land;''.

It appears that the Government and the Australian Democrats have no intention of supporting the Bill before us. It is because of their lack of support that we find, for instance, that there was a 38 per cent fall in expenditure on field exploration in the mining areas of the west coast of Tasmania between 1984-85 and 1986-87. This occurred because the present Federal Government has created the situation where the mining industries do not have the confidence to go ahead and carry out their exploration. A 38 per cent drop should interest the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is in the chamber now, because that means a lot of dollars that otherwise would help our overseas debt. It is the lack of confidence that this Government is creating in its environmental policies generally which is at the heart of that sort of fall. Again, the Government's failure to support my Bill will create so much uncertainty and suspicion that I can only presume that it will further destroy any of the mining, forestry or exports with which our State is so closely associated.

I thank my colleagues who have spoken in support of my Bill. I thank those many people who have written in support of my Bill. I am sorry that the Government and the Australian Democrats are so opposed to private ownership and so lacking in trust of the Australian people that they cannot see the need for my amendments.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee agrees to the amendments made by the House of Representatives on Senate amendments Nos 4, 5, 9 and 20.

I just want to clarify the position of the Law Council of Australia in relation to the transfer of Federal jurisdiction to the Family Court. The Law Council remains opposed to any such transfer, whether within the trade practices area or anywhere else and whether with or without associated jurisdiction. This has been clarified by Mr Bennett, the Secretary-General of the Law Council, this afternoon and I am happy to acquaint the Senate with that firm adherence of the Law Council to that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the Minister said last time that the Law Council of Australia was perfectly happy with it. Is he now telling us that he was wrong?

—What I said last time is that the trade practices committee of the Law Council of Australia had contacted the Attorney-General's Department with its worries about the associated jurisdiction in trade practices matters, that the Department had replied and that there had been no response from the trade practices committee. I said that it might be inferred from that that the trade practices committee was satisfied with the reply. Since then, Mr Bennett, the Secretary-General of the Law Council of Australia, has indicated, having written on 3 December indicating the Council's opposition to the transfer of jurisdiction, including associated jurisdiction, and having on 17 February in a circular to honourable senators indicated that it still had those objections, that the position is that the Law Council has an objection to the transfer of jurisdiction as a whole, including the question of associated jurisdiction. We received a communication from Mr Bennett this afternoon to that effect. I held discussions with Senator Durack about this this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Tate has moved that the Committee agree to the amendments now proposed by the House of Representatives to the amendments made by the Senate. It is worth noting that the House of Representatives has agreed to the majority of the amendments that were made in the course of a very extensive committee debate in the Senate. In particular, it has agreed with, and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) seems to express some satisfaction with, the decision of the Senate to enable the judges of the Family Court of Australia to robe if that is their wish; in other words, we removed the prohibition on that and the House of Representatives has accepted our amendment. That decision of the House of Representatives, in accepting the amendment of the Senate, will be another very important step in the renovation of the Family Court and the bringing back of it into the mainstream of the judicial system. Having moved that amendment in the Senate on behalf of the Opposition, I must express my satisfaction that that will now become law.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives has also accepted with a minor amendment the proposal from Senator Walters to limit the power of the judicial registrars in relation to contested custody and access matters. Honourable senators will remember that we had a very long debate upon that matter. Finally, in committee we persuaded the Minister for Justice to agree to that amendment on the basis that some tidying up might be required, particularly in relation to interim orders which would be suitably made by judicial registrars, but that any permanent orders would still have to be made by a judge. That particular amendment has been agreed to in principle as it was passed in the Senate, together with a suggested amendment making that qualification, so that judicial registrars will be able to deal with the minor matters that arise, the pre-trial matters, interim orders and so on. Therefore, I again express my satisfaction that the Government has agreed to the principle of those amendments and has recognised, as we recognised in this chamber, that some tidying up of that kind might be justified.

However, the House of Representatives has not agreed to an amendment made in the Senate to limit the jurisdiction of magistrates to $10,000 in matters relating to the settlement of property, or to $20,000 where a motor vehicle is involved. This was the subject of a lot of debate in the Senate. We in the Opposition believe that the figure of $10,000 should be agreed upon in the Committee. The Government suggested $20,000. By way of compromise, the Australian Democrats, in their usual style, suggested an unworkable proposal of increasing the figure from $10,000 to $20,000 where a motor vehicle was involved. Of course, that was such nonsense. As was pointed out in the House of Representatives, and indeed here, if one wanted to increase the jurisdiction from $10,000 to $20,000 all one had to do was to buy an old bomb for $50 or less and the jurisdiction of the magistrate would be increased by $10,000. But the wisdom of that did not seem to prevail on the Democrats, nor indeed on Senator Tate and the Government here. When it got back to the House of Representatives, the stupidity of that matter was recognised. But, unfortunately, the Government wants to increase the figure now to $20,000. I therefore move:
Leave out all words after ``amendments'' (second occurring), insert:
``Nos 4 and 5, and agrees to the amendments made by the House of Representatives on Senate amendments 9 and 20 with the following further amendments:
Amendment No. 9-Leave out `$20,000', insert `$10,000'.
Amendment No. 20-Leave out `$20,000', insert `$10,000'''.

Of course, this was our original proposition. The figure of $10,000 is a very considerable advance on the jurisdiction that has been exercised by magistrates under the Family Law Act in this matter. The amount has been limited to $1,000. Taking inflation into account over those years, it is estimated that probably an appropriate figure now would be about $3,500 to $4,000 but we in the Opposition have taken into account the movement of costs in certain areas, which may be greater than the ordinary consumer price index rate of inflation, particularly in relation to motor cars. That is why we determined on a figure of $10,000, which in fact trebles the real jurisdiction of a magistrate in property matters. We think that is a suitable figure and see no reason why it should be extended to $20,000 when the jurisdiction of magistrates in a number of States is less than that.

The Opposition has maintained its position consistently in this matter throughout this debate. We believe that the Senate should maintain the view that the figure should be $10,000, without any reference to the involvement of a motor vehicle, which only confuses the issue totally, would be easily subverted and probably unworkable. With those comments the Opposition agrees to the amendments, with the amendment that I have moved. I just add that further amendments have had to be made to amendments that the Government introduced in the committee stage dealing with the question of seniority of judges. The Government still was not able to get it right the second time around. I remind the Committee, yet again, that these are amendments to amendments to a Bill which the Government wanted to be passed about three stages ago in December last year.

When the Opposition sought to have the matter referred to a committee, because of all the technical difficulties that obviously were there and which needed proper investigation, the Government, with the support of the Democrats, opposed the Opposition's sensible proposal. It re-emerged in the course of the lengthy committee debate that the Government had seen the need for a number of amendments and it brought in a whole raft of them which complicated and greatly extended the committee debate. Even then the Government still could not get it right and has since had to have another go at the thing. Heaven knows whether it is right or not, but at least it is a big improvement on the Bill which the Government wanted this chamber to pass in December last. I hope that the Minister, who has not been very familiar with the Department that he now administers with the Attorney-General, will learn some lessons from his experience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Durack that there is not particular virtue in consistency if it is only another name for bloody-mindedness or pig-headedness and say simply that, while I express disquiet at the behaviour of some parties in this place, I am not particularly impressed at the Government's reneging on this particular amendment. It seems to have been persuaded by some lawyers, who have difficulty in deciding what a motor vehicle is, to back off from what is a sensible compromise. New South Wales does not seem to have any difficulty in working out what a motor vehicle is because its legislation says precisely that the amount will be $10,000 or, where a motor vehicle is involved, $20,000. Apparently the Australian Labor Party has succumbed to this incapacity in some lawyers, as well as the hysterics-that is what it was-of the Opposition shadow in another place who dreamed up the idea that some people with $10,500 worth of property might abuse the system by going out and buying a $50 car in order to fall under the $20,000 limit if a car is involved. In the meantime apparently, the Labor Party is quite happy to see a lot of very ordinary families, low income families, which have a car and a washing machine-for heaven's sake!-the value of which amounts to more than $10,000 having to go to the Family Court to have their property distribution determined. I can think of nothing more ludicrous nor demeaning in this place that that we should fall for that sort of hysterical outburst from a member of another place and be prepared to disadvantage many people.

SPEECH.PARA: I happen to believe that $10,000 is too low a limit. An assortment of ordinary family home items, such as a fridge, a washing machine and perhaps a freezer, plus a car-and most families have cars-adds up to at least $10,000. To make those ordinary people go to the Family Court instead of a court of summary jurisdiction is ridiculous. On the other hand, it could well be argued that $20,000 may be too high a limit. It was a sensible compromise when one considers that most families in this country have a car. With the price of cars today, $10,000 was a reasonable amount to take for the contents of a house, with the limit being pushed to $20,000 if there was a vehicle. Instead, we in this place are now forced to make a decision between $10,000, which will severely inconvenience a large number of ordinary families-simply because some Opposition members have hysterics at what might be abuse by a small group of people-and $20,000 which may well be too high. I find it absolutely outrageous that we are more concerned in this place with playing politics, not only between one side of this chamber and another but also between one chamber and another, and catching in the middle a whole lot of very ordinary families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard such hypocrisy in all my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber for its support for two of the amendments which were passed in the House of Representatives and sent to this chamber for our consideration and agreement. In particular, I refer to the amendment dealing with seniority within the Family Court of Australia. That amendment is necessary and, whilst it is complex, it will satisfy the requirements of several judges within the Family Court who may have been disadvantaged in the hierarchical arrangements had the original amendment passed by this chamber been passed into law.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of interim orders relating to disputed custody matters, it is quite clear that the House of Representatives has made a very sensible amendment. It will enable judicial registrars to provide valuable relief to the judiciary in urgent matters which arise from day to day in each registry, particularly during court vacations, recesses and so on, when a prompt response is required. I thank the chamber for its support for that amendment. As to the question of the upper limit that might be placed on the jurisdiction of magistrates courts in dealing with the matters we have agreed may be dealt with by a magistrate, it is true-I can understand Senator Haines's distress at the fact--

TALK.START.PARA: —Try `anger'.

—I will accept `anger' because it has been properly manifested. I can understand Senator Haines's anger at the fact that an amendment which she suggested in absolute good faith and which, I must say, I concurred in in good faith has not found favour in the House of Representatives. Nevertheless, the House of Representatives amendment does have the virtue of providing a jurisdictional limit which is simple to understand and which does not require definitions of motor vehicles. Such definitions, whilst they can be somewhat pedantic and petty, in fact vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In New South Wales they are set in order to determine questions of liability in relation to motor vehicle accidents and so on rather than the question of property distribution about which we are concerned. Therefore, I think that amendment has the virtue of simplicity and ought to commend itself to the chamber. For that reason the Government will be opposing the amendment moved by Senator Durack to amendment No. 9 and amendment No. 20.

I must say that the way in which this whole issue has been approached by the Government and the Australian Democrats has been entirely unsatisfactory. I reiterate that the Government's original proposals-which the Government and presumably the Australian Democrats were prepared to pass; certainly they were not prepared to have the matter examined in detail by a committee of the Senate back in December- were on a completely different track altogether; namely, that the jurisdiction of magistrates in regard to property settlements would be determined by whatever jurisdiction the magistrates had in debt recovery in the particular State in which they were sitting. Senator Tate has conceded that is a totally absurd proposition. The Opposition's approach has always been that there should be a set figure for the jurisdiction. We had amendments to that effect on the table. We have consistently maintained the figure of $10,000 through the various changes of attitude exhibited by the Government and the Democrats. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which is a very important piece of legislation, highlights where responsibility for and hypocrisy in this matter lie. In fact, I think it is fair to say that in recent times the Opposition has taken a very considered and responsible position in relation to environmental matters. Thanks to the good efforts of the shadow Minister for the environment, we now have a situation in this country where each of the States recognises that the Federal Government has a role to play in this important area. That is a breakthrough for which all Australians should be grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: It is against that background that one must look very closely at the provisions of this Bill. On the face of it, the second reading speech in particular seems fairly innocuous. However, a closer analysis of it can only cause one to wonder what the real agenda is meant to be. One of the matters of most concern is the provision in relation to identified property. That regime is supposedly included because it provides a new definition so that the principal Act will follow more closely the World Heritage Convention. But the reality is that the Convention creates no duty to protect individual World Heritage property and make no mention of interim protective measures. I think the High Court of Australia, in its recent judgment, went almost as far as it can possibly go in terms of the limits of the external affairs powers. As a result, one is left wondering why there should be a need for this type of legislation. I shall refer for a moment to some of the remarks of Chief Justice Mason and Mr Justice Brennan who handed down the leading joint judgment in the matter. In that judgment they said:

Here, however, we are not concerned with the making of a conclusive finding of constitutional facts necessary to support the exercise of a legislative power with respect to a head of power. Rather we are concerned to ascertain whether there is a basis for invalidating the legislative judgment that the area in question may possess world heritage characteristics which justify on an interim footing the freeze on activities . . .
At page 18 of this unprinted judgment they said:

The matters to which we have referred provide a basis for a legislative judgment that substantial parts of the area, the location of which cannot be identified at this time with any certainty, may conceivably possess world heritage characteristics which should be protected.

Later in the judgment they used a similar phrase. The effect of that is to create real doubts about the extent of the power that is sought in this Bill, because the court has accepted that normal principles of interlocutory application should apply to this type of legislation. One cannot quarrel with the logic of that because it is a well recognised principle of equity that interlocutory relief should be available if irreparable harm is likely to be caused. If one were to stand back for a moment and look at the nature of this type of legislation, it should become clear that, within this whole idea of declaring something to be of outstanding natural or cultural value, we are not dealing with a transient piece of the environment or something that can be destroyed by a few simple movements of vehicles or men; we are dealing with something that is of enduring quality and, presumably, of outstanding significance.

Against that background it is very difficult to imagine how something which, for perhaps thousands or millions of years-certainly for the past 200 years-has stayed in place without too much desecration or violation of its integrity can all of a sudden at the whim of a Minister be the subject of a court action on the basis that irreparable harm will flow unless an interim injunction, an interlocutory, is granted. That strikes me as passing strange because it has connotations of political opportunism, of wanting to up the ante, of somehow wanting to bring the court into a highly contentious area where it is forced to exercise its prerogative powers and to grant equitable relief when there is no good reason why the normal procedures should not be followed. When one examines the Act even more closely, I think it becomes even more apparent that what we have here is a very unhealthy admixture of law and politics.

I turn now to the scheme that will apply not only for the appointment of inspectors but also in relation to the powers that they will be given. Inspectors are to be given a whole range of powers to enter and search, record occurrences, and inspect, examine, photograph and take measurements of an eligible thing. An eligible thing is almost self-defining. It is whatever the Government says it is. Inspectors are to be given enormous powers and are to be allowed, almost at will, to enter upon premises. One has to ask why they are to be given those powers. Is it to collect material for court cases? Is it somehow to preserve minute samples that might be used for archeological purposes? It is more likely that those powers are being conferred in order to provide the Government with very wide discretion to inject a sense of urgency and to create political issues where none exist and then to put the onus on the court to determine these matters. I think that is both invidious and insidious. An inspector will have the power to enter a property on a warrant granted by a judge. That is not an unusual situation. Judges are often asked to grant warrants. However, in normal circumstances the judges who grant such warrants sit in a practice court and are called upon in rotation to exercise the normal powers of the court. That is the very last thing for which this proposed Act provides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on a matter that was initially engendered in my mind by my colleague Senator Parer. He made a speech on 16 December last year in which he expressed a great deal of concern about the Endeavour Foundation in Queensland which had had a funding cut under the Disability Services Act. Because of that I decided to make some inquiries in my own State and found, to my horror, that things have been happening in Tasmania and all round Australia that should be brought to the attention of this Senate. It is a subject that I have become very interested in; it is a subject that I have looked at, and I have spoken to many people who are involved in, and work with, handicapped people, people with disabilities and people in sheltered workshops in Tasmania. I have found that, since December, I have had the opportunity to observe many programs operating in my home State. Just to refresh the minds of honourable senators, in 1986 the Government changed the old Handicapped Persons Act to the Disability Services Act No. 129. Let me just read the objects of that Act:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. The objects of this Act are-

(a) to replace provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, and of Part VIII of the Social Security Act 1947, with provisions that are more flexible and more responsive to the needs and aspirations of persons with disabilities;
(b) to ensure that persons with disabilities receive the services necessary to enable them to achieve their maximum potential as members of the community;
(c) to ensure that services provided to persons with disabilities-
(i) further the integration of persons with disabilities in the community, and complement services available generally to persons in the community;
(ii) enable persons with disabilities to achieve positive outcomes, such as increased independence, employment opportunities and integration in the community; and
(iii) are provided in ways that promote in the community a positive image of persons with disabilities and enhance their self-esteem;

(d) to ensure that the outcomes achieved by persons with disabilities by the provision of services for them are taken into account in the granting of financial assistance for the provision of such services;
(e) to encourage innovation in the provision of services for persons with disabilities; and

(f) to achieve positive outcomes, such as increased independence, employment opportunities and integration in the community, for persons with disabilities who are of working age by the provision of comprehensive rehabilitation services,
and this Act shall be construed and administered accordingly.

In 1987-88 all those people in Australia whose funding for the proposed expansion of their equipment and capital works comes under the Disability Services Act have received no funding at all. We are now nine months into this financial year. I was quite shocked when I saw that. I have had the opportunity to observe programs operating at the Summit workshop in Devonport, Oakdale, Rosedale and at the Walkabout workshop. Thirteen major industries in Tasmania are creating employment for disabled people and those poor disabled people are making a very big contribution to our community and are salvaging some pride from their disabilities. They have a lot of pride in, and respect for, themselves and their fellow workers in those situations.

Unfortunately, because of the lack of funding and the lack of direction by this Government under this Act I believe that, in some cases, the Government will rationalise some of the services. This will mean that a lot of these disabled people will not be able to be cared for. They will be thrust back into the situation they were before where they are not secure. I spoke to one person the other day who administered one of these workshops. He said that, when these people go on holidays, they cannot wait to get back to the workshops to do something to help their fellow workers. It gives them a sense of pride in, and respect for, their community.

Of course, we should not forget and the Government should not forget the quite significant savings that these centres provide to the taxpayers of Tasmania. Most of them are managed by community committees. I feel sorry for those people who are giving of their time on a voluntary basis. Even the people who are being paid for their work are very dedicated to the needs of the disabled. They are really confused. I was speaking to some of them the other day and they said, `In 1986 when this new Act came in, we were given an undertaking by the former Minister Don Grimes at the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled conference in June 1986 that it would simplify things and that we would not be any worse off. In fact, we could be better off'. The fact of the matter is that, on looking around and on making some investigations, for example, the Summit industries in Devonport received $31,000 in 1984-85, $94,000 in 1985-86, and $44,000 in 1986-87-an average of $57,000 over the last three or four years. This year they will be receiving about $16,000. As another example I believe that the St Vincent de Paul sheltered workshop at Wynyard received about $42,000 last year to assist in the upgrading of its equipment. It applied for $42,000 and it received $46,000 and that has been the average for the last three years. As a result of its submission this year it got nothing.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I assure you that the St Vincent de Paul Society not only was shattered at losing its leader in Tasmania this week, the Archbishop of Tasmania, Sir Guilford Young, who died very tragically, but also was shattered by being told this week that its funding for equipment this year is absolutely zero. What a disgrace it is that these people who give their time voluntarily, who are trying to do the right thing by the unfortunate people in our community, have been so disadvantaged. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Neal Blewett, proudly espoused in a Press release on 10 March this year:
The Government's newly-introduced Disability Services Act recognises that `People with disabilities have a right to be part of the community . . .
Further on Dr Blewett said:
. . . increased Federal funding would assist services reshape their programs . . .

I can assure honourable senators that their programs have been reshaped all right. Most of the organisations that I have spoken to will be reshaping their situations in such a way that these unfortunate disabled people, who have been taking such a pride in their active role in the community, will not be working at all. They will be going back into a situation where they will become a burden not only on their families but also on the community. That is not what they want and I do not believe that that is what the people of Australia want.

Another matter that came to my attention related to the St Giles centre in Launceston. This is Don Grimes's home town. I am sure he would be appalled to learn what is going on. The St Giles centre in Launceston runs two group homes accommodating seven severely disabled adults. These people cannot help themselves and need assistance with everything. The centre's annual recurrent costs are about $242,000. Its funding expires in June this year. It has received no word at all of any funding from this Government. One can imagine the distress this is causing to those disabled adults who rely on these homes for their shelter. One can imagine them trying to plan under these conditions.

As I have said, there have been many promises of added assistance and statements to the effect that there will be increased funding. However, all of the organisations I have contacted have suffered severe cut-backs. I have asked the people running the programs why they have not said or done anything. They have replied that they have been promised funds. Last October they were told to wait until next month; that there would be a statement from the Minister in November. Then they were put off to December, and then to January. All this time the unfortunate bureaucrats who have received no direction at all from the Minister, have said, `Trust us. It will be all right' One can gauge the value of trust when organisations such as St Giles that rely totally on funds from generous people in the community receive no assistance whatsoever from the Government.

I instance also Walkabout, Summit Workshops and Saint Vincent de Paul. They are just some of the groups in my State. Senator Parer referred to the Endeavour Workshop, one arm of the Endeavour Foundation. Recently I was told-I do not know whether it was correct-that the Endeavour Workshop is considering cutting back its program. It is one of the biggest organisations of this type in Australia. So, someone is telling lies somewhere along the line.

I refer to another small matter of people telling lies. When I returned from Hobart tonight I received a nice letter from a politician called Duncan Kerr, the member for Denison. He wanted to know whether Bruce Goodluck and I attended the South African Embassy last night during the suspension of the sitting for dinner. He said:
I am writing to you to give you the courtesy of allowing you to inform me that my information is not correct, should that be the case, or to explain . . .

I do not know what he is on about. The fact of the matter is that I was there. But that is my business. I practise politics the way I want to. If I feel that I can be of some assistance in respect of the situation in South Africa by talking to some of the people in that embassy, that is my business. I do not inquire of Duncan Kerr what he was doing with the Russians down in the Antarctic, or whether he goes to the Russian Embassy and talks about Afghanistan. That is his business. If I, along with Bruce Goodluck or anyone else, believe I can do some good by talking to officials at the South African Embassy, why should Mr Kerr write to me? He knows perfectly well that I was there; otherwise he would not have written to me. I put the record straight by saying that of course I was there. I was there for about 30 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you do any good in relation to the executions tomorrow?

—As a matter of fact, I spoke to a Mr Tramere from Sydney, as well as to his wife and a couple of other people. I do not know whether I did any good. But at least I spoke to them. I do not believe that a stand-off situation or throwing eggs from outside the embassy will do any good. I believe that the more that this Government and anyone else who is concerned about South Africa talk to these people and try to convince them, the better it will be. In conclusion, I return to my original topic and suggest that something should be done about the lack of funding for disabled people in our community. This is a matter of great concern to me and, indeed, to all Tasmanians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I spoke on the sad topic of jobs for the boys in the Labor Party in New South Wales. It is with a degree of sadness that I raise yet another instance of the jobs for the boys syndrome.
—Sadness my foot.

—Great sadness, because this affects Sydney University. The Sydney University Senate comprises 30 members. It now includes six members appointed by the New South Wales Minister for Education, Mr Cavalier, because recently the New South Wales Labor Government changed the Act so that the Minister could make more appointments. There are two further Government appointees: the Hon. Bryan Vaughan from the Legislative Council and Dr Refshauge from the Legislative Assembly. The membership of the Senate includes the Chairman of the Academic Board, three professors elected by the staff, three academics elected by the staff, one non-academic staff, 10 elected graduates, three students and one Vice-Chancellor. Whereas previously only five fellows were nominated by the Government, there is now a total of eight, including the delegates from the Legislative Council and the Legislative Assembly.

SPEECH.PARA: On Monday, 4 April next, the University Senate will elect its new Chancellor. Sir Herman Black, a most distinguished Australian who has been Chancellor since 1970, will on those figures almost certainly be rolled by Gough Whitlam by 16 votes to 14.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a distinguished appointment that will be.
—Jobs for the boys yet again, with a stacked Senate.
—Gough Whitlam-30 years in parliament; a former Prime Minister of Australia; a former Ambassador of UNESCO. Who are you kidding?

—Not elected by the academic appointments to the Senate but by a stacked ministerial appointment to give a margin of two votes to roll a distinguished Australian, Sir Herman Black. The jobs for the boys syndrome will extend even further. Should Gough Whitlam become Chancellor of Sydney University on the stacked appointments of Minister Cavalier, the position of Vice-Chancellor undoubtedly will go to one Peter Wilenski. That Labor appointment will be another instance of jobs for the boys.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one reason why the numbers will favour former Prime Minister Whitlam and Mr Peter Wilenski: Very simply, once again the Labor Government in New South Wales has changed an Act to enable it in this instance, to appoint its people to the University Senate to give it the numbers to again provide a job for its fellows. It is interesting to look at the names of those appointed by Minister Cavalier. They include Ms Jenny George, President of the New South Wales Teachers Federation; Ms Alison Ziller, Director for Equal Opportunity in New South Wales; Mr Robert Winder, New South Wales Director-General of Education; Dr Amy McGrath, historian and noted graduate of the university; Mr John O'Neill, Managing Director of the State Bank; and Mr Whitlam.

The reason I raise this issue is that previously there were denials that Mr Whitlam would stand against Sir Herman. After the concerned academics ran their own ticket for the first time in an academic election for the Sydney University Senate, they believed that the academics would have the numbers to prevail. As I said, it was only when Minister Cavalier chose to appoint a selected group of people that the numbers changed. I think it is important that this election not take place without people being aware of it. I refer particularly to undergraduates of Sydney University, people who care about the independence of a university, people who do not like politics being intruded into the activities of the Sydney University Senate. To quote the Australian, those people should be made aware of the spectre hanging over the Sydney University Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall refer Senator Calvert's concerns to the relevant Minister. I am not aware of the matters that he raised in detail, but I shall do my best to convey his concerns.
—Can you bring us a response?

—I shall make sure that the Minister considers giving a response to Senator Calvert. I am not sure that I will be the appropriate conduit at the time. However, I shall deliver to Senator Archer a response about the Antarctic ship as soon as I can.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Bishop's remarks, I, like all honourable senators, will be very happy when 19 March is over and gone and we no longer have to go through this process. We have just heard an attack on the New South Wales Government over some appointments to the Senate of Sydney University and the possibility of there being a ballot between Herman Black and Gough Whitlam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Herman Black.
—I am terribly sorry, between Sir Herman Black and Gough Whitlam, QC, MP, about who might be--
—MP?

—Well, he was once an MP; I think he was a Prime Minister! I am not really concerned with the unseemly numbers games that go on in these quarters. I would not choose to soil my hands in getting involved in those matters. Rather, it should suffice to say that as an eminent lawyer, as a distinguished parliamentarian, as a Deputy Leader of the Opposition, as a Leader of the Opposition, and as a Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam has served his country well, and I should have thought that Sydney University could not look for a better person than Gough Whitlam to be its chancellor.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.51 p.m.
